  <section id="read-the-docs-documentation-simplified">
<h1>Start with Ubuntu<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-documentation-simplified" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h1>
<span class="guilabel">Ubuntu v-16.04.7 LTS</span>
<p></p>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-tutorial/index"></span><section id="read-the-docs-tutorial">
<h2>Read the Docs tutorial<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-tutorial" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>In this tutorial you will create a documentation project on Read the Docs
by importing a Sphinx project from a GitHub repository,
tailor its configuration, and explore several useful features of the platform.</p>
<p>The tutorial is aimed at people interested in learning
how to use Read the Docs to host their documentation projects.
You will fork a fictional software library
similar to the one developed in the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/tutorial/index.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">official Sphinx tutorial</span></a>.
No prior experience with Sphinx is required
and you can follow this tutorial without having done the Sphinx one.</p>
<p>The only things you will need are
a web browser, an Internet connection, and a GitHub account
(you can <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/signup">register for a free account</a> if you don‚Äôt have one).
You will use Read the Docs Community, which means that the project will be public.</p>
<section id="getting-started">
<h3>Getting started<a class="headerlink" href="#getting-started" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<section id="preparing-your-project-on-github">
<h4>Preparing your project on GitHub<a class="headerlink" href="#preparing-your-project-on-github" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To start, <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/login">sign in to GitHub</a>
and navigate to <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/tutorial-template/">the tutorial GitHub template</a>,
where you will see a green <span class="guilabel">Use this template</span> button.
Click it to open a new page that will ask you for some details:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Leave the default ‚ÄúOwner‚Äù, or change it to something better for a tutorial project.</p></li>
<li><p>Introduce an appropriate ‚ÄúRepository name‚Äù, for example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rtd-tutorial</span></code>.</p></li>
<li><p>Make sure the project is ‚ÄúPublic‚Äù, rather than ‚ÄúPrivate‚Äù.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>After that, click on the green <span class="guilabel">Create repository from template</span> button,
which will generate a new repository on your personal account
(or the one of your choosing).
This is the repository you will import on Read the Docs,
and it contains the following files:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">README.rst</span></code></dt><dd><p>Basic description of the repository, you will leave it untouched.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">pyproject.toml</span></code></dt><dd><p>Python project metadata that makes it installable.
Useful for automatic documentation generation from sources.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">lumache.py</span></code></dt><dd><p>Source code of the fictional Python library.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/</span></code></dt><dd><p>Directory holding all the Sphinx documentation sources,
including the Sphinx configuration <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/source/conf.py</span></code>
and the root document <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/source/index.rst</span></code> written in reStructuredText.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<figure class="align-center" id="id3">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/github-template.png"><img alt="GitHub template for the tutorial" src="_images/github-template.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">GitHub template for the tutorial</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id3" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
<section id="sign-up-for-read-the-docs">
<h4>Sign up for Read the Docs<a class="headerlink" href="#sign-up-for-read-the-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To sign up for a Read the Docs account,
navigate to the <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/signup/">Sign Up page</a>
and choose the option <span class="guilabel">Sign up with GitHub</span>.
On the authorization page, click the green <span class="guilabel">Authorize readthedocs</span> button.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id4">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/github-authorization.png"><img alt="GitHub authorization page" src="_images/github-authorization.png" style="width: 60%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">GitHub authorization page</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id4" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Read the Docs needs elevated permissions to perform certain operations
that ensure that the workflow is as smooth as possible,
like installing <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a>.
If you want to learn more,
check out <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#permissions-for-connected-accounts"><span class="std std-ref">Permissions for connected accounts</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<p>After that, you will be redirected to Read the Docs,
where you will need to confirm your e-mail and username.
Clicking the <span class="guilabel">Sign Up ¬ª</span> button will create your account
and redirect you to your <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-dashboard"><span class="xref std std-term">dashboard</span></a>.</p>
<p>By now, you should have two email notifications:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>One from GitHub, telling you that ‚ÄúA third-party OAuth application ‚Ä¶
was recently authorized to access your account‚Äù. You don‚Äôt need to do
anything about it.</p></li>
<li><p>Another one from Read the Docs, prompting you to ‚Äúverify your email
address‚Äù. Click on the link to finalize the process.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Once done, your Read the Docs account is created
and ready to import your first project.</p>
<p>Welcome!</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id5">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/rtd-empty-dashboard.png"><img alt="Read the Docs empty dashboard" src="_images/rtd-empty-dashboard.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Read the Docs empty dashboard</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id5" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Our commercial site offers some extra features,
like support for private projects.
You can learn more about <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-choosing-a-site"><span class="doc">our two different sites</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<section id="first-steps">
<h3>First steps<a class="headerlink" href="#first-steps" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<section id="importing-the-project-to-read-the-docs">
<h4>Importing the project to Read the Docs<a class="headerlink" href="#importing-the-project-to-read-the-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To import your GitHub project to Read the Docs,
first click on the <span class="guilabel">Import a Project</span> button on your dashboard
(or browse to <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/import/">the import page</a> directly).
You should see your GitHub account under the ‚ÄúFilter repositories‚Äù list on the right.
If the list of repositories is empty, click the üîÑ button,
and after that all your repositories will appear on the center.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id6">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/rtd-import-projects.gif"><img alt="Import projects workflow" src="_images/rtd-import-projects.gif" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Import projects workflow</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id6" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Locate your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rtd-tutorial</span></code> project
(possibly clicking <span class="guilabel">next ‚Ä∫‚Ä∫</span> at the bottom if you have several pages of projects),
and then click on the ‚ûï button to the right of the name.
The next page will ask you to fill some details about your Read the Docs project:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Name</dt><dd><p>The name of the project. It has to be unique across all the service,
so it is better if you prepend your username,
for example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">{username}-rtd-tutorial</span></code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Repository URL</dt><dd><p>The URL that contains the sources. Leave the automatically filled value.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Repository type</dt><dd><p>Version control system used, leave it as ‚ÄúGit‚Äù.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Default branch</dt><dd><p>Name of the default branch of the project, leave it as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Edit advanced project options</dt><dd><p>Leave it unchecked, we will make some changes later.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>After hitting the <span class="guilabel">Next</span> button, you will be redirected to the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>.
You just created your first project on Read the Docs! üéâ</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id7">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/rtd-project-home.png"><img alt="Project home" src="_images/rtd-project-home.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Project home</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id7" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
<section id="checking-the-first-build">
<h4>Checking the first build<a class="headerlink" href="#checking-the-first-build" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs will try to build the documentation of your project
right after you create it.
To see the build logs,
click on the <span class="guilabel">Your documentation is building</span> link on the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>,
or alternatively navigate to the ‚ÄúBuilds‚Äù page,
then open the one on top (the most recent one).</p>
<p>If the build has not finished yet by the time you open it,
you will see a spinner next to a ‚ÄúInstalling‚Äù or ‚ÄúBuilding‚Äù indicator,
meaning that it is still in progress.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id8">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/rtd-first-successful-build.png"><img alt="First successful documentation build" src="_images/rtd-first-successful-build.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">First successful documentation build</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id8" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>When the build finishes, you will see a green ‚ÄúBuild completed‚Äù indicator,
the completion date, the elapsed time,
and a link to see the corresponding documentation.
If you now click on <span class="guilabel">View docs</span>, you will see your documentation live!</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id9">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/rtd-first-light.png"><img alt="HTML documentation live on Read the Docs" src="_images/rtd-first-light.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">HTML documentation live on Read the Docs</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id9" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Advertisement is one of our main sources of revenue.
If you want to learn more about how do we fund our operations
and explore options to go ad-free,
check out our <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/sustainability/">Sustainability page</a>.</p>
<p>If you don‚Äôt see the ad, you might be using an ad blocker.
Our EthicalAds network respects your privacy, doesn‚Äôt target you,
and tries to be as unobstrusive as possible,
so we would like to kindly ask you to <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-advertising/ad-blocking"><span class="doc">not block us</span></a> ‚ù§Ô∏è</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="basic-configuration-changes">
<h4>Basic configuration changes<a class="headerlink" href="#basic-configuration-changes" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can now proceed to make some basic configuration adjustments.
Navigate back to the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-page"><span class="xref std std-term">project page</span></a>
and click on the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> button, which will open the Settings page.</p>
<p>First of all, add the following text in the description:</p>
<blockquote>
<div><p>Lumache (/lu‚Äômake/) is a Python library for cooks and food lovers
that creates recipes mixing random ingredients.</p>
</div></blockquote>
<p>Then set the project homepage to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://world.openfoodfacts.org/</span></code>,
and write <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">food,</span> <span class="pre">python</span></code> in the list of tags.
All this information will be shown on your project home.</p>
<p>After that, configure your email so you get a notification if the build fails.
To do so, click on the <span class="guilabel">Notifications</span> link on the left,
type the email where you would like to get the notification,
and click the <span class="guilabel">Add</span> button.
After that, your email will be shown under ‚ÄúExisting Notifications‚Äù.</p>
</section>
<section id="trigger-a-build-from-a-pull-request">
<h4>Trigger a build from a pull request<a class="headerlink" href="#trigger-a-build-from-a-pull-request" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs allows you to <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">trigger builds from GitHub pull requests</span></a>
and gives you a preview of how the documentation would look like with those changes.</p>
<p>To enable that functionality, first click on the <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span> link on the left
under the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> menu, check the ‚ÄúBuild pull requests for this project‚Äù checkbox,
and click the <span class="guilabel">Save</span> button at the bottom of the page.</p>
<p>Next, navigate to your GitHub repository, locate the file <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/source/index.rst</span></code>,
and click on the ‚úèÔ∏è icon on the top-right with the tooltip ‚ÄúEdit this file‚Äù
to open a web editor (more information <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-files-in-a-repository/managing-files-on-github/editing-files-in-your-repository">on their documentation</a>).</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id10">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/gh-edit.png"><img alt="File view on GitHub before launching the editor" src="_images/gh-edit.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">File view on GitHub before launching the editor</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id10" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>In the editor, add the following sentence to the file:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id11">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">docs/source/index.rst</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id11" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>Lumache has its documentation hosted on Read the Docs.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Write an appropriate commit message,
and choose the ‚ÄúCreate a <strong>new branch</strong> for this commit and start a pull request‚Äù option,
typing a name for the new branch.
When you are done, click the green <span class="guilabel">Propose changes</span> button,
which will take you to the new pull request page,
and there click the <span class="guilabel">Create pull request</span> button below the description.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id12">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/gh-pr-build.png"><img alt="Read the Docs building the pull request from GitHub" src="_images/gh-pr-build.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Read the Docs building the pull request from GitHub</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id12" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>After opening the pull request, a Read the Docs check will appear
indicating that it is building the documentation for that pull request.
If you click on the <span class="guilabel">Details</span> link while it is building,
you will access the build logs,
otherwise it will take you directly to the documentation.
When you are satisfied, you can merge the pull request!</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="customizing-the-build-process">
<h3>Customizing the build process<a class="headerlink" href="#customizing-the-build-process" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>The Settings page of the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a> allows you
to change some <em>global</em> configuration values of your project.
In addition, you can further customize the building process
using the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/v2"><span class="doc">configuration file</span></a>.
This has several advantages:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>The configuration lives next to your code and documentation, tracked by version control.</p></li>
<li><p>It can be different for every version (more on versioning in the next section).</p></li>
<li><p>Some configurations are only available using the config file.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Read the Docs works without this configuration
by <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#default-versions-of-dependencies"><span class="std std-ref">making some decisions on your behalf</span></a>.
For example, what Python version to use, how to install the requirements, and others.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Settings that apply to the entire project are controlled in the web dashboard,
while settings that are version or build specific are better in the YAML file.</p>
</div>
<section id="upgrading-the-python-version">
<h4>Upgrading the Python version<a class="headerlink" href="#upgrading-the-python-version" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>For example, to explicitly use Python 3.8 to build your project,
navigate to your GitHub repository, click on the <span class="guilabel">Add file</span> button,
and add a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> file with these contents to the root of your project:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id13">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">.readthedocs.yaml</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id13" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nt">version</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">2</span>

<span class="nt">build</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">os</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;ubuntu-20.04&quot;</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">tools</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="nt">python</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;3.8&quot;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The purpose of each key is:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">version</span></code></dt><dd><p>Mandatory, specifies <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/v2"><span class="doc">version 2 of the configuration file</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">build.os</span></code></dt><dd><p>Required to specify the Python version,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#build-os"><span class="std std-ref">states the name of the base image</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">build.tools.python</span></code></dt><dd><p>Declares the Python version to be used.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>After you commit these changes, go back to your project home,
navigate to the ‚ÄúBuilds‚Äù page, and open the new build that just started.
You will notice that one of the lines contains <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">python3.8</span></code>:
if you click on it, you will see the full output of the corresponding command,
stating that it used Python 3.8.6 to create the virtual environment.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id14">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/build-python3.8.png"><img alt="Read the Docs build using Python 3.8" src="_images/build-python3.8.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Read the Docs build using Python 3.8</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id14" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
<section id="making-warnings-more-visible">
<h4>Making warnings more visible<a class="headerlink" href="#making-warnings-more-visible" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you navigate to your HTML documentation,
you will notice that the index page looks correct
but the API section is empty.
This is a very common issue with Sphinx,
and the reason is stated in the build logs.
On the build page you opened before,
click on the <span class="guilabel">View raw</span> link on the top right,
which opens the build logs in plain text,
and you will see several warnings:</p>
<div class="highlight-text notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>WARNING: [autosummary] failed to import &#39;lumache&#39;: no module named lumache
...
WARNING: autodoc: failed to import function &#39;get_random_ingredients&#39; from module &#39;lumache&#39;; the following exception was raised:
No module named &#39;lumache&#39;
WARNING: autodoc: failed to import exception &#39;InvalidKindError&#39; from module &#39;lumache&#39;; the following exception was raised:
No module named &#39;lumache&#39;
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>To spot these warnings more easily and allow you to address them,
you can add the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx.fail_on_warning</span></code> option to your Read the Docs configuration file.
For that, navigate to GitHub, locate the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> file you created earlier,
click on the ‚úèÔ∏è icon, and add these contents:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id15">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">.readthedocs.yaml</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id15" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nt">version</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">2</span>

<span class="nt">build</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">os</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;ubuntu-20.04&quot;</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">tools</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="nt">python</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;3.8&quot;</span>

<span class="hll"><span class="nt">sphinx</span><span class="p">:</span>
</span><span class="hll"><span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">fail_on_warning</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">true</span>
</span></pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>At this point, if you navigate back to your ‚ÄúBuilds‚Äù page,
you will see a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Failed</span></code> build, which is exactly the intended result:
the Sphinx project is not properly configured yet,
and instead of rendering an empty API page, now the build fails.</p>
<p>The reason <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/autosummary.html#module-sphinx.ext.autosummary" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx.ext.autosummary</span></code></a> and <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/autodoc.html#module-sphinx.ext.autodoc" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx.ext.autodoc</span></code></a>
fail to import the code is because it is not installed.
Luckily, the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> also allows you to specify
which requirements to install.</p>
<p>To install the library code of your project,
go back to editing <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> on GitHub and modify it as follows:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id16">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">.readthedocs.yaml</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id16" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nt">python</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="hll"><span class="w">  </span><span class="c1"># Install our python package before building the docs</span>
</span><span class="hll"><span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">install</span><span class="p">:</span>
</span><span class="hll"><span class="w">    </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">method</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">pip</span>
</span><span class="w">      </span><span class="nt">path</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">.</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>With this change, Read the Docs will install the Python code
before starting the Sphinx build, which will finish seamlessly.
If you go now to the API page of your HTML documentation,
you will see the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">lumache</span></code> summary!</p>
</section>
<section id="enabling-pdf-and-epub-builds">
<h4>Enabling PDF and EPUB builds<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-pdf-and-epub-builds" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Sphinx can build several other formats in addition to HTML, such as PDF and EPUB.
You might want to enable these formats for your project
so your users can read the documentation offline.</p>
<p>To do so, add this extra content to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code>:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id17">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">.readthedocs.yaml</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id17" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nt">sphinx</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">fail_on_warning</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">true</span>

<span class="hll"><span class="nt">formats</span><span class="p">:</span>
</span><span class="hll"><span class="w">  </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">pdf</span>
</span><span class="hll"><span class="w">  </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">epub</span>
</span></pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After this change, PDF and EPUB downloads will be available
both from the ‚ÄúDownloads‚Äù section of the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>,
as well as the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a>.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id18">
<img alt="Downloads available from the flyout menu" src="_images/flyout-downloads.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Downloads available from the flyout menu</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id18" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
</section>
<section id="versioning-documentation">
<h3>Versioning documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#versioning-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs allows you to have <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">several versions of your documentation</span></a>,
in the same way that you have several versions of your code.
By default, it creates a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version
that points to the default branch of your version control system
(<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code> in the case of this tutorial),
and that‚Äôs why the URLs of your HTML documentation contain the string <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/latest/</span></code>.</p>
<section id="creating-a-new-version">
<h4>Creating a new version<a class="headerlink" href="#creating-a-new-version" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Let‚Äôs say you want to create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0</span></code> version of your code,
with a corresponding <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0</span></code> version of the documentation.
For that, first navigate to your GitHub repository, click on the branch selector,
type <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code>, and click on ‚ÄúCreate branch: 1.0.x from ‚Äòmain‚Äô‚Äù
(more information <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-and-deleting-branches-within-your-repository">on their documentation</a>).</p>
<p>Next, go to your <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>, click on the <span class="guilabel">Versions</span> button,
and under ‚ÄúActive Versions‚Äù you will see two entries:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version, pointing to the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code> branch.</p></li>
<li><p>A new <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version, pointing to the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">origin/1.0.x</span></code> branch.</p></li>
</ul>
<figure class="align-center" id="id19">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/active-versions.png"><img alt="List of active versions of the project" src="_images/active-versions.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">List of active versions of the project</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id19" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Right after you created your branch,
Read the Docs created a new special version called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> pointing to it,
and started building it. When the build finishes,
the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version will be listed in the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a>
and your readers will be able to choose it.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Read the Docs <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#how-we-envision-versions-working"><span class="std std-ref">follows some rules</span></a>
to decide whether to create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version pointing to your new branch or tag.
To simplify, it will check if the name resembles a version number
like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0.3</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">4.x</span></code>.</p>
</div>
<p>Now you might want to set <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> as the <em>default version</em>,
rather than <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code>,
so that users see the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> documentation
when they visit the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-root-URL"><span class="xref std std-term">root URL</span></a> of your documentation
(while still being able to change the version in the flyout menu).</p>
<p>For that, go to the <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span> link
under the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> menu of your project home,
choose <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> in the ‚ÄúDefault version*‚Äù dropdown,
and hit <span class="guilabel">Save</span> at the bottom.
Done!</p>
</section>
<section id="modifying-versions">
<h4>Modifying versions<a class="headerlink" href="#modifying-versions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Both <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> are now <em>active</em>, which means that
they are visible for users, and new builds can be triggered for them.
In addition to these, Read the Docs also created an <em>inactive</em> <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code>
version, which will always point to the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> branch of your repository.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id20">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/inactive-versions.png"><img alt="List of inactive versions of the project" src="_images/inactive-versions.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">List of inactive versions of the project</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id20" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Let‚Äôs activate the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> version.
For that, go to the ‚ÄúVersions‚Äù on your <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>,
locate <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> under ‚ÄúActivate a version‚Äù,
and click on the <span class="guilabel">Activate</span> button.
This will take you to a new page with two checkboxes,
‚ÄúActive‚Äù and ‚ÄúHidden‚Äù. Check only ‚ÄúActive‚Äù,
and click <span class="guilabel">Save</span>.</p>
<p>After you do this, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> will appear on the ‚ÄúActive Versions‚Äù section,
and a new build will be triggered for it.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You can read more about <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#hidden"><span class="std std-ref">hidden versions</span></a>
in our documentation.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="show-a-warning-for-old-versions">
<h4>Show a warning for old versions<a class="headerlink" href="#show-a-warning-for-old-versions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When your project matures, the number of versions might increase.
Sometimes you will want to warn your readers
when they are browsing an old or outdated version of your documentation.</p>
<p>To showcase how to do that, let‚Äôs create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0</span></code> version of the code:
navigate to your GitHub repository, click on the branch selector,
type <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0.x</span></code>, and click on ‚ÄúCreate branch: 2.0.x from ‚Äòmain‚Äô‚Äù.
This will trigger two things:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Since <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0.x</span></code> is your newest branch, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> will switch to tracking it.</p></li>
<li><p>A new <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0.x</span></code> version will be created on your Read the Docs project.</p></li>
<li><p>Since you already have an active <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0.x</span></code> will be activated.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>From this point, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> version is no longer the most up to date one.
To display a warning to your readers, go to the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> menu of your project home,
click on the <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span> link on the left,
enable the ‚ÄúShow version warning‚Äù checkbox, and click the <span class="guilabel">Save</span> button.</p>
<p>If you now browse the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.0.x</span></code> documentation, you will see a warning on top
encouraging you to browse the latest version instead. Neat!</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id21">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/old-version-warning.png"><img alt="Warning for old versions" src="_images/old-version-warning.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Warning for old versions</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id21" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
</section>
<section id="getting-insights-from-your-projects">
<h3>Getting insights from your projects<a class="headerlink" href="#getting-insights-from-your-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Once your project is up and running, you will probably want to understand
how readers are using your documentation, addressing some common questions like:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>what pages are the most visited pages?</p></li>
<li><p>what search terms are the most frequently used?</p></li>
<li><p>are readers finding what they look for?</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Read the Docs offers you some analytics tools to find out the answers.</p>
<section id="browsing-traffic-analytics">
<h4>Browsing traffic analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#browsing-traffic-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-analytics"><span class="doc">How to use traffic analytics</span></a> view shows the top viewed documentation pages of the past 30 days,
plus a visualization of the daily views during that period.
To generate some artificial views on your newly created project,
you can first click around the different pages of your project,
which will be accounted immediately for the current day statistics.</p>
<p>To see the Traffic Analytics view, go back the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-project-page"><span class="xref std std-term">project page</span></a> again,
click on the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> button,
and then click on the <span class="guilabel">Traffic Analytics</span> section.
You will see the list of pages in descending order of visits,
as well as a plot similar to the one below.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id22">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/traffic-analytics-plot.png"><img alt="Traffic Analytics plot" src="_images/traffic-analytics-plot.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Traffic Analytics plot</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id22" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The Traffic Analytics view explained above gives you a simple overview
of how your readers browse your documentation. It has the advantage that
it stores no identifying information about your visitors,
and therefore it respects their privacy.
However, you might want to get more detailed data by
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#enabling-google-analytics-on-your-project"><span class="std std-ref">enabling Google Analytics</span></a>.
Notice though that we take some extra measures to <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#analytics"><span class="std std-ref">respect user
privacy</span></a>
when they visit projects that have Google Analytics enabled,
and this might reduce the number of visits counted.</p>
</div>
<p>Finally, you can also download this data for closer inspection.
To do that, scroll to the bottom of the page
and click on the <span class="guilabel">Download all data</span> button.
That will prompt you to download a <abbr title="Comma-Separated Values">CSV</abbr> file
that you can process any way you want.</p>
</section>
<section id="browsing-search-analytics">
<h4>Browsing search analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#browsing-search-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Apart from traffic analytics, Read the Docs also offers the possibility
to inspect <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/search-analytics"><span class="doc">what search terms your readers use</span></a>
on your documentation.
This can inform decisions on what areas to reinforce,
or what parts of your project are less understood or more difficult to find.</p>
<p>To generate some artificial search statistics on the project,
go to the HTML documentation, locate the Sphinx search box on the left,
type <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">ingredients</span></code>, and press the <kbd class="kbd docutils literal notranslate">Enter</kbd> key.
You will be redirected to the search results page, which will show two entries.</p>
<p>Next, go back to the <span class="guilabel">‚öô Admin</span> section of your project page,
and then click on the <span class="guilabel">Search Analytics</span> section.
You will see a table with the most searched queries
(including the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">ingredients</span></code> one you just typed),
how many results did each query return, and how many times it was searched.
Below the queries table, you will also see a visualization
of the daily number of search queries during the past 30 days.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id23">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/search-analytics-terms.png"><img alt="Most searched terms" src="_images/search-analytics-terms.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Most searched terms</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id23" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Like the Traffic Analytics, you can also download the whole dataset in CSV format
by clicking on the <span class="guilabel">Download all data</span> button.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="where-to-go-from-here">
<h3>Where to go from here<a class="headerlink" href="#where-to-go-from-here" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This is the end of the tutorial. You started by forking a GitHub repository
and importing it on Read the Docs, building its HTML documentation,
and then went through a series of steps to customize the build process,
tweak the project configuration, and add new versions.</p>
<p>Here you have some resources to continue learning about documentation
and Read the Docs:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>You can learn more about the functionality of the platform
by going over our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/features"><span class="doc">features</span></a> page.</p></li>
<li><p>To make the most of the documentation generators that are supported,
you can read the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/tutorial/index.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">Sphinx tutorial</span></a>
or the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/">MkDocs User Guide</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Display example projects and read the source code in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-examples"><span class="doc">Example projects</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Whether you are a documentation author, a project administrator, a developer, or a designer,
you can follow our how-to guides that cover specific tasks,
available under <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/index"><span class="doc">How-to guides A-Z</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>For private project support and other enterprise features,
you can use <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">our commercial service</span></a>
(and if in doubt, check out <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-choosing-a-site"><span class="doc">Choosing between our two platforms</span></a>).</p></li>
<li><p>Do you want to join a global community of fellow <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">documentarians</span></code>?
Check out <a class="reference external" href="https://www.writethedocs.org/">Write the Docs</a> and
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.writethedocs.org/slack/" title="(in Write the Docs v1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">its Slack workspace</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Do you want to contribute to Read the Docs?
We greatly appreciate it! Check out <a class="reference external" href="https://dev.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contribute.html" title="(in Read the Docs developer documentation v9.13.0)"><span>Contributing to Read the Docs</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Happy documenting!</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-intro/getting-started-with-sphinx"></span><section id="getting-started-with-sphinx">
<h2>Getting started with Sphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#getting-started-with-sphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>Sphinx is a powerful documentation generator that
has many great features for writing technical documentation including:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Generate web pages, printable PDFs, documents for e-readers (ePub),
and more all from the same sources</p></li>
<li><p>You can use reStructuredText or <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#using-markdown-with-sphinx"><span class="std std-ref">Markdown</span></a>
to write documentation</p></li>
<li><p>An extensive system of cross-referencing code and documentation</p></li>
<li><p>Syntax highlighted code samples</p></li>
<li><p>A vibrant ecosystem of first and third-party <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/index.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">extensions</span></a></p></li>
</ul>
<p>If you want to learn more about how to create your first Sphinx project, read on.
If you are interested in exploring the Read the Docs platform using an already existing Sphinx project,
check out <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-tutorial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs tutorial</span></a>.</p>
<section id="quick-start">
<h3>Quick start<a class="headerlink" href="#quick-start" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>If you already have a Sphinx project, check out our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/import-guide"><span class="doc">Importing your documentation</span></a> guide.</p>
</div>
<p>Assuming you have Python already, <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/installation.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">install Sphinx</span></a>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">pip<span class="w"> </span>install<span class="w"> </span>sphinx</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Create a directory inside your project to hold your docs:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1"><span class="nb">cd</span><span class="w"> </span>/path/to/project</span>
<span class="prompt1">mkdir<span class="w"> </span>docs</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Run <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx-quickstart</span></code> in there:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1"><span class="nb">cd</span><span class="w"> </span>docs</span>
<span class="prompt1">sphinx-quickstart</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This quick start will walk you through creating the basic configuration; in most cases, you
can just accept the defaults. When it‚Äôs done, you‚Äôll have an <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">index.rst</span></code>, a
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> and some other files. Add these to revision control.</p>
<p>Now, edit your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">index.rst</span></code> and add some information about your project.
Include as much detail as you like (refer to the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">reStructuredText syntax</span></a>
or <a class="reference external" href="https://www.writethedocs.org/guide/writing/beginners-guide-to-docs/#id1">this template</a> if you need help). Build them to see how they look:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">make<span class="w"> </span>html</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">index.rst</span></code> has been built into <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">index.html</span></code>
in your documentation output directory (typically <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_build/html/index.html</span></code>).
Open this file in your web browser to see your docs.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1" style="width: 500px">
<img alt="_images/sphinx-hello-world.png" src="_images/sphinx-hello-world.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Your Sphinx project is built</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Edit your files and rebuild until you like what you see, then commit your changes and push to your public repository.
Once you have Sphinx documentation in a public repository, you can start using Read the Docs
by <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/import-guide"><span class="doc">importing your docs</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>We strongly recommend to <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">pin the Sphinx version</span></a>
used for your project to build the docs to avoid potential future incompatibilities.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="using-markdown-with-sphinx">
<h3>Using Markdown with Sphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#using-markdown-with-sphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>You can use <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using/intro.html">Markdown using MyST</a> and reStructuredText in the same Sphinx project.
We support this natively on Read the Docs, and you can do it locally:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">pip<span class="w"> </span>install<span class="w"> </span>myst-parser</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Then in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&quot;myst_parser&quot;</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>You can now continue writing your docs in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> files and it will work with Sphinx.
Read the <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/sphinx/intro.html">Getting started with MyST in Sphinx</a> docs for additional instructions.</p>
</section>
<section id="get-inspired">
<h3>Get inspired!<a class="headerlink" href="#get-inspired" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>You might learn more and find the first ingredients for starting your own documentation project by looking at <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-examples"><span class="doc">Example projects</span></a> - view live example renditions and copy &amp; paste from the accompanying source code.</p>
</section>
<section id="external-resources">
<h3>External resources<a class="headerlink" href="#external-resources" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Here are some external resources to help you learn more about Sphinx.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/">Sphinx documentation</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">RestructuredText primer</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2016/jul/1/sphinx-and-rtd-for-writers/">An introduction to Sphinx and Read the Docs for technical writers</a></p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-intro/getting-started-with-mkdocs"></span><section id="getting-started-with-mkdocs">
<h2>Getting started with MkDocs<a class="headerlink" href="#getting-started-with-mkdocs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>MkDocs is a documentation generator that focuses on speed and simplicity.
It has many great features including:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Preview your documentation as you write it</p></li>
<li><p>Easy customization with themes and extensions</p></li>
<li><p>Writing documentation with Markdown</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>MkDocs is a great choice for building technical documentation.
However, Read the Docs also supports <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/getting-started-with-sphinx"><span class="doc">Sphinx</span></a>,
another tool for writing and building documentation.</p>
</div>
<section id="quick-start">
<h3>Quick start<a class="headerlink" href="#quick-start" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>If you already have a Mkdocs project, check out our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/import-guide"><span class="doc">Importing your documentation</span></a> guide.</p>
</div>
<p>Assuming you have Python already, <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/installation/">install MkDocs</a>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><style type="text/css">
span.prompt1:before {
  content: "$ ";
}
</style><span class="prompt1">pip<span class="w"> </span>install<span class="w"> </span>mkdocs</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Setup your MkDocs project:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">mkdocs<span class="w"> </span>new<span class="w"> </span>.</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This command creates <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">mkdocs.yml</span></code> which holds your MkDocs configuration,
and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/index.md</span></code> which is the Markdown file
that is the entry point for your documentation.</p>
<p>You can edit this <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">index.md</span></code> file to add more details about your project
and then you can build your documentation:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">mkdocs<span class="w"> </span>serve</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This command builds your Markdown files into HTML
and starts a development server to browse your documentation.
Open up <a class="reference external" href="http://127.0.0.1:8000/">http://127.0.0.1:8000/</a> in your web browser to see your documentation.
You can make changes to your Markdown files and your docs will automatically rebuild.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1" style="width: 500px">
<img alt="_images/mkdocs-hello-world.png" src="_images/mkdocs-hello-world.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Your MkDocs project is built</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Once you have your documentation in a public repository such as GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab,
you can start using Read the Docs by <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/import-guide"><span class="doc">importing your docs</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>We strongly recommend to <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">pin the MkDocs version</span></a>
used for your project to build the docs to avoid potential future incompatibilities.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="get-inspired">
<h3>Get inspired!<a class="headerlink" href="#get-inspired" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>You might learn more and find the first ingredients for starting your own documentation project by looking at <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-examples"><span class="doc">Example projects</span></a> - view live example renditions and copy &amp; paste from the accompanying source code.</p>
</section>
<section id="external-resources">
<h3>External resources<a class="headerlink" href="#external-resources" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Here are some external resources to help you learn more about MkDocs.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/">MkDocs documentation</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax">Markdown syntax guide</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/writing-your-docs/">Writing your docs with MkDocs</a></p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-intro/import-guide"></span><section id="importing-your-documentation">
<h2>Importing your documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#importing-your-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>To import a public documentation repository, visit your <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/dashboard">Read the Docs dashboard</a> and click <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/import">Import</a>.
For private repositories, please use <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.</p>
<section id="automatically-import-your-docs">
<h3>Automatically import your docs<a class="headerlink" href="#automatically-import-your-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you have <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-connected-accounts"><span class="doc">connected your Read the Docs account</span></a> to GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab,
you will see a list of your repositories that we are able to import.
To import one of these projects, just click the import
icon next to the repository you‚Äôd like to import. This will bring up a form that
is already filled with your project‚Äôs information. Feel free to edit any of
these properties, and then click <strong>Next</strong> to
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#building-your-documentation"><span class="std std-ref">build your documentation</span></a>.</p>
<figure class="align-right" id="id1" style="width: 300px">
<img alt="_images/import-a-repository.png" src="_images/import-a-repository.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Importing a repository</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</section>
<section id="manually-import-your-docs">
<h3>Manually import your docs<a class="headerlink" href="#manually-import-your-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you have not <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/connecting-git-account"><span class="doc">connected a Git provider account</span></a>,
you will need to select <strong>Import Manually</strong>
and enter the information for your repository yourself. You will also need to
manually configure the webhook for your repository as well. When importing your
project, you will be asked for the repository URL, along with some other
information for your new project. The URL is normally the URL or path name you‚Äôd
use to checkout, clone, or branch your repository. Some examples:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Git: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://github.com/ericholscher/django-kong.git</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Mercurial: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://bitbucket.org/ianb/pip</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Subversion: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">http://varnish-cache.org/svn/trunk</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Bazaar: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">lp:pasta</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>Add an optional homepage URL and some tags, and then click <strong>Next</strong>.</p>
<p>Once your project is created, you‚Äôll need to manually configure the repository
webhook if you would like to have new changes trigger builds for your
project on Read the Docs. Go to your project‚Äôs <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span> page to
configure a new webhook.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/git-integrations"><span class="doc">How to manually connect your Git repository</span></a></dt><dd><p>Once you have imported your git project, use this guide to manually set up basic and additional <em>webhook</em> integration.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Admin</span></code> page can be found at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/&lt;project-slug&gt;/edit/</span></code>.
You can access all of the project settings from the admin page sidebar.</p>
<figure class="align-default" style="width: 400px">
<img alt="_images/admin-panel.png" src="_images/admin-panel.png" />
</figure>
</div>
</section>
<section id="building-your-documentation">
<h3>Building your documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#building-your-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Within a few seconds of completing the import process,
your code will automatically be fetched from your repository,
and the documentation will be built.
Check out our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">Build process overview</span></a> page to learn more about how Read the Docs builds your docs,
and to troubleshoot any issues that arise.</p>
<p>Some documentation projects require additional configuration to build
such as specifying a certain version of Python or installing additional dependencies.
You can configure these settings in a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> file.
See our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/index"><span class="doc">Configuration file</span></a> docs for more details.</p>
<p>It is also important to note that the default version of Sphinx is <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">v1.8.5</span></code>.
We recommend to set the version your project uses <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">explicitily with pinned dependencies</span></a>.</p>
<p>Read the Docs will host multiple versions of your code. You can read more about
how to use this well on our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">Versioned documentation</span></a> page.</p>
<p>If you have any more trouble, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to us.
The <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-support"><span class="doc">Site support</span></a> page has more information on getting in touch.</p>
</section>
</section>

<section id="contributing-an-example-project">
<h3>Contributing an example project<a class="headerlink" href="#contributing-an-example-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>We would love to add more examples that showcase features of Read the Docs or great tools or methods to build documentation projects.</p>
<p>We <strong>require</strong> that an example project:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>is <strong>hosted and maintained by you</strong> in its own Git repository, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-&lt;topic&gt;</span></code>.</p></li>
<li><p>contains a README.</p></li>
<li><p>uses a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> configuration.</p></li>
<li><p>is added to the above list by <strong>opening a PR</strong> targeting <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/blob/main/docs/user/examples.rst">examples.rst</a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We <strong>recommend</strong> that your project:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>has <strong>continuous integration and PR builds</strong>.</p></li>
<li><p>is <strong>versioned</strong> as a real software project, i.e. using git tags.</p></li>
<li><p>covers your most important scenarios, but references external real-life projects whenever possible.</p></li>
<li><p>has a minimal tech stack ‚Äì or whatever you feel comfortable about maintaining.</p></li>
<li><p>copies from an existing example project as a template to get started.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We‚Äôre excited to see what you come up with!</p>
</section>

<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-choosing-a-site"></span><section id="choosing-between-our-two-platforms">
<h2>Choosing between our two platforms<a class="headerlink" href="#choosing-between-our-two-platforms" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>Users often ask what the differences are between Read the Docs Community and Read the Docs for Business.</p>
<p>While many of our features are available on both of these platforms, there
are some key differences between our two platforms.</p>
<section id="read-the-docs-community">
<h3>Read the Docs Community<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-community" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs Community is exclusively for hosting open source documentation. We support
open source communities by providing free documentation building and hosting
services, for projects of all sizes.</p>
<p>Important points:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Open source project hosting is always free</p></li>
<li><p>All documentation sites include advertising</p></li>
<li><p>Only supports public VCS repositories</p></li>
<li><p>All documentation is publicly accessible to the world</p></li>
<li><p>Less build time and fewer build resources (memory &amp; CPU)</p></li>
<li><p>Email support included only for issues with our platform</p></li>
<li><p>Documentation is organized by projects</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You can sign up for an account at <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org">https://readthedocs.org</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="read-the-docs-for-business">
<h3>Read the Docs for Business<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-for-business" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs for Business is meant for companies and users who have more complex requirements
for their documentation project. This can include commercial projects with
private source code, projects that can only be viewed with authentication, and
even large scale projects that are publicly available.</p>
<p>Important points:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Hosting plans require a paid subscription plan</p></li>
<li><p>There is no advertising on documentation sites</p></li>
<li><p>Allows importing private and public repositories from VCS</p></li>
<li><p>Supports private versions that require authentication to view</p></li>
<li><p>Supports team authentication, including SSO with Google, GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket</p></li>
<li><p>More build time and more build resources (memory &amp; CPU)</p></li>
<li><p>Includes 24x5 email support, with 24x7 SLA support available</p></li>
<li><p>Documentation is organized by organization, giving more control over permissions</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You can sign up for an account at <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com">https://readthedocs.com</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="questions">
<h3>Questions?<a class="headerlink" href="#questions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you have a question about which platform would be best,
email us at <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>org</a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-integrations"></span><section id="continuous-documentation-deployment">
<h2>Continuous Documentation Deployment<a class="headerlink" href="#continuous-documentation-deployment" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>Read the Docs is a <em>Continuous Documentation Deployment</em> platform for your software project.
Every time you change something in your documentation, Read the Docs will detect your change and build your documentation.</p>
<p>The Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) features are configured with your repository provider,
such as GitHub, Bitbucket or GitLab.
With each change committed to your repository, we are notified by the configured <em>webhook</em>.</p>
<p>When a receive a <em>webhook</em> notification, we match it to a project‚Äôs <em>Integration</em>.
When a webhook is received, the matching project will then:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">Build</span></a> the latest commit.</p></li>
<li><p>Synchronize your versions based on the latest tag and branch data in Git.</p></li>
<li><p>Run your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">automation rules</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Auto-cancel any currently running builds of the same version.</p></li>
<li><p>Add a log entry to the integration‚Äôs <span class="guilabel">Recent Activity</span>.</p></li>
</ul>
<section id="continuous-documentation-for-software-projects">
<h3>Continuous Documentation for software projects<a class="headerlink" href="#continuous-documentation-for-software-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Documentation fits into any CI/CD pipeline by following a process known as <em>Documentation as Code (Docs as code)</em>.
The primary method of doing this is by maintaining documentation alongside the source code,
meaning that the documentation‚Äôs life cycle is the same as your software project.
By managing these changes in the same life cycle,
you can benefit from <strong>documentation and source code being part of the same code review process</strong>.</p>
<p>Having an automated and short feedback loop for your documentation allows you to
keep it updated with minimal effort.
This allows more iteration on documentation,
and increases overall value from the documentation you write.</p>
<p>As part of this quick feedback loop,
You can preview documentation changes immediately using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">pull request previews</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="automated-versioning">
<h3>Automated versioning<a class="headerlink" href="#automated-versioning" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>With Read the Docs‚Äô automated CI/CD pipeline, you will be able to fully align your project‚Äôs <strong>release cycle</strong> with your documentation.
For instance, a new version of a software project can build and publish a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">new documentation version</span></a>.</p>
<p>When you release a new version for your project,
you are likely also adding a version tag to your Git repository.
These Git events can be configured to build and publish your documentation automatically with <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">Automation rules</span></a>.
If you use a versioning schema, you can configure it as part of the automation process.</p>
<p>Whether you choose to handle versioning automatically or with manual control is up to you.</p>
<p>Read the Docs will store your version history and make it possible for users to visit archived versions of your documentation.
Your version setup is ultimately captured by the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/git-integrations"><span class="doc">How to manually connect your Git repository</span></a></dt><dd><p>Information on setting up your Git repository to make Read the Docs automatically build your documentation project.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">Automation rules</span></a></dt><dd><p>Information on setting up your Git repository to make Read the Docs automatically build your documentation project.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-flyout-menu"><span class="doc">Flyout menu</span></a></dt><dd><p>Discover the functionality of the Flyout menu and the ways that it can be customized.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-downloadable-documentation"></span><section id="understanding-offline-formats">
<h2>Understanding offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#understanding-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>This page will provide an overview of a core Read the Docs feature: building docs in multiple formats.</p>
<p>Read the Docs supports the following formats by default:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>PDF</p></li>
<li><p>ePub</p></li>
<li><p>Zipped HTML</p></li>
</ul>
<p>This means that every commit that you push will automatically update your offline formats as well as your documentation website.</p>
<section id="use-cases">
<h3>Use cases<a class="headerlink" href="#use-cases" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This functionality is great for anyone who needs documentation when they aren‚Äôt connected to the internet.
Users who are about to get on a plane can grab a single file and have the entire documentation during their trip.
Many academic and scientific projects benefit from these additional formats.</p>
<p>PDF versions are also helpful to automatically <strong>create printable versions of your documentation</strong>.
The source of your documentation will be structured to support both online and offline formats.
This means that a documentation project displayed as a website can be downloaded as a PDF,
ready to be printed as a report or a book.</p>
<p>Offline formats also support having the entire documentation in a single file.
Your entire documentation can now be delivered as an email attachment,
uploaded to an eReader,
or accessed and searched locally without online latency.
This makes your documentation project <strong>easy to redistribute or archive</strong>.</p>
</section>
<section id="accessing-offline-formats">
<h3>Accessing offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#accessing-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
