<p>You can download offline formats in the <span class="guilabel">Project dashboard</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Downloads</span>:</p>
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/offline-formats.jpg"><img alt="_images/offline-formats.jpg" src="_images/offline-formats.jpg" style="width: 75%;" /></a>
<p>When you are browsing a documentation project,
they can also be accessed directly from the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-flyout-menu"><span class="doc">Flyout menu</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="examples">
<h3>Examples<a class="headerlink" href="#examples" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you want to see an example,
you can download the Read the Docs documentation in the following formats:</p>
<blockquote>
<div><ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/_/downloads/en/latest/pdf/">PDF</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/_/downloads/en/latest/epub/">ePub</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/_/downloads/en/latest/htmlzip/">Zipped HTML</a></p></li>
</ul>
</div></blockquote>
</section>
<section id="continue-learning">
<h3>Continue learning<a class="headerlink" href="#continue-learning" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Downloadable documentation formats are built by your documentation framework.
They are then published by Read the Docs and included in your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">Flyout menu</span></a>.
Therefore, it‚Äôs your framework that decides exactly how each output is built and which formats are supported:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Sphinx</dt><dd><p>All output formats are built mostly lossless from the documentation source,
meaning that your documentation source (reStructuredText or Markdown/MyST) is built from scratch for each output format.</p>
</dd>
<dt>MkDocs and Docsify + more</dt><dd><p>The common case for most documentation frameworks is that several alternative extensions exist supporting various output formats.
Most of the extensions export the HTML outputs as another format (for instance PDF) through a conversion process.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Because Sphinx supports the generation of offline formats through an official process,
we are also able to support it officially.
Other alternatives can also work,
provided that you identify which extension you want to use and configure the environment for it to run.
<strong>Other formats aren‚Äôt natively supported by Read the Docs,
but support is coming soon.</strong></p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>Other pages in our documentation are relevant to this feature,
and might be a useful next step.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/enable-offline-formats"><span class="doc">How to enable offline formats</span></a> - Guide to enabling and disabling this feature.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#formats"><span class="std std-ref">formats</span></a> - Configuration file options for offline formats.</p></li>
</ul>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-environment-variables"></span><section id="understanding-environment-variables">
<span id="environment-variables"></span><h2>Understanding environment variables<a class="headerlink" href="#understanding-environment-variables" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>Read the Docs allows you to define your own environment variables to be used in the build process.
It also defines a set of <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/environment-variables"><span class="doc">default environment variables</span></a> with information about your build.
These are useful for different purposes:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Custom environment variables are useful for adding build secrets such as API tokens.</p></li>
<li><p>Default environment variables are useful for varying your build specifically for Read the Docs or specific types of builds on Read the Docs.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Custom environment variables are defined in the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-dashboard"><span class="xref std std-term">dashboard</span></a> interface in <span class="menuselection">Admin ‚Ä£ Environment variables</span>.
Environment variables are defined for a project‚Äôs entire build process,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#custom-env-var-exceptions"><span class="std std-ref">with 2 important exceptions</span></a>.</p>
<p>Aside from storing secrets,
there are <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#patterns-of-using-environment-variables"><span class="std std-ref">other patterns</span></a> that take advantage of environment variables,
like reusing the same <em>monorepo</em> configuration in multiple documentation projects.
In cases where the environment variable isn‚Äôt a secret,
like a build tool flag,
you should also be aware of the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#alternatives-to-environment-variables"><span class="std std-ref">alternatives to environment variables</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/environment-variables"><span class="doc">How to use custom environment variables</span></a></dt><dd><p>A practical example of adding and accessing custom environment variables.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/environment-variables"><span class="doc">Environment variables</span></a></dt><dd><p>Reference to all pre-defined environment variables for your build environments.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#environment-variables"><span class="std std-ref">Public API reference: Environment variables</span></a></dt><dd><p>Reference for managing custom environments via Read the Docs‚Äô API.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="environment-variables-and-build-process">
<h3>Environment variables and build process<a class="headerlink" href="#environment-variables-and-build-process" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>When a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">build process</span></a> is started,
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/environment-variables"><span class="doc">pre-defined environment variables</span></a> and custom environment variables are added <em>at each step</em> of the build process.
The two sets of environment variables are merged together during the build process and are exposed to all of the executed commands,
with pre-defined variables taking precedence over custom environment variables.</p>
<p id="custom-env-var-exceptions">There are two noteworthy exceptions for <em>custom environment variables</em>:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Build checkout step</dt><dd><p>Custom environment variables are <strong>not</strong> available during the checkout step of the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">build process</span></a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Pull Request builds</dt><dd><p>Custom environment variables that are not marked as <span class="guilabel">Public</span> will not be available in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">pull request builds</span></a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
</section>
<section id="patterns-of-using-environment-variables">
<h3>Patterns of using environment variables<a class="headerlink" href="#patterns-of-using-environment-variables" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Aside from storing secrets,
environment variables are also useful if you need to make either your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/v2"><span class="doc">.readthedocs.yaml</span></a> or the commands called in the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">build process</span></a>
behave depending on <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/environment-variables"><span class="doc">pre-defined environment variables</span></a> or your own custom environment variables.</p>
<section id="example-multiple-projects-from-the-same-git-repo">
<h4>Example: Multiple projects from the same Git repo<a class="headerlink" href="#example-multiple-projects-from-the-same-git-repo" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you have the need to build multiple documentation websites from the same Git repository,
you can use an environment variable to configure the behavior of your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-build-customization"><span class="doc">build commands</span></a>
or Sphinx <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file.</p>
<p>An example of this is found in <em>the documentation project that you are looking at now</em>.
Using the Sphinx extension <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-multiproject.readthedocs.io/">sphinx-multiproject</a>,
the following configuration code decides whether to build the <em>user</em> or <em>developer</em> documentation.
This is defined by the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">PROJECT</span></code> environment variable:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id3">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">Read the Docs‚Äô conf.py <a class="footnote-reference brackets" href="#id2" id="id1" role="doc-noteref"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span>1<span class="fn-bracket">]</span></a> is used to build 2 documentation projects.</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id3" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">multiproject.utils</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">get_project</span>

<span class="c1"># (...)</span>

<span class="n">multiproject_projects</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;user&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;use_config_file&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;config&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
            <span class="s2">&quot;project&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;Read the Docs user documentation&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="p">},</span>
    <span class="p">},</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;dev&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;use_config_file&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;config&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
            <span class="s2">&quot;project&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;Read the Docs developer documentation&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="p">},</span>
    <span class="p">},</span>
<span class="p">}</span>


<span class="n">docset</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">get_project</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">multiproject_projects</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<aside class="footnote-list brackets">
<aside class="footnote brackets" id="id2" role="note">
<span class="label"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span><a role="doc-backlink" href="#id1">1</a><span class="fn-bracket">]</span></span>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/blob/main/docs/conf.py">https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/blob/main/docs/conf.py</a></p>
</aside>
</aside>
</section>
</section>
<section id="alternatives-to-environment-variables">
<h3>Alternatives to environment variables<a class="headerlink" href="#alternatives-to-environment-variables" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In some scenarios, it‚Äôs more feasible to define your build‚Äôs environment variables using the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/index"><span class="doc">configuration file</span></a>.
Using the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-dashboard"><span class="xref std std-term">dashboard</span></a> for administering environment variables may not be the right fit if you already know that you want to manage environment variables <em>as code</em>.</p>
<p>Consider the following scenario:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>The environment variable <strong>is not</strong> a secret.</p>
<p><strong>and</strong></p>
</li>
<li><p>The environment variable is used just once for a custom command.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>In this case, you can define the environment variable <em>as code</em> using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-build-customization"><span class="doc">Build process customization</span></a>.
The following example shows how a non-secret single-purpose environment variable can also be used.</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id4">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">.readthedocs.yaml</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id4" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nt">version</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">2</span>
<span class="nt">build</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">os</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;ubuntu-22.04&quot;</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">tools</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="nt">python</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s">&quot;3.11&quot;</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nt">jobs</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="nt">post_build</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">      </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">EXAMPLE_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE=foobar command --flag</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-subprojects"></span><section id="subprojects-host-multiple-projects-on-a-single-domain">
<h2>Subprojects: host multiple projects on a single domain<a class="headerlink" href="#subprojects-host-multiple-projects-on-a-single-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>In this article, you can learn more about how several documentation projects can be combined and presented to the reader on the same website.</p>
<p>Read the Docs can be configured to make other <em>projects</em> available on the website of the <em>main project</em> as <strong>subprojects</strong>.
This allows for documentation projects to share a search index and a namespace or custom domain,
but still be maintained independently.</p>
<p>This is useful for:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Organizations that need all their projects visible in one documentation portal or landing page</p></li>
<li><p>Projects that document and release several packages or extensions</p></li>
<li><p>Organizations or projects that want to have a common search function for several sets of documentation</p></li>
</ul>
<p>For a main project <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project</span></code>, a subproject <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project-plugin</span></code> can be made available as follows:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Main project: <a class="reference external" href="https://example-project.readthedocs.io/en/latest/">https://example-project.readthedocs.io/en/latest/</a></p></li>
<li><p>Subproject: <a class="reference external" href="https://example-project.readthedocs.io/projects/plugin/en/latest/">https://example-project.readthedocs.io/projects/plugin/en/latest/</a></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/subprojects"><span class="doc">How to manage subprojects</span></a></dt><dd><p>Learn how to create and manage subprojects</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">How to link to other documentation projects with Intersphinx</span></a></dt><dd><p>Learn how to use references between different Sphinx projects, for instance between subprojects</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="sharing-a-custom-domain">
<h3>Sharing a custom domain<a class="headerlink" href="#sharing-a-custom-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Projects and subprojects can be used to share a custom domain.
To configure this, one project should be established as the main project and configured with a custom domain.
Other projects are then added as subprojects to the main project.</p>
<p>If the example project <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project</span></code> was set up with a custom domain,
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code>, the URLs for projects <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project-plugin</span></code> with alias <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">plugin</span></code> would
respectively be at:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project</span></code>: <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.example.com/en/latest/">https://docs.example.com/en/latest/</a></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project-plugin</span></code>: <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.example.com/projects/plugin/en/latest/">https://docs.example.com/projects/plugin/en/latest/</a></p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="using-aliases">
<h3>Using aliases<a class="headerlink" href="#using-aliases" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Adding an alias for the subproject allows you to override the URL that is used to access it,
giving more control over how you want to structure your projects.
You can choose an alias for the subproject when it is created.</p>
<p>You can set your subproject‚Äôs project name and <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-slug"><span class="xref std std-term">slug</span></a> however you want,
but we suggest prefixing it with the name of the main project.</p>
<p>Typically, a subproject is created with a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;mainproject&gt;-</span></code> prefix,
for instance if the main project is called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project</span></code> and the subproject is called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">plugin</span></code>,
then the subproject‚Äôs Read the Docs project <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-slug"><span class="xref std std-term">slug</span></a> will be <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project-plugin</span></code>.
When adding the subproject,
the alias is set to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">plugin</span></code> and the project‚Äôs URL becomes
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project.readthedocs.io/projects/plugin</span></code>.</p>
<p>When you add a subproject,
the subproject will not be directly available anymore from its own domain.
For instance, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project-plugin.readthedocs.io/</span></code> will redirect to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example-project.readthedocs.io/projects/plugin</span></code>.</p>
</section>
<section id="custom-domain-on-subprojects">
<h3>Custom domain on subprojects<a class="headerlink" href="#custom-domain-on-subprojects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Adding a custom domain to a subproject is not allowed,
since your documentation will always be served from
the domain of the parent project.</p>
</section>
<section id="separate-release-cycles">
<h3>Separate release cycles<a class="headerlink" href="#separate-release-cycles" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>By using subprojects,
you can present the documentation of several projects
even though they have separate release cycles.</p>
<p>Your main project may have its own versions and releases,
while all of its subprojects maintain their own individual versions and releases.
We recommend that documentation follows the release cycle of whatever it is documenting,
meaning that your subprojects should be free to follow their own release cycle.</p>
<p>This is solved by having an individual <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a> active for the project that‚Äôs viewed.
When the user navigates to a subproject,
they are presented with a flyout menu matching the subproject‚Äôs versions and <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-downloadable-documentation"><span class="doc">Understanding offline formats</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="search">
<h3>Search<a class="headerlink" href="#search" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Search on the parent project will include results from its subprojects.
If you search on the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">v1</span></code> version of the parent project,
results from the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">v1</span></code> version of its subprojects will be included,
or from the default version for subprojects that don‚Äôt have a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">v1</span></code> version.</p>
<p>This is currently the only way to share search results between projects,
we do not yet support sharing search results between sibling subprojects or arbitrary projects.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-localization"></span><section id="localization-of-documentation">
<h2>Localization of documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#localization-of-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>In this article, we explain high-level approaches to internationalizing and localizing your documentation.</p>
<p>By default, Read the Docs assumes that your documentation is or <em>might become</em> multilingual one day.
The initial default language is English and
therefore you often see the initial build of your documentation published at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/</span></code>,
where the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en</span></code> denotes that it‚Äôs in English.
By having the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">en</span></code> URL component present from the beginning,
you are ready for the eventuality that you would want a second language.</p>
<p>Read the Docs supports hosting your documentation in multiple languages.
Read below for the various approaches that we support.</p>
<nav class="contents local" id="contents">
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#projects-with-one-language" id="id1">Projects with one language</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#projects-with-multiple-translations-sphinx-only" id="id2">Projects with multiple translations (Sphinx-only)</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#translation-workflows" id="id3">Translation workflows</a></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</nav>
<section id="projects-with-one-language">
<h3><a class="toc-backref" href="#id1" role="doc-backlink">Projects with one language</a><a class="headerlink" href="#projects-with-one-language" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If your documentation isn‚Äôt in English (the default),
you should indicate which language you have written it in.</p>
<p>It is easy to set the <em>Language</em> of your project.
On the project <em>Admin</em> page (or <em>Import</em> page),
simply select your desired <em>Language</em> from the dropdown.
This will tell Read the Docs that your project is in the language.
The language will be represented in the URL for your project.</p>
<p>For example,
a project that is in Spanish will have a default URL of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/es/latest/</span></code> instead of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/</span></code>.</p>
</section>
<section id="projects-with-multiple-translations-sphinx-only">
<h3><a class="toc-backref" href="#id2" role="doc-backlink">Projects with multiple translations (Sphinx-only)</a><a class="headerlink" href="#projects-with-multiple-translations-sphinx-only" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-translations-sphinx"><span class="doc">How to manage translations for Sphinx projects</span></a></dt><dd><p>Describes the whole process for a documentation with multiples languages in the same repository and how to keep the translations updated on time.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<p>This situation is a bit more complicated.
To support this,
you will have one parent project and a number of projects marked as translations of that parent.
Let‚Äôs use <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin</span></code> as an example.</p>
<p>The main <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin</span></code> project is the parent for all translations.
Then you must create a project for each translation,
for example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin-spanish</span></code>.
You will set the <em>Language</em> for <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin-spanish</span></code> to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Spanish</span></code>.
In the parent projects <em>Translations</em> page,
you will say that <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin-spanish</span></code> is a translation for your project.</p>
<p>This has the results of serving:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin</span></code> at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">http://phpmyadmin.readthedocs.io/en/latest/</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">phpmyadmin-spanish</span></code> at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">http://phpmyadmin.readthedocs.io/es/latest/</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>It also gets included in the Read the Docs <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a>:</p>
<img alt="_images/translation_bar.png" src="_images/translation_bar.png" />
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The default language of a custom domain is determined by the language of the
parent project that the domain was configured on. See
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-custom-domains"><span class="doc">Custom domains</span></a> for more information.</p>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You can include multiple translations in the same repository,
with same <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> files,
but each project must specify the language to build for those docs.</p>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You must commit the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> files for Read the Docs to translate your documentation.</p>
</div>
<section id="translation-workflows">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id3" role="doc-backlink">Translation workflows</a><a class="headerlink" href="#translation-workflows" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When you work with translations,
the workflow of your translators becomes a critical component.</p>
<p>Considerations include:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Are your translators able to use a git workflow? For instance, are they able to translate directly via GitHub?</p></li>
<li><p>Do you benefit from machine translation?</p></li>
<li><p>Do you need different roles, for instance do you need translators and editors?</p></li>
<li><p>What is your source language?</p></li>
<li><p>When are your translated versions published?</p></li>
</ul>
<p>By using Sphinx and .po files,
you will be able to automatically synchronize between your documentation source messages on your git platform and your translation platform.</p>
<p>There are many translation platforms that support this workflow.
These include:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://weblate.org/">Weblate</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.transifex.com/">Transifex</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://crowdin.com/">Crowdin</a></p></li>
</ul>
<p>Because Read the Docs builds your git repository,
you can use any of the above solutions.
Any solution that synchronizes your translations with your git repository
will ensure that your translations are automatically published with Read the Docs.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
</div>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/setup/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-project-setup-and-configuration">
<h2>How-to guides: project setup and configuration<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-project-setup-and-configuration" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>The following how-to guides help you solve common tasks and challenges in the setup and configuration stages.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/connecting-git-account"><span class="doc">Connecting your Read the Docs account to your Git provider</span></a></dt><dd><p>Steps to connect an account on GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab with your Read the Docs account.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-connected-accounts"><span class="doc">Connecting your Git repository automatically</span></a></dt><dd><p>Once your account is connected to your Git provider,
adding and configuring a Git repository <strong>automatically</strong> is possible for GitHub, Bitbucket, and GitLab.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/git-integrations"><span class="doc">Connecting your Git repository manually</span></a></dt><dd><p>If you are connecting a Git repository from another provider (for instance Gitea or Codeberg),
this guide tells you how to add and configure the Webhook <strong>manually</strong>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">Managing custom domains</span></a></dt><dd><p>Hosting your documentation using your own domain name, such as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/redirects"><span class="doc">Using custom URL redirects in documentation projects</span></a></dt><dd><p>Configuring your Read the Docs project for redirecting visitors from one location to another.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/subprojects"><span class="doc">Managing subprojects</span></a></dt><dd><p>Need several projects under the same umbrella?
Start using subprojects, which is a way to host multiple projects under a ‚Äúmain project‚Äù.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/setup/monorepo"><span class="doc">Using a .readthedocs.yaml file in a sub-folder</span></a></dt><dd><p>This guide shows how to configure a Read the Docs project to use a custom path for the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> build configuration.
<em>Monorepos</em> that have multiple documentation projects in the same Git repository can benefit from this feature.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/hiding-a-version"><span class="doc">Hiding a version</span></a></dt><dd><p>Is your version (flyout) menu overwhelmed and hard to navigate?
Here‚Äôs how to make it shorter.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-tutorial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs tutorial</span></a></dt><dd><p>All you need to know to get started.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/connecting-git-account"></span><section id="how-to-connect-your-read-the-docs-account-to-your-git-provider">
<h3>How to connect your Read the Docs account to your Git provider<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-connect-your-read-the-docs-account-to-your-git-provider" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this how to article,
you are shown the steps to connect an account on GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab with your Read the Docs account.
This is relevant if you have signed up for Read the Docs with your email
or if you have signed up using a Git provider account and want to connect additional providers.</p>
<p>If you are going to import repositories from GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab,
you should connect your Read the Docs account to your Git provider first.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If you signed up or logged in to Read the Docs with your GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab credentials,
you‚Äôre all done. Your account is connected ‚úÖÔ∏è.
You only need this how-to if you want to connect additional Git providers.</p>
</div>
<section id="adding-a-connection">
<h4>Adding a connection<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-a-connection" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To connect your Read the Docs account with a Git provider,
go to the main login menu: <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Connected Services</span>.</p>
<p>From here, you‚Äôll be able to connect to your GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab
account. This process will ask you to authorize an integration with Read the Docs.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id3">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/oauth_github_dialog.png"><img alt="Screenshot of example OAuth dialog on GitHub" src="_images/oauth_github_dialog.png" style="width: 300px;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">An example of how your OAuth dialog on GitHub may look.</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id3" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>After approving the request,
you will be taken back to Read the Docs.
You will now see the account appear in the list of connected services.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id4">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/screenshot_connected_services.png"><img alt="Screenshot of Read the Docs &quot;Connected Services&quot; page with multiple services connected" src="_images/screenshot_connected_services.png" style="width: 600px;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Connected Services <a class="footnote-reference brackets" href="#f1" id="id1" role="doc-noteref"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span>1<span class="fn-bracket">]</span></a> <a class="footnote-reference brackets" href="#f2" id="id2" role="doc-noteref"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span>2<span class="fn-bracket">]</span></a> shows the list of Git providers that</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id4" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Now your connection is ready and you will be able to import and configure Git repositories with just a few clicks.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-connected-accounts"><span class="doc">How to connect your Git repository</span></a></dt><dd><p>Learn about what a connected account with your Git provider is used for
and the permissions required for connecting accounts.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<section id="removing-a-connection">
<h4>Removing a connection<a class="headerlink" href="#removing-a-connection" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You may at any time delete the connection from Read the Docs.
Delete the connection makes Read the Docs forget the immediate access,
but you should also disable our OAuth Application from your Git provider.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>On GitHub, navigate to <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/settings/applications">Authorized OAuth Apps</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>On Bitbucket, navigate to <a class="reference external" href="https://bitbucket.org/account/settings/app-authorizations/">Application Authorizations</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>On GitLab, navigat to <a class="reference external" href="https://gitlab.com/-/profile/applications">Applications</a></p></li>
</ul>
<aside class="footnote-list brackets">
<aside class="footnote brackets" id="f1" role="note">
<span class="label"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span><a role="doc-backlink" href="#id1">1</a><span class="fn-bracket">]</span></span>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/social/connections/">Connected Services on readthedocs.org</a></p>
</aside>
<aside class="footnote brackets" id="f2" role="note">
<span class="label"><span class="fn-bracket">[</span><a role="doc-backlink" href="#id2">2</a><span class="fn-bracket">]</span></span>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/accounts/social/connections/">Connected Services on readthedocs.com</a></p>
</aside>
</aside>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-connected-accounts"></span><section id="how-to-connect-your-git-repository">
<h3>How to connect your Git repository<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-connect-your-git-repository" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this article, we explain how connecting your Read the Docs account to GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab
automatically configures your Git repository and your Read the Docs project.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚úÖÔ∏è Signed up with your Git provider?</dt><dd><p>If you signed up or logged in to Read the Docs with your GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab
credentials, you‚Äôre all done. Your account is connected.
The permissions that are granted are <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#permissions-for-connected-accounts"><span class="std std-ref">explained below</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚¨áÔ∏è Signed up with your email address?</dt><dd><p>If you have signed up to Read the Docs with your email address,
you can add the connection to the Git provider afterwards.
See: <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/connecting-git-account"><span class="doc">How to connect your Read the Docs account to your Git provider</span></a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>If you are going to import repositories from GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab,
we recommend that you connect your Read the Docs account to your Git provider.</p>
<p>Connecting your account allows for:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Easy import of your repositories.</p></li>
<li><p>Automatic configuration of your repository <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-integrations"><span class="doc">Continuous Documentation Deployment</span></a>.
which allow Read the Docs to build your docs on every change to your repository</p></li>
<li><p>Logging into Read the Docs with your GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab credentials.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#manually-import-your-docs"><span class="std std-ref">Manually import your docs</span></a></dt><dd><p>Using a different provider?
Read the Docs still supports other providers such as Gitea or GitHub Enterprise.
In fact, any Git repository URL can be configured manually.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>A single Read the Docs account can connect to many different Git providers.
This allows you to have a single login for all your various identities.</p>
</div>
<section id="how-does-the-connection-work">
<h4>How does the connection work?<a class="headerlink" href="#how-does-the-connection-work" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs uses <a class="reference external" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OAuth">OAuth</a> to connect to your account at GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab,
You are asked to grant permissions for Read the Docs to perform a number of actions on your behalf.</p>
<p>At the same time, we use this process for authentication (login)
since we trust that GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab have verified your user account and email address.</p>
<p>By granting Read the Docs the requested permissions,
we are issued a secret OAuth token from your Git provider.</p>
<p>Using the secret token,
we can automatically configure the repository that you select in the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/import-guide"><span class="doc">project import</span></a>.
We also use the token to send back build statuses and preview URLs for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">pull requests</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Access granted to Read the Docs can always be revoked.
This is a function offered by all Git providers.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="permissions-for-connected-accounts">
<h4>Permissions for connected accounts<a class="headerlink" href="#permissions-for-connected-accounts" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs does not generally ask for <em>write</em> permission to your repository code
(with one exception detailed below)
and since we only connect to public repositories we don‚Äôt need special permissions to read them.
However, we do need permissions for authorizing your account
so that you can login to Read the Docs with your connected account credentials
and to setup <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-integrations"><span class="doc">Continuous Documentation Deployment</span></a>
which allow us to build your documentation on every change to your repository.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">GitHub</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">Bitbucket</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-2" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-2" name="0-2" role="tab" tabindex="-1">GitLab</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>Read the Docs requests the following permissions (more precisely, <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.github.com/apps/building-oauth-apps/understanding-scopes-for-oauth-apps/">OAuth scopes</a>)
when connecting your Read the Docs account to GitHub.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Read access to your email address (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">user:email</span></code>)</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so you can create a Read the Docs account and login with your GitHub credentials.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Administering webhooks (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">admin:repo_hook</span></code>)</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so we can create <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a> on your repositories when you import them into Read the Docs.
This allows us to build the docs when you push new commits.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Read access to your organizations (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">read:org</span></code>)</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so we know which organizations you have access to.
This allows you to filter repositories by organization when importing repositories.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Repository status (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">repo:status</span></code>)</dt><dd><p>Repository statuses allow Read the Docs to report the status
(eg. passed, failed, pending) of pull requests to GitHub.
This is used for a feature currently in beta testing
that builds documentation on each pull request similar to a continuous integration service.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs for Business</span></a>
asks for one additional permission (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">repo</span></code>) to allow access to private repositories
and to allow us to setup SSH keys to clone your private repositories.
Unfortunately, this is the permission for read/write control of the repository
but there isn‚Äôt a more granular permission
that only allows setting up SSH keys for read access.</p>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>We request permissions for:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Administering your repositories (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">repository:admin</span></code>)</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so we can create <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a> on your repositories when you import them into Read the Docs.
This allows us to build the docs when you push new commits.
NB! This permission scope does <strong>not</strong> include any write access to code.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Reading your account information including your email address</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so you can create a Read the Docs account and login with your Bitbucket credentials.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Read access to your team memberships</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so we know which organizations you have access to.
This allows you to filter repositories by organization when importing repositories.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Read access to your repositories</dt><dd><p>We ask for this so we know which repositories you have access to.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>To read more about Bitbucket permissions, see <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/bitbucket/bitbucket-cloud-rest-api-scopes/">official Bitbucket documentation on API scopes</a></p>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-2" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-2" name="0-2" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>Like the others, we request permissions for:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Reading your account information (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">read_user</span></code>)</p></li>
<li><p>API access (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">api</span></code>) which is needed to create webhooks in GitLab</p></li>
</ul>
</div></div>
<section id="github-permission-troubleshooting">
<span id="id1"></span><h5>GitHub permission troubleshooting<a class="headerlink" href="#github-permission-troubleshooting" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p><strong>Repositories not in your list to import</strong>.</p>
<p>Many organizations require approval for each OAuth application that is used,
or you might have disabled it in the past for your personal account.
This can happen at the personal or organization level,
depending on where the project you are trying to access has permissions from.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">Personal Account</button><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">Organization Account</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>You need to make sure that you have granted access to the Read the Docs <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/settings/applications">OAuth App</a> to your <strong>personal GitHub account</strong>.
If you do not see Read the Docs in the <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/settings/applications">OAuth App</a> settings, you might need to disconnect and reconnect the GitHub service.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>GitHub docs on <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/restricting-access-to-your-organizations-data/approving-oauth-apps-for-your-organization">requesting access to your personal OAuth</a> for step-by-step instructions.</p>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>You need to make sure that you have granted access to the Read the Docs OAuth App to your <strong>organization GitHub account</strong>.
If you don‚Äôt see ‚ÄúRead the Docs‚Äù listed, then you might need to connect GitHub to your social accounts as noted above.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>GitHub doc on <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-your-github-user-account/managing-your-membership-in-organizations/requesting-organization-approval-for-oauth-apps">requesting access to your organization OAuth</a> for step-by-step instructions.</p>
</div>
</div></div>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/git-integrations"></span><section id="how-to-manually-connect-your-git-repository">
<h3>How to manually connect your Git repository<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manually-connect-your-git-repository" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide,
you will find the simple steps to manually integrating your Read the Docs project with all Git providers that supports our generic API.
This includes most Git providers, for example GitHub, Bitbucket, and GitLab.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If your account is connected to the provider,
we‚Äôll try to setup the integration automatically.
If something fails, you can still setup the integration manually.</p>
</div>
<section id="provider-specific-instructions">
<span id="webhook-integration-gitlab"></span><span id="webhook-integration-bitbucket"></span><span id="webhook-integration-github"></span><h4>Provider-specific instructions<a class="headerlink" href="#provider-specific-instructions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">GitHub</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">Bitbucket</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-2" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-2" name="0-2" role="tab" tabindex="-1">GitLab</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-3" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-3" name="0-3" role="tab" tabindex="-1">Gitea</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to the <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> page for your <strong>GitHub project</strong></p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Webhooks</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Add webhook</span></p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>Payload URL</strong>, use the URL of the integration on your <strong>Read the Docs project</strong>,
found on the project‚Äôs <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span> page.
You may need to prepend <em>https://</em> to the URL.</p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>Content type</strong>, both <em>application/json</em> and
<em>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</em> work</p></li>
<li><p>Leave the <strong>Secrets</strong> field blank</p></li>
<li><p>Select <strong>Let me select individual events</strong>,
and mark <strong>Branch or tag creation</strong>, <strong>Branch or tag deletion</strong>, <strong>Pull requests</strong> and <strong>Pushes</strong> events</p></li>
<li><p>Ensure <strong>Active</strong> is enabled; it is by default</p></li>
<li><p>Finish by clicking <strong>Add webhook</strong>.  You may be prompted to enter your GitHub password to confirm your action.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You can verify if the webhook is working at the bottom of the GitHub page under <strong>Recent Deliveries</strong>.
If you see a Response 200, then the webhook is correctly configured.
For a 403 error, it‚Äôs likely that the Payload URL is incorrect.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The webhook token, intended for the GitHub <strong>Secret</strong> field, is not yet implemented.</p>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to the <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Webhooks</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Add webhook</span> page for your project</p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>URL</strong>, use the URL of the integration on Read the Docs,
found on the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span>  page</p></li>
<li><p>Under <strong>Triggers</strong>, <strong>Repository push</strong> should be selected</p></li>
<li><p>Finish by clicking <strong>Save</strong></p></li>
</ul>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-2" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-2" name="0-2" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to the <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Webhooks</span> page for your GitLab project</p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>URL</strong>, use the URL of the integration on <strong>Read the Docs project</strong>,
found on the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span>  page</p></li>
<li><p>Leave the default <strong>Push events</strong> selected,
additionally mark <strong>Tag push events</strong> and <strong>Merge request events</strong>.</p></li>
<li><p>Finish by clicking <strong>Add Webhook</strong></p></li>
</ul>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-3" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-3" name="0-3" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>These instructions apply to any Gitea instance.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>This isn‚Äôt officially supported, but using the ‚ÄúGitHub webhook‚Äù is an effective workaround,
because Gitea uses the same payload as GitHub. The generic webhook is not compatible with Gitea.
See <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/issues/8364">issue #8364</a> for more details. Official support may be implemented in the future.</p>
</div>
<p>On Read the Docs:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Manually create a ‚ÄúGitHub webhook‚Äù integration
(this will show a warning about the webhook not being correctly set up,
that will go away when the webhook is configured in Gitea)</p></li>
</ul>
<p>On your Gitea instance:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to the <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Webhooks</span> page for your project on your Gitea instance</p></li>
<li><p>Create a new webhook of type ‚ÄúGitea‚Äù</p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>URL</strong>, use the URL of the integration on Read the Docs,
found on the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span> page</p></li>
<li><p>Leave the default <strong>HTTP Method</strong> as POST</p></li>
<li><p>For <strong>Content type</strong>, both <em>application/json</em> and
<em>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</em> work</p></li>
<li><p>Leave the <strong>Secret</strong> field blank</p></li>
<li><p>Select <strong>Choose events</strong>,
and mark <strong>Branch or tag creation</strong>, <strong>Branch or tag deletion</strong> and <strong>Push</strong> events</p></li>
<li><p>Ensure <strong>Active</strong> is enabled; it is by default</p></li>
<li><p>Finish by clicking <strong>Add Webhook</strong></p></li>
<li><p>Test the webhook with <span class="guilabel">Delivery test</span></p></li>
</ul>
<p>Finally, on Read the Docs, check that the warnings have disappeared
and the delivery test triggered a build.</p>
</div></div>
</section>
<section id="additional-integration">
<h4>Additional integration<a class="headerlink" href="#additional-integration" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can configure multiple incoming <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a>.</p>
<p>To manually set up an integration, go to <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span> &gt;  <span class="guilabel">Add integration</span>
dashboard page and select the integration type you‚Äôd like to add.
After you have added the integration, you‚Äôll see a link to information about the integration.</p>
<p>As an example, the URL pattern looks like this: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://readthedocs.org/api/v2/webhook/&lt;project-name&gt;/&lt;id&gt;/*</span></code>.</p>
<p>Use this URL when setting up a new integration with your provider ^^ these steps vary depending on the provider.</p>
</section>
<section id="using-the-generic-api-integration">
<span id="webhook-integration-generic"></span><h4>Using the generic API integration<a class="headerlink" href="#using-the-generic-api-integration" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>For repositories that are not hosted with a supported provider, we also offer a
generic API endpoint for triggering project builds. Similar to webhook integrations,
this integration has a specific URL, which can be found on the project‚Äôs <strong>Integrations</strong> dashboard page
(<span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span>).</p>
<p>Token authentication is required to use the generic endpoint, you will find this
token on the integration details page. The token should be passed in as a
request parameter, either as form data or as part of JSON data input.</p>
<section id="parameters">
<h5>Parameters<a class="headerlink" href="#parameters" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>This endpoint accepts the following arguments during an HTTP POST:</p>
<dl>
<dt>branches</dt><dd><p>The names of the branches to trigger builds for. This can either be an array
of branch name strings, or just a single branch name string.</p>
<p>Default: <strong>latest</strong></p>
</dd>
<dt>token</dt><dd><p>The integration token found on the project‚Äôs <strong>Integrations</strong> dashboard page
(<span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Integrations</span>).</p>
</dd>
<dt>default_branch</dt><dd><p>This is the default branch of the repository
(ie. the one checked out when cloning the repository without arguments)</p>
<p><em>Optional</em></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>For example, the cURL command to build the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">dev</span></code> branch, using the token
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1234</span></code>, would be:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">curl</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">X</span> <span class="n">POST</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">d</span> <span class="s2">&quot;branches=dev&quot;</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">d</span> <span class="s2">&quot;token=1234&quot;</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="n">d</span> <span class="s2">&quot;default_branch=main&quot;</span>
<span class="n">https</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="o">//</span><span class="n">readthedocs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">org</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">api</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">v2</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">webhook</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">project</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>A command like the one above could be called from a cron job or from a hook
inside <a class="reference external" href="http://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/githooks.html">Git</a>, <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mikewest.org/2006/06/subversion-post-commit-hooks-101">Subversion</a>, <a class="reference external" href="http://hgbook.red-bean.com/read/handling-repository-events-with-hooks.html">Mercurial</a>, or <a class="reference external" href="http://wiki.bazaar.canonical.com/BzrHooks">Bazaar</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="authentication">
<h5>Authentication<a class="headerlink" href="#authentication" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>This endpoint requires authentication. If authenticating with an integration
token, a check will determine if the token is valid and matches the given
project. If instead an authenticated user is used to make this request, a check
will be performed to ensure the authenticated user is an owner of the project.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="payload-validation">
<h4>Payload validation<a class="headerlink" href="#payload-validation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If your project was imported through a connected account,
we create a secret for every integration that offers a way to verify that a webhook request is legitimate.
Currently, <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.github.com/webhooks/securing/">GitHub</a> and <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/webhooks.html#validate-payloads-by-using-a-secret-token">GitLab</a>
offer a way to check this.</p>
</section>
<section id="troubleshooting">
<h4>Troubleshooting<a class="headerlink" href="#troubleshooting" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="debugging-webhooks">
<h5>Debugging webhooks<a class="headerlink" href="#debugging-webhooks" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>If you are experiencing problems with an existing webhook, you may be able to
use the integration detail page to help debug the issue. Each project
integration, such as a webhook or the generic API endpoint, stores the HTTP
exchange that takes place between Read the Docs and the external source. You‚Äôll
find a list of these exchanges in any of the integration detail pages.</p>
</section>
<section id="webhook-activation-failed-make-sure-you-have-the-necessary-permissions">
<h5>Webhook activation failed. Make sure you have the necessary permissions<a class="headerlink" href="#webhook-activation-failed-make-sure-you-have-the-necessary-permissions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>If you find this error,
make sure your user has permissions over the repository.
In case of GitHub,
check that you have granted access to the Read the Docs <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/settings/applications">OAuth App</a> to your organization.</p>
</section>
<section id="my-project-isn-t-automatically-building">
<h5>My project isn‚Äôt automatically building<a class="headerlink" href="#my-project-isn-t-automatically-building" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>If your project isn‚Äôt automatically building, you can check your integration on
Read the Docs to see the payload sent to our servers. If there is no recent
activity on your Read the Docs project webhook integration, then it‚Äôs likely
that your VCS provider is not configured correctly. If there is payload
information on your Read the Docs project, you might need to verify that your
versions are configured to build correctly.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/custom-domains"></span><section id="how-to-manage-custom-domains">
<h3>How to manage custom domains<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manage-custom-domains" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This guide describes how to host your documentation using your own domain name, such as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code>.</p>
<nav class="contents local" id="contents">
<p class="topic-title">Contents</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#adding-a-custom-domain" id="id1">Adding a custom domain</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#removing-a-custom-domain" id="id2">Removing a custom domain</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#strict-transport-security-hsts-and-other-custom-headers" id="id3">Strict Transport Security (HSTS) and other custom headers</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#multiple-documentation-sites-as-sub-folders-of-a-domain" id="id4">Multiple documentation sites as sub-folders of a domain</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#troubleshooting" id="id5">Troubleshooting</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#ssl-certificate-issue-delays" id="id6">SSL certificate issue delays</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#the-validation-process-period-has-ended" id="id7">The validation process period has ended</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#migrating-from-gitbook" id="id8">Migrating from GitBook</a></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</nav>
<section id="adding-a-custom-domain">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id1" role="doc-backlink">Adding a custom domain</a><a class="headerlink" href="#adding-a-custom-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To setup your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-custom-domains"><span class="doc">custom domain</span></a>, follow these steps:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> tab of your project.</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Domains</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>Enter the domain where you want to serve the documentation from (e.g. <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code>).</p></li>
<li><p>Mark the <span class="guilabel">Canonical</span> option if you want use this domain
as your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-canonical-urls"><span class="doc">canonical domain</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>At the top of the next page you‚Äôll find the value of the DNS record that you need to point your domain to.
For Read the Docs Community this is <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">readthedocs.io</span></code>, and for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>
the record is in the form of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;hash&gt;.domains.readthedocs.com</span></code>.</p></li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Once you have completed these steps and your new DNS entry has propagated (usually takes a few minutes), you need to build your project‚Äôs published branches again so the Canonical URL is correct.</strong></p>
<blockquote>
<div><div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>For a subdomain like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code> add a CNAME record,
and for a root domain like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example.com</span></code> use an ANAME or ALIAS record.</p>
</div>
</div></blockquote>
<p>We provide a validated SSL certificate for the domain,
managed by <a class="reference external" href="https://www.cloudflare.com/">Cloudflare</a>.
The SSL certificate issuance should happen within a few minutes,
but might take up to one hour.
See <a class="reference internal" href="#ssl-certificate-issue-delays">SSL certificate issue delays</a> for more troubleshooting options.</p>
<p>To see if your DNS change has propagated, you can use a tool like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">dig</span></code> to inspect your domain from your command line.
As an example, our blog‚Äôs DNS record looks like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><style type="text/css">
span.prompt2:before {
  content: " ";
}
</style><span class="prompt1">dig<span class="w"> </span>+short<span class="w"> </span>CNAME<span class="w"> </span>blog.readthedocs.com</span>
<span class="prompt2"><span class="w"> </span>readthedocs.io.</span>
</pre></div></div><div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>We don‚Äôt support pointing subdomains or root domains to a project using A records.
DNS A records require a static IP address and our IPs may change without notice.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="removing-a-custom-domain">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id2" role="doc-backlink">Removing a custom domain</a><a class="headerlink" href="#removing-a-custom-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To remove a custom domain:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> tab of your project.</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Domains</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>Click the <span class="guilabel">Remove</span> button next to the domain.</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Confirm</span> on the confirmation page.</p></li>
</ol>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Once a domain is removed,
your previous documentation domain is no longer served by Read the Docs,
and any request for it will return a 404 Not Found!</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="strict-transport-security-hsts-and-other-custom-headers">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id3" role="doc-backlink">Strict Transport Security (HSTS) and other custom headers</a><a class="headerlink" href="#strict-transport-security-hsts-and-other-custom-headers" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>By default, we do not return a <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security">Strict Transport Security header</a> (HSTS) for user custom domains.
This is a conscious decision as it can be misconfigured in a not easily reversible way.
For both Read the Docs Community and Read the Docs for Business, HSTS and other custom headers can be set upon request.</p>
<p>We always return the HSTS header with a max-age of at least one year
for our own domains including <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">*.readthedocs.io</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">*.readthedocs-hosted.com</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">readthedocs.org</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">readthedocs.com</span></code>.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Please contact <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-support"><span class="doc">Site support</span></a> if you want to add a custom header to your domain.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="multiple-documentation-sites-as-sub-folders-of-a-domain">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id4" role="doc-backlink">Multiple documentation sites as sub-folders of a domain</a><a class="headerlink" href="#multiple-documentation-sites-as-sub-folders-of-a-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You may host multiple documentation repositories as <strong>sub-folders of a single domain</strong>.
For example, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.org/projects/repo1</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.org/projects/repo2</span></code>.
This is <a class="reference external" href="https://moz.com/blog/subdomains-vs-subfolders-rel-canonical-vs-301-how-to-structure-links-optimally-for-seo-whiteboard-friday">a way to boost the SEO of your website</a>.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-subprojects"><span class="doc">Subprojects: host multiple projects on a single domain</span></a></dt><dd><p>Further information about hosting multiple documentation repositories, using the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-subproject"><span class="xref std std-term">subproject</span></a> feature.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<section id="troubleshooting">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id5" role="doc-backlink">Troubleshooting</a><a class="headerlink" href="#troubleshooting" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="ssl-certificate-issue-delays">
<h5><a class="toc-backref" href="#id6" role="doc-backlink">SSL certificate issue delays</a><a class="headerlink" href="#ssl-certificate-issue-delays" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The status of your domain validation and certificate can always be seen on the details page for your domain
under <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Domains</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">YOURDOMAIN.TLD (details)</span>.</p>
<p>Domains are usually validated and a certificate issued within minutes.
However, if you setup the domain in Read the Docs without provisioning the necessary DNS changes
and then update DNS hours or days later,
this can cause a delay in validating because there is an exponential back-off in validation.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Loading the domain details in the Read the Docs dashboard and saving the domain again will force a revalidation.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="the-validation-process-period-has-ended">
<h5><a class="toc-backref" href="#id7" role="doc-backlink">The validation process period has ended</a><a class="headerlink" href="#the-validation-process-period-has-ended" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>After you add a new custom domain, you have 30 days to complete the configuration.
Once that period has ended, we will stop trying to validate your domain.
If you still want to complete the configuration,
go to your domain and click on <span class="guilabel">Save</span> to restart the process.</p>
</section>
<section id="migrating-from-gitbook">
<h5><a class="toc-backref" href="#id8" role="doc-backlink">Migrating from GitBook</a><a class="headerlink" href="#migrating-from-gitbook" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>If your custom domain was previously used in GitBook, contact GitBook support (via live chat in their website)
to remove the domain name from their DNS Zone in order for your domain name to work with Read the Docs,
otherwise it will always redirect to GitBook.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/subprojects"></span><section id="how-to-manage-subprojects">
<h3>How to manage subprojects<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manage-subprojects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This guide shows you how to manage subprojects,
which is a way to host multiple projects under a ‚Äúmain project‚Äù.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-subprojects"><span class="doc">Subprojects: host multiple projects on a single domain</span></a></dt><dd><p>Read more about what the subproject feature can do and how it works.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="adding-a-subproject">
<h4>Adding a subproject<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-a-subproject" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>In the admin dashboard for your project, select <span class="guilabel">Subprojects</span> from the left menu.
From this page you can add a subproject by choosing a project from the <span class="guilabel">Subproject</span> dropdown
and typing an alias in the <span class="guilabel">Alias</span> field.</p>
<p>Immediately after adding the subproject, it will be hosted at the URL displayed in the updated list of subprojects.</p>
<img alt="Screenshot of a subproject immediately visible in the list after creation" src="_images/screenshot_subprojects_list.png" />
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Read the Docs Community</dt><dd><p>You need to be <em>maintainer</em> of a subproject in order to choose it from your main project.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Read the Docs for Business</dt><dd><p>You need to have <em>admin access</em> to the subproject in order to choose it from your main project.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<section id="editing-a-subproject">
<h4>Editing a subproject<a class="headerlink" href="#editing-a-subproject" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can edit a subproject at any time by clicking <span class="guilabel">üìùÔ∏è</span> in the list of subprojects.
On the following page, it‚Äôs possible to both change the subproject and its alias
