using the <span class="guilabel">Subproject</span> dropdown and the <span class="guilabel">Alias</span> field.
Click <span class="guilabel">Update subproject</span> to save your changes.</p>
<p>The documentations served at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/projects/&lt;subproject-alias&gt;/</span></code> will be updated immediately when you save your changes.</p>
</section>
<section id="deleting-a-subproject">
<h4>Deleting a subproject<a class="headerlink" href="#deleting-a-subproject" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can delete a subproject at any time by clicking <span class="guilabel">üìùÔ∏è</span> in the list of subprojects.
On the edit page, click <span class="guilabel">Delete subproject</span>.</p>
<p>Your subproject will be removed immediately and will be served from it‚Äôs own domain:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Previously it was served at: <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;main-project-domain&gt;/projects/&lt;subproject-alias&gt;/</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Now it will be served at <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;subproject-domain&gt;/</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Deleting a subproject only removes the reference from the main project.</strong>
It does not completely remove that project.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/hiding-a-version"></span><section id="how-to-hide-a-version-and-keep-its-documentation-online">
<h3>How to hide a version and keep its documentation online<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-hide-a-version-and-keep-its-documentation-online" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you manage a project with a lot of versions,
the version (flyout) menu of your docs can be easily overwhelmed and hard to navigate.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<img alt="_images/flyout-overwhelmed.png" src="_images/flyout-overwhelmed.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Overwhelmed flyout menu</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>You can deactivate the version to remove its docs,
but removing its docs isn‚Äôt always an option.
To not list a version in the flyout menu while keeping its docs online, you can mark it as hidden.
Go to the <span class="guilabel">Versions</span> tab of your project, click on <span class="guilabel">Edit</span> and mark the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Hidden</span></code> option.</p>
<p>Users that have a link to your old version will still be able to see your docs.
And new users can see all your versions (including hidden versions) in the versions tab of your project at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://readthedocs.org/projects/&lt;your-project&gt;/versions/</span></code></p>
<p>Check the docs about <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#version-states"><span class="std std-ref">versions‚Äô states</span></a> for more information.</p>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/setup/monorepo"></span><section id="how-to-use-a-readthedocs-yaml-file-in-a-sub-folder">
<h3>How to use a .readthedocs.yaml file in a sub-folder<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-a-readthedocs-yaml-file-in-a-sub-folder" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This guide shows how to configure a Read the Docs project to use a custom path for the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> build configuration.
<a class="reference external" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monorepo">Monorepos</a> that have multiple documentation projects in the same Git repository can benefit from this feature.</p>
<p>By default,
Read the Docs will use the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> at the top level of your Git repository.
But if a Git repository contains multiple documentation projects that need different build configurations,
you will need to have a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code> file in multiple sub-folders.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-multiproject.readthedocs.io/en/latest/">sphinx-multiproject</a></dt><dd><p>If you are only using Sphinx projects and want to share the same build configuration,
you can also use the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx-multiproject</span></code> extension.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/environment-variables"><span class="doc">How to use custom environment variables</span></a></dt><dd><p>You might also be able to reuse the same configuration file across multiple projects,
using only environment variables.
This is possible if the configuration pattern is very similar and the documentation tool is the same.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="implementation-considerations">
<h4>Implementation considerations<a class="headerlink" href="#implementation-considerations" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>This feature is currently <em>project-wide</em>.
A custom build configuration file path is applied to all versions of your documentation.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Changing the configuration path will apply to all versions.
Different versions of the project may not be able to build again if this path is changed.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="adding-an-additional-project-from-the-same-repository">
<h4>Adding an additional project from the same repository<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-an-additional-project-from-the-same-repository" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Once you have added the first project from the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#automatically-import-your-docs"><span class="std std-ref">Import Wizard</span></a>,
it will show as if it has already been imported and cannot be imported again.
In order to add another project with the same repository,
you will need to use the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#manually-import-your-docs"><span class="std std-ref">Manual Import</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="setting-the-custom-build-configuration-file">
<h4>Setting the custom build configuration file<a class="headerlink" href="#setting-the-custom-build-configuration-file" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Once you have added a Git repository to a project that needs a custom configuration file path,
navigate to <span class="menuselection">Admin ‚Ä£ Advanced Settings</span> and add the path to the <span class="guilabel">Build configuration file</span> field.</p>
<img alt="Screenshot of where to find the :guilabel:`Build configuration file` setting." src="_images/screenshot-howto-build-configuration-file.png" />
<p>After pressing <span class="guilabel">Save</span>,
you need to ensure that relevant versions of your documentation are built again.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Having multiple different build configuration files can be complex.
We recommend setting up 1-2 projects in your Monorepo and getting them to build and publish successfully before adding additional projects to the equation.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="next-steps">
<h4>Next steps<a class="headerlink" href="#next-steps" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Once you have your monorepo pattern implemented and tested and it‚Äôs ready to roll out to all your projects,
you should also consider the Read the Docs project setup for these individual projects.</p>
<p>Having individual projects gives you the full flexibility of the Read the Docs platform to make individual setups for each project.</p>
<p>For each project, it‚Äôs now possible to configure:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Sets of maintainers (or <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">organizations</span></a> on Read the Docs for Business)</p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">Custom redirect rules</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">Custom domains</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">Automation rules</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/analytics"><span class="doc">Traffic and search analytics</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Additional documentation tools with individual <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-build-customization"><span class="doc">build processes</span></a>:
One project might use <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/index.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">Sphinx</span></a>,
while another project setup might use <a class="reference external" href="https://asciidoctor.org/">Asciidoctor</a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>‚Ä¶and much more. <em>All</em> settings for a Read the Docs project is available for each individual project.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/subprojects"><span class="doc">How to manage subprojects</span></a></dt><dd><p>More information on nesting one project inside another project.
In this setup, it is still possible to use the same monorepo for each subproject.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<section id="other-tips">
<h4>Other tips<a class="headerlink" href="#other-tips" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>For a monorepo,
it‚Äôs not desirable to have changes in unrelated sub-folders trigger new builds.</p>
<p>Therefore,
you should consider setting up <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#cancel-build-based-on-a-condition"><span class="std std-ref">conditional build cancellation rules</span></a>.
The configuration is added in each <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code>,
making it possible to write one conditional build rules per documentation project in the Monorepo üíØÔ∏è</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/redirects"></span><section id="how-to-use-custom-url-redirects-in-documentation-projects">
<h3>How to use custom URL redirects in documentation projects<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-custom-url-redirects-in-documentation-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide,
you will learn the steps necessary to configure your Read the Docs project for redirecting visitors from one location to another.</p>
<p>User-defined redirects are issued by our servers when a reader visits an <em>old URL</em>,
which means that the reader is automatically redirected to a <em>new URL</em>.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/best-practice/links"><span class="doc">Best practices for linking to your documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>The need for a redirect often comes from external links to your documentation.
Read more about handling links in this explanation of best practices.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-user-defined-redirects"><span class="doc">Custom and built-in redirects on Read the Docs</span></a></dt><dd><p>If you want to know more about our implementation of redirects,
you can look up more examples in our reference before continuing with the how-to.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="adding-a-redirect-rule">
<h4>Adding a redirect rule<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-a-redirect-rule" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Redirects are configured in the project dashboard,
go to <span class="menuselection">Admin &gt; Redirects</span>.</p>
<figure class="align-default">
<img alt="Screenshot of the Redirect admin page" src="_images/screenshot_redirects.png" />
</figure>
<p>After clicking <span class="guilabel">Add Redirect</span>,
you need to select a <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span>.
This is where things get a bit more complicated you need to fill in specific information according to that choice.</p>
<section id="choosing-a-redirect-type">
<h5>Choosing a <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span><a class="headerlink" href="#choosing-a-redirect-type" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>There are different types of redirect rules targeting different needs.
For each choice in <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span>,
you can mark the choice in order to experiment and <strong>preview</strong> the final rule generated.</p>
<figure class="align-default">
<img alt="Screenshot of the Redirect &quot;Add Redirect&quot; form" src="_images/screenshot_redirects_preview.png" />
</figure>
<p>Here is a quick overview of the options available in <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span>:</p>
<dl>
<dt>Prefix redirect</dt><dd><p>This option is often relevant when moving a project from a former host to Read the Docs.
In this case, often URL paths hierarchies are redirected.</p>
<p>Read more about this option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#prefix-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Prefix redirects</span></a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Page redirect</dt><dd><p>With this option,
you can specify a page in your documentation to redirect elsewhere.
The rule triggers no matter the version of your documentation that the user is visiting.
This rule can also redirect to another website.</p>
<p>Read more about this option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#id2"><span class="std std-ref">Page redirects</span></a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Exact redirect</dt><dd><p>With this option,
you can specify a page in your documentation to redirect elsewhere.
The rule is specific to the language and version of your documentation that the user is visiting.
This rule can also redirect to another website.</p>
<p>Read more about this option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#exact-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Exact redirects</span></a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Sphinx HTMLDir =&gt; HTML</dt><dd><p>If you choose to change your Sphinx builder from <em>DirHTML writer</em> to the default <em>html5writer</em>,
you can redirect all mismatches automatically.</p>
<p>Read more about this option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#sphinx-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Sphinx redirects</span></a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Sphinx HTML =&gt; HTMLDir</dt><dd><p>Similarly to the former option,
if you choose to change your Sphinx builder from the default <em>html5writer</em> to <em>DirHTML writer</em>,
you can redirect all mismatches automatically.</p>
<p>Read more about this option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#sphinx-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Sphinx redirects</span></a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>By default, redirects are followed only if the requested page doesn‚Äôt exist
(<em>404 File Not Found</em> error).
If you need to apply a redirect for files that exist,
you can have a <span class="guilabel">Apply even if the page exists</span> option visible.
<strong>This option is only available on some plan levels</strong>.
Please ask support to enable it for you.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="defining-the-redirect-rule">
<h5>Defining the redirect rule<a class="headerlink" href="#defining-the-redirect-rule" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>As mentioned before,
you can pick and choose a <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span> that fits your redirect need.
When you have entered a <span class="guilabel">From URL</span> and <span class="guilabel">To URL</span> and the redirect preview looks good,
you are ready to save the rule.</p>
</section>
<section id="saving-the-redirect">
<h5>Saving the redirect<a class="headerlink" href="#saving-the-redirect" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The redirect is not activated before you click <span class="guilabel">Save</span>.
Before clicking, you are free to experiment and preview the effects.
Your redirect rules is added and effective immediately after saving it.</p>
<p>After adding the rule,
you can add more redirects as needed.
There are no immediate upper bounds to how many redirect rules a project may define.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="editing-and-deleting-redirect-rules">
<h4>Editing and deleting redirect rules<a class="headerlink" href="#editing-and-deleting-redirect-rules" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can always revisit <span class="menuselection">Admin &gt; Redirects</span>.
in order to delete a rule or edit it.</p>
<p>When editing a rule,
you can change its <span class="guilabel">Redirect Type</span> and its <span class="guilabel">From URL</span> or <span class="guilabel">To URL</span>.</p>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/build/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-build-process">
<h2>How-to guides: build process<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-build-process" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/build-notifications"><span class="doc">Setup build notifications and webhooks</span></a></dt><dd><p>Build notifications can alert you when your builds fail so you can take immediate action.
In this guide,
you will learn how to get notified through various available channel integrations,
including email and chat.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/pull-requests"><span class="doc">Configuring pull request builds</span></a></dt><dd><p>Have your documentation built and access a preview for every <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">pull request builds</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/environment-variables"><span class="doc">Using custom environment variables</span></a></dt><dd><p>Extra environment variables, for instance secrets, may be needed in the build process and can be defined from the project‚Äôs <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-dashboard"><span class="xref std std-term">dashboard</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/automation-rules"><span class="doc">Managing versions automatically</span></a></dt><dd><p>Automating your versioning on Read the Docs means you only have to handle your versioning logic in Git.
Learn how to define rules to automate creation of new versions on Read the Docs,
entirely using your Git repository‚Äôs version logic.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/build-notifications"></span><section id="how-to-setup-build-notifications-and-webhooks">
<h3>How to setup build notifications and webhooks<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-setup-build-notifications-and-webhooks" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide, you can learn how to setup a number of build notification mechanisms.
Build notifications can alert you when your builds fail so you can take immediate action.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Currently we don‚Äôt send notifications or trigger <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a>
on <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">builds from pull requests</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">Preview documentation from pull requests</span></a></dt><dd><p>Similarly to build notifications, you can also configure automated feedback for your pull requests.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<nav class="contents local" id="contents">
<p class="topic-title">Contents</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#email-notifications" id="id5">Email notifications</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#build-status-webhooks" id="id6">Build status webhooks</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#custom-payload-examples" id="id7">Custom payload examples</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#slack" id="id8">Slack</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#discord" id="id9">Discord</a></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#variable-substitutions-reference" id="id10">Variable substitutions reference</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#validating-the-payload" id="id11">Validating the payload</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#legacy-webhooks" id="id12">Legacy webhooks</a></p></li>
</ul>
