<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/technical-docs-seo-guide"></span><section id="how-to-do-search-engine-optimization-seo-for-documentation-projects">
<h3>How to do Search Engine Optimization (SEO) for documentation projects<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-do-search-engine-optimization-seo-for-documentation-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This article explains how documentation can be optimized to appear in search results,
ultimately increasing traffic to your docs.</p>
<p>While you optimize your docs to make them more friendly for search engine spiders/crawlers,
it‚Äôs important to keep in mind that your ultimate goal is to make your docs
more <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-discoverability"><span class="xref std std-term">discoverable</span></a> for your users.</p>
<p>By following <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#best-practices-for-documentation-seo"><span class="std std-ref">our best practices for SEO</span></a>,
you can ensure that when a user types a question into a search engine,
they can get the answers from your documentation in the search results.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>This guide isn‚Äôt meant to be your only resource on SEO,
and there‚Äôs a lot of SEO topics not covered here.
For additional reading, please see the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#external-resources"><span class="std std-ref">external resources</span></a> section.</p>
</div>
<section id="seo-basics">
<h4>SEO basics<a class="headerlink" href="#seo-basics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Search engines like Google and Bing crawl through the internet
following links in an attempt to understand and build an index
of what various pages and sites are about.
This is called ‚Äúcrawling‚Äù or ‚Äúindexing‚Äù.
When a person sends a query to a search engine,
the search engine evaluates this index using a number of factors
and attempts to return the results most likely to answer that person‚Äôs question.</p>
<p>How search engines ‚Äúrank‚Äù sites based on a person‚Äôs query
is part of their secret sauce.
While some search engines publish the basics of their algorithms
(see Google‚Äôs published details on PageRank), few search engines
give all of the details in an attempt to prevent users from gaming the rankings
with low value content which happens to rank well.</p>
<p>Both <a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769">Google</a>
and <a class="reference external" href="https://www.bing.com/webmaster/help/webmaster-guidelines-30fba23a">Bing</a> publish a set of guidelines
to help make sites easier to understand for search engines and rank better.
To summarize some of the most important aspects
as they apply to technical documentation, your site should:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Use descriptive and accurate titles in the HTML <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;title&gt;</span></code> tag.
For Sphinx, the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;title&gt;</span></code> comes from the first heading on the page.</p></li>
<li><p>Ensure your URLs are descriptive. They are displayed in search results.
Sphinx uses the source filename without the file extension as the URL.</p></li>
<li><p>Make sure the words your readers would search for to find your site
are actually included on your pages.</p></li>
<li><p>Avoid low content pages or pages with very little original content.</p></li>
<li><p>Avoid tactics that attempt to increase your search engine ranking
without actually improving content.</p></li>
<li><p>Google specifically <a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/2721306">warns about automatically generated content</a>
although this applies primarily to keyword stuffing and low value content.
High quality documentation generated from source code
(eg. auto generated API documentation) seems OK.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>While both Google and Bing discuss site performance as an important factor
in search result ranking, this guide is not going to discuss it in detail.
Most technical documentation that uses Sphinx or Read the Docs
generates static HTML and the performance is typically decent
relative to most of the internet.</p>
</section>
<section id="best-practices-for-documentation-seo">
<h4>Best practices for documentation SEO<a class="headerlink" href="#best-practices-for-documentation-seo" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Once a crawler or spider finds your site, it will follow links and redirects
in an attempt to find any and all pages on your site.
While there are a few ways to guide the search engine in its crawl
for example by using a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#seo-sitemap-xml"><span class="std std-ref">sitemap</span></a>
or a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#seo-robots-txt"><span class="std std-ref">robots.txt file</span></a>
which we‚Äôll discuss shortly,
the most important thing is making sure the spider can follow links on your site
and get to all your pages.</p>
<section id="avoid-unlinked-pages">
<h5>Avoid unlinked pages ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#avoid-unlinked-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>When building your documentation,
you should ensure that pages aren‚Äôt <em>unlinked</em>,
meaning that no other pages or navigation have a link to them.</p>
<p>Search engine crawlers will not discover pages that aren‚Äôt linked from somewhere else on your site.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">Sphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MkDocs</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>Sphinx calls pages that don‚Äôt have links to them ‚Äúorphans‚Äù
and will throw a warning while building documentation that contains an orphan
unless the warning is silenced with the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/field-lists.html#metadata" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-ref">orphan directive</span></a>.</p>
<p>We recommend failing your builds whenever Sphinx warns you,
using the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">fail_on_warnings</span></code> option in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#sphinx"><span class="std std-ref">.readthedocs.yaml</span></a>.</p>
<p>Here is an example of a warning of an unreferenced page:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>$ make html
sphinx-build -b html -d _build/doctrees . _build/html
Running Sphinx v1.8.5
...
checking consistency... /path/to/file.rst: WARNING: document isn&#39;t included in any toctree
done
...
build finished with problems, 1 warning.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>MkDocs automatically includes all <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> files in the main navigation üíØÔ∏è.
This makes sure that all files are discoverable by default,
however there are configurations that allow for unlinked files in various ways.
If you want to scan your documentation for unreferenced files and images,
a plugin like <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/wilhelmer/mkdocs-unused-files">mkdocs-unused-files</a> does the job.</p>
</div></div>
</section>
<section id="avoid-uncrawlable-content">
<h5>Avoid uncrawlable content ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#avoid-uncrawlable-content" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>While typically this isn‚Äôt a problem with technical documentation,
try to avoid content that is ‚Äúhidden‚Äù from search engines.
This includes content hidden in images or videos
which the crawler may not understand.
For example, if you do have a video in your docs,
make sure the rest of that page describes the content of the video.</p>
<p>When using images, make sure to set the image alt text or set a caption on figures.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">Sphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MkDocs</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>For Sphinx, the image and figure directives support both alt texts and captions:</p>
<div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">image</span><span class="p">::</span> your-image.png
    <span class="nc">:alt:</span> A description of this image

<span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">figure</span><span class="p">::</span> your-image.png

    A caption for this figure
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>The Markdown syntax defines an alt text for images:</p>
<div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>![<span class="nt">Image alt text</span>](<span class="na">https://dummyimage.com/600x400/</span>){ width=&quot;300&quot; }
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Though HTML supports figures and captions,
Markdown and MkDocs do not have a built-in feature.
Instead,
you can use markdown extensions such as <a class="reference external" href="https://python-markdown.github.io/extensions/md_in_html/">md-in-html</a> to allow the necessary HTML structures for including figures:</p>
<div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>&lt;figure markdown&gt;
   ![<span class="nt">Image alt text</span>](<span class="na">https://dummyimage.com/600x400/</span>){ width=&quot;300&quot; }
   &lt;figcaption&gt;Image caption&lt;/figcaption&gt;
&lt;/figure&gt;
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
</section>
<section id="redirects">
<span id="seo-redirects"></span><h5>Redirects ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Redirects tell search engines when content has moved.
For example, if this guide moved from <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">guides/technical-docs-seo-guide.html</span></code> to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">guides/sphinx-seo-guide.html</span></code>,
there will be a time period where search engines will still have the old URL in their index
and will still be showing it to users.
This is why it is important to update your own links within your docs as well as redirecting.
If the hostname moved from docs.readthedocs.io to docs.readthedocs.org, this would be even more important!</p>
<p>Read the Docs supports a few different kinds of <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-user-defined-redirects"><span class="doc">user defined redirects</span></a>
that should cover all the different cases such as redirecting a certain page for all project versions,
or redirecting one version to another.</p>
</section>
<section id="canonical-urls">
<h5>Canonical URLs ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#canonical-urls" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Anytime very similar content is hosted at multiple URLs,
it is pretty important to set a canonical URL.
The canonical URL tells search engines where the original version
your documentation is even if you have multiple versions on the internet
(for example, incomplete translations or deprecated versions).</p>
<p>Read the Docs supports <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-canonical-urls"><span class="doc">setting the canonical URL</span></a>
if you are using a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-custom-domains"><span class="doc">custom domain</span></a>
under <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Domains</span>
in the Read the Docs dashboard.</p>
</section>
<section id="use-a-robots-txt-file">
<span id="seo-robots-txt"></span><h5>Use a robots.txt file ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#use-a-robots-txt-file" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>A <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file is readable by crawlers
and lives at the root of your site (eg. <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/robots.txt">https://docs.readthedocs.io/robots.txt</a>).
It tells search engines which pages to crawl or not to crawl
and can allow you to control how a search engine crawls your site.
For example, you may want to request that search engines
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#how-can-i-avoid-search-results-having-a-deprecated-version-of-my-docs"><span class="std std-ref">ignore unsupported versions of your documentation</span></a>
while keeping those docs online in case people need them.</p>
<p>By default, Read the Docs serves a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> for you.
To customize this file, you can create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file
that is written to your documentation root on your default branch/version.</p>
<p>See the <a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/6062608">Google‚Äôs documentation on robots.txt</a>
for additional details.</p>
</section>
<section id="use-a-sitemap-xml-file">
<span id="seo-sitemap-xml"></span><h5>Use a sitemap.xml file ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#use-a-sitemap-xml-file" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>A sitemap is a file readable by crawlers that contains a list of pages
and other files on your site and some metadata or relationships about them
(eg. <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/sitemap.xml">https://docs.readthedocs.io/sitemap.xml</a>).
A good sitemaps provides information like how frequently a page or file is updated
or any alternate language versions of a page.</p>
<p>Read the Docs generates a sitemap for you that contains the last time
your documentation was updated as well as links to active versions, subprojects, and translations your project has.
We have a small separate guide on <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/sitemaps"><span class="doc">sitemaps</span></a>.</p>
<p>See the <a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/183668">Google docs on building a sitemap</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="use-meta-tags">
<h5>Use meta tags ‚úÖÔ∏è<a class="headerlink" href="#use-meta-tags" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Using a meta description allows you to customize how your pages
look in search engine result pages.</p>
<p>Typically search engines will use the first few sentences of a page if no meta description is provided.
In Sphinx, you can customize your meta description using the following RestructuredText:</p>
<div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">meta</span><span class="p">::</span>
    <span class="nc">:description lang=en:</span>
        Adding additional CSS or JavaScript files to your Sphinx documentation
        can let you customize the look and feel of your docs or add additional functionality.
</pre></div>
</div>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1" style="width: 80%">
<img alt="_images/google-search-engine-results.png" src="_images/google-search-engine-results.png" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Google search engine results showing a customized meta description</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Moz.com, an authority on search engine optimization,
makes the following suggestions for meta descriptions:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Your meta description should have the most relevant content of the page.
A searcher should know whether they‚Äôve found the right page from the description.</p></li>
<li><p>The meta description should be between 150-300 characters
and it may be truncated down to around 150 characters in some situations.</p></li>
<li><p>Meta descriptions are used for display but not for ranking.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Search engines don‚Äôt always use your customized meta description
if they think a snippet from the page is a better description.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="measure-iterate-improve">
<h4>Measure, iterate, &amp; improve<a class="headerlink" href="#measure-iterate-improve" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Search engines (and soon, Read the Docs itself) can provide useful data
that you can use to improve your docs‚Äô ranking on search engines.</p>
<section id="search-engine-feedback">
<h5>Search engine feedback<a class="headerlink" href="#search-engine-feedback" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://search.google.com/search-console">Google Search Console</a> and
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.bing.com/webmaster/help/webmaster-guidelines-30fba23a">Bing Webmaster Tools</a>
are tools for webmasters
to get feedback about the crawling of their sites (or docs in our case).
Some of the most valuable feedback these provide include:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Google and Bing will show pages that were previously indexed that now give a 404
(or more rarely a 500 or other status code).
These will remain in the index for some time but will eventually be removed.
This is a good opportunity to create a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#seo-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">redirect</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>These tools will show any crawl issues with your documentation.</p></li>
<li><p>Search Console and Webmaster Tools will highlight security issues found
or if Google or Bing took action against your site because they believe it is spammy.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="analytics-tools">
<h5>Analytics tools<a class="headerlink" href="#analytics-tools" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>A tool like <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#enabling-google-analytics-on-your-project"><span class="std std-ref">Google Analytics</span></a>
can give you feedback about the search terms people use to find your docs,
your most popular pages, and lots of other useful data.</p>
<p>Search term feedback can be used to help you optimize content for certain keywords or for related keywords.
For Sphinx documentation, or other technical documentation that has its own search features,
analytics tools can also tell you the terms people search for within your site.</p>
<p>Knowing your popular pages can help you prioritize where to spend your SEO efforts.
Optimizing your already popular pages can have a significant impact.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="external-resources">
<h4>External resources<a class="headerlink" href="#external-resources" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Here are a few additional resources to help you learn more about SEO
and rank better with search engines.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://moz.com/beginners-guide-to-seo">Moz‚Äôs beginners guide to SEO</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769">Google‚Äôs Webmaster Guidelines</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.bing.com/webmaster/help/webmaster-guidelines-30fba23a">Bing‚Äôs Webmaster Guidelines</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/7451184">Google‚Äôs SEO Starter Guide</a></p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-analytics"></span><section id="how-to-use-traffic-analytics">
<h3>How to use traffic analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-traffic-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide, you can learn to use Read the Docs‚Äô built-in traffic analytics for your documentation project.
You will also learn how to optionally add your own Google Analytics account or completely disable Google Analytics on your project.</p>
<p>Traffic Analytics lets you see <em>which</em> documents your users are reading.
This allows you to understand how your documentation is being used,
so you can focus on expanding and updating parts people are reading most.</p>
<p>To see a list of the top pages from the last month,
go to the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> tab of your project,
and then click on <span class="guilabel">Traffic Analytics</span>.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/traffic-analytics-demo.png"><img alt="Traffic analytics demo" src="_images/traffic-analytics-demo.png" style="width: 50%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Traffic analytics demo</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>You can also access analytics data from <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/search-analytics"><span class="doc">search results</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The amount of analytics data stored for download depends which site you‚Äôre using:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>On the Community site, the last 90 days are stored.</p></li>
<li><dl class="simple">
<dt>On the Commercial one, it goes from 30 to infinite storage</dt><dd><p>(check out <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/pricing/">the pricing page</a>).</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<section id="enabling-google-analytics-on-your-project">
<h4>Enabling Google Analytics on your project<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-google-analytics-on-your-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs has native support for Google Analytics.
You can enable it by:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Going to <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span> in your project.</p></li>
<li><p>Fill in the <strong>Analytics code</strong> heading with your Google Tracking ID (example <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">UA-123456674-1</span></code>)</p></li>
</ul>
<figure class="align-center" id="id2">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/google-analytics-options.png"><img alt="Options to manage Google Analytics" src="_images/google-analytics-options.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Options to manage Google Analytics</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id2" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Once your documentation rebuilds it will include your Analytics tracking code and start sending data.
Google Analytics usually takes 60 minutes,
and sometimes can take up to a day before it starts reporting data.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Read the Docs takes some extra precautions with analytics to protect user privacy.
As a result, users with Do Not Track enabled will not be counted
for the purpose of analytics.</p>
<p>For more details, see the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#do-not-track"><span class="std std-ref">Do Not Track section</span></a>
of our privacy policy.</p>
</div>
<section id="disabling-google-analytics-on-your-project">
<h5>Disabling Google Analytics on your project<a class="headerlink" href="#disabling-google-analytics-on-your-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Google Analytics can be completely disabled on your own projects.
To disable Google Analytics:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Going to <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span> in your project.</p></li>
<li><p>Check the box <strong>Disable Analytics</strong>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Your documentation will need to be rebuilt for this change to take effect.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/search-analytics"></span><section id="how-to-use-search-analytics">
<h3>How to use search analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-search-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide, you can learn to use Read the Docs‚Äô built-in search analytics for your documentation project.</p>
<p>To see a list of the top queries and an overview from the last month,
go to the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> tab of your project,
and then click on <span class="guilabel">Search Analytics</span>.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/search-analytics-demo.png"><img alt="Search analytics demo" src="_images/search-analytics-demo.png" style="width: 50%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">How the search analytics page looks.</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>In <strong>Top queries in the past 30 days</strong>,
you see all the latest searches ordered by their popularity.
The list itself is often longer than what meets the eye,
Scroll downwards on the list itself to see more results.</p>
<section id="understanding-your-analytics">
<h4>Understanding your analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#understanding-your-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>In <strong>Top queries in the past 30 days</strong>, you can see the most popular terms that users have searched for.
Next to the search query, the number of actual <strong>results</strong> for that query is shown.
The number of times the query has been used in a search is displayed as the <strong>searches</strong> number.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>If you see a search term that doesn‚Äôt have any results,
you could apply that term in documentation articles or create new ones.
This is a great way to understand missing gaps in your documentation.</p></li>
<li><p>If a search term is often used but the documentation article exists,
it can also indicate that it‚Äôs hard to navigate to the article.</p></li>
<li><p>Repeat the search yourself and inspect the results to see if they are relevant.
You can add keywords to various pages that you want to show up for searches on that page.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>In <strong>Daily search totals</strong>, you can see trends that might match special events in your project‚Äôs publicity.
If you wish to analyze these numbers in details, click <span class="guilabel">Download all data</span>
to get a CSV formatted file with all available search analytics.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/canonical-urls"></span><section id="how-to-enable-canonical-urls">
<h3>How to enable canonical URLs<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-enable-canonical-urls" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide, we introduce relevant settings for enabling canonical URLs in popular documentation frameworks.</p>
<p>If you need to customize the domain from which your documentation project is served,
please refer to <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">How to manage custom domains</span></a>.</p>
<section id="sphinx">
<h4>Sphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#sphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you are using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/getting-started-with-sphinx"><span class="doc">Sphinx</span></a>,
Read the Docs will automatically add a default value of the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/page/usage/configuration.html#confval-html_baseurl">html_baseurl</a> setting matching your canonical domain.</p>
<p>If you are using a custom <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_baseurl</span></code> in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>,
you have to ensure that the value is correct.
This can be complex,
supporting pull request builds (which are published on a separate domain),
special branches
or if you are using <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-subproject"><span class="xref std std-term">subproject</span></a> s or <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#localization-of-documentation"><span class="std std-ref">translations</span></a>.
We recommend not including a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_baseurl</span></code> in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>,
and letting Read the Docs define it.</p>
</section>
<section id="mkdocs">
<h4>MkDocs<a class="headerlink" href="#mkdocs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>For <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/getting-started-with-mkdocs"><span class="doc">MkDocs</span></a> we do not define your canonical domain automatically,
but you can use the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#site_url">site_url</a> setting to set a similar value.</p>
<p>In your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">mkdocs.yml</span></code>, define the following:</p>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Canonical URL, adjust as need with respect to your slug, language,</span>
<span class="c1"># default branch and if you use a custom domain.</span>
<span class="nt">site_url</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">https://&lt;slug&gt;.readthedocs.io/en/stable/</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Note that this will define the same canonical URL for all your branches and versions.
According to MkDocs, defining <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#site_url">site_url</a> will only define the canonical URL of a website and does not affect the base URL of generated links, CSS, or Javascript files.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>2 known issues are currently making it impossible to use <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#environment-variables">environment variables in MkDocs configuration</a>.
Once these issues are solved, it will be easier.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Support for <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">!ENV</span></code>: <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/issues/8529">#8529</a></p></li>
<li><p>Add environment variable for canonical URL: <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/issues/9781">#9781</a></p></li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>If you change your default version or canonical domain,
you‚Äôll need to re-build all your versions in order to update their
canonical URL to the new one.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/enable-offline-formats"></span><section id="how-to-enable-offline-formats">
<h3>How to enable offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-enable-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This guide provides <strong>step-by-step instructions to enabling offline formats</strong> of your documentation.</p>
<p>They are automatically built by Read the Docs during our default build process,
as long as you have the configuration enabled to turn this on.</p>
<section id="enabling-offline-formats">
<h4>Enabling offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Offline formats are enabled by the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#formats"><span class="std std-ref">formats</span></a> key in our config file.
A simple example is here:</p>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Build PDF &amp; ePub</span>
<span class="nt">formats</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">epub</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="p p-Indicator">-</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">pdf</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="verifying-offline-formats">
<h4>Verifying offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#verifying-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can verify that offline formats are building in your <span class="guilabel">Project dashboard</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Downloads</span>:</p>
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/offline-formats.jpg"><img alt="_images/offline-formats.jpg" src="_images/offline-formats.jpg" style="width: 75%;" /></a>
</section>
<section id="deleting-offline-formats">
<h4>Deleting offline formats<a class="headerlink" href="#deleting-offline-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The entries in the Downloads section of your project dashboard reflect the
formats specified in your config file for each active version.</p>
<p>This means that if you wish to remove downloadable content for a given version,
you can do so by removing the matching <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#formats"><span class="std std-ref">formats</span></a> key from
your config file.</p>
</section>
<section id="continue-learning">
<h4>Continue learning<a class="headerlink" href="#continue-learning" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>Other pages in our documentation are relevant to this feature,
and might be a useful next step.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-downloadable-documentation"><span class="doc">Understanding offline formats</span></a> - Overview of this feature.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#formats"><span class="std std-ref">formats</span></a> - Configuration file options for offline formats.</p></li>
</ul>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/embedding-content"></span><section id="how-to-embed-content-from-your-documentation">
<h3>How to embed content from your documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-embed-content-from-your-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs allows you to embed content from any of the projects we host and specific allowed external domains
(currently, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.python.org</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.scipy.org</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.sympy.org</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">numpy.org</span></code>)
This allows reuse of content across sites, making sure the content is always up to date.</p>
<p>There are a number of use cases for embedding content,
so we‚Äôve built our integration in a way that enables users to build on top of it.
This guide will show you some of our favorite integrations:</p>
<nav class="contents local" id="contents">
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#contextualized-tooltips-on-documentation-pages" id="id2">Contextualized tooltips on documentation pages</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#inline-help-on-application-website" id="id3">Inline help on application website</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#calling-the-embed-api-directly" id="id4">Calling the Embed API directly</a></p></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<section id="contextualized-tooltips-on-documentation-pages">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id2" role="doc-backlink">Contextualized tooltips on documentation pages</a><a class="headerlink" href="#contextualized-tooltips-on-documentation-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Tooltips on your own documentation are really useful to add more context to the current page the user is reading.
You can embed any content that is available via reference in Sphinx, including:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Python object references</p></li>
<li><p>Full documentation pages</p></li>
<li><p>Sphinx references</p></li>
<li><p>Term definitions</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We built a Sphinx extension called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx-hoverxref</span></code> on top of our Embed API
you can install in your project with minimal configuration.</p>
<p>Here is an example showing a tooltip when you hover with the mouse a reference:</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/sphinx-hoverxref-example.png"><img alt="_images/sphinx-hoverxref-example.png" src="_images/sphinx-hoverxref-example.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Tooltip shown when hovering on a reference using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx-hoverxref</span></code>.</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>You can find more information about this extension, how to install and configure it in the <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-hoverxref.readthedocs.io/">hoverxref documentation</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="inline-help-on-application-website">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id3" role="doc-backlink">Inline help on application website</a><a class="headerlink" href="#inline-help-on-application-website" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>This allows us to keep the official documentation as the single source of truth,
while having great inline help in our application website as well.
On the ‚ÄúAutomation Rules‚Äù admin page we could embed the content of our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">Automation rules</span></a> documentation
page and be sure it will be always up to date.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>We recommend you point at tagged releases instead of latest.
Tags don‚Äôt change over time, so you don‚Äôt have to worry about the content you are embedding disappearing.</p>
</div>
<p>The following example will fetch the section ‚ÄúCreating an automation rule‚Äù in page <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">automation-rules.html</span></code>
from our own docs and will populate the content of it into the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">#help-container</span></code> div element.</p>
<div class="highlight-html notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&quot;text/javascript&quot;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
<span class="kd">var</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">=</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="s1">&#39;url&#39;</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/automation-rules.html%23creating-an-automation-rule&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="c1">// &#39;doctool&#39;: &#39;sphinx&#39;,</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="c1">// &#39;doctoolversion&#39;: &#39;4.2.0&#39;,</span>
<span class="p">};</span>
<span class="kd">var</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nx">url</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">=</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">+</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">param</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">params</span><span class="p">);</span>
<span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">get</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">url</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{</span>
<span class="w">  </span><span class="nx">$</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;#help-container&#39;</span><span class="p">).</span><span class="nx">content</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;content&#39;</span><span class="p">]);</span>
<span class="p">});</span>
<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>

<span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">id</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&quot;help-container&quot;</span><span class="p">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>You can modify this example to subscribe to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.onclick</span></code> Javascript event,
and show a modal when the user clicks in a ‚ÄúHelp‚Äù link.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Take into account that if the title changes, your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">section</span></code> argument will break.
To avoid that, you can manually define Sphinx references above the sections you don‚Äôt want to break.
For example,</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="cp">.. in your .rst document file</span>

<span class="hll"><span class="p">..</span> <span class="nt">_unbreakable-section-reference:</span>
</span>
<span class="gh">Creating an automation rule</span>
<span class="gh">---------------------------</span>

This is the text of the section.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>.. in your .md document file

<span class="hll">(unbreakable-section-reference)=
</span><span class="gu">## Creating an automation rule</span>

This is the text of the section.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>To link to the section ‚ÄúCreating an automation rule‚Äù you can send <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">section=unbreakable-section-reference</span></code>.
If you change the title it won‚Äôt break the embedded content because the label for that title will still be <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">unbreakable-section-reference</span></code>.</p>
<p>Please, take a look at the Sphinx <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">:ref:</span></code> <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#role-ref">role documentation</a> for more information about how to create references.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="calling-the-embed-api-directly">
<h4><a class="toc-backref" href="#id4" role="doc-backlink">Calling the Embed API directly</a><a class="headerlink" href="#calling-the-embed-api-directly" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Embed API lives under <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/</span></code> URL and accept the URL of the content you want to embed.
Take a look at <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#embed"><span class="std std-ref">its own documentation</span></a> to find out more details.</p>
<p>You can click on the following links and check a live response directly in the browser as examples:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/features.html%23automatic-documentation-deployment">https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/features.html%23automatic-documentation-deployment</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://sphinx-hoverxref.readthedocs.io/en/latest/configuration.html%23confval-hoverxref_role_types&amp;doctool=sphinx&amp;doctoolversion=4.2.0">https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://sphinx-hoverxref.readthedocs.io/en/latest/configuration.html%23confval-hoverxref_role_types&amp;doctool=sphinx&amp;doctoolversion=4.2.0</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://docs.sympy.org/latest/tutorial/gotchas.html%23equals-signs">https://readthedocs.org/api/v3/embed/?url=https://docs.sympy.org/latest/tutorial/gotchas.html%23equals-signs</a></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>All relative links to pages contained in the remote content will continue to point at the remote page.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/manage-translations-sphinx"></span><section id="how-to-manage-translations-for-sphinx-projects">
<h3>How to manage translations for Sphinx projects<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manage-translations-for-sphinx-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This guide walks through the process needed to manage translations of your documentation.
Once this work is done, you can setup your project under Read the Docs to build each language of your documentation by reading <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-localization"><span class="doc">Localization of documentation</span></a>.</p>
<section id="overview">
<h4>Overview<a class="headerlink" href="#overview" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>There are many different ways to manage documentation in multiple languages by using different tools or services.
All of them have their pros and cons depending on the context of your project or organization.</p>
<p>In this guide we will focus our efforts around two different methods: manual and using <a class="reference external" href="https://www.transifex.com/">Transifex</a>.</p>
<p>In both methods, we need to follow these steps to translate our documentation:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Create translatable files (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.pot</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> extensions) from source language</p></li>
<li><p>Translate the text on those files from source language to target language</p></li>
<li><p>Build the documentation in <em>target language</em> using the translated texts</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Besides these steps, once we have published our first translated version of our documentation,
we will want to keep it updated from the source language. At that time, the workflow would be:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Update our translatable files from source language</p></li>
<li><p>Translate only <em>new</em> and <em>modified</em> texts in source language into target language</p></li>
<li><p>Build the documentation using the most up to date translations</p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="create-translatable-files">
<h4>Create translatable files<a class="headerlink" href="#create-translatable-files" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To generate these <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.pot</span></code> files it‚Äôs needed to run this command from your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs/</span></code> directory:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">sphinx-build<span class="w"> </span>-b<span class="w"> </span>gettext<span class="w"> </span>.<span class="w"> </span>_build/gettext</span>
</pre></div></div><div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>We recommend configuring Sphinx to use <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/page/usage/configuration.html#confval-gettext_uuid">gettext_uuid</a> as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">True</span></code>
and also <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/page/usage/configuration.html#confval-gettext_compact">gettext_compact</a> as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">False</span></code> to generate <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.pot</span></code> files.</p>
</div>
<p>This command will leave the generated files under <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_build/gettext</span></code>.</p>
</section>
<section id="translate-text-from-source-language">
<h4>Translate text from source language<a class="headerlink" href="#translate-text-from-source-language" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="manually">
<h5>Manually<a class="headerlink" href="#manually" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We recommend using <a class="reference external" href="https://pypi.org/project/sphinx-intl/">sphinx-intl</a> tool for this workflow.</p>
<p>First, you need to install it:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">pip<span class="w"> </span>install<span class="w"> </span>sphinx-intl</span>
</pre></div></div><p>As a second step, we want to create a directory with each translated file per target language
(in this example we are using Spanish/Argentina and Portuguese/Brazil).
This can be achieved with the following command:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">sphinx-intl<span class="w"> </span>update<span class="w"> </span>-p<span class="w"> </span>_build/gettext<span class="w"> </span>-l<span class="w"> </span>es_AR<span class="w"> </span>-l<span class="w"> </span>pt_BR</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This command will create a directory structure similar to the following
(with one <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> file per <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> file in your documentation):</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>locale
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ es_AR
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ LC_MESSAGES
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.po
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pt_BR
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ LC_MESSAGES
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.po
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Now, you can just open those <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> files with a text editor and translate them taking care of no breaking the reST notation.
Example:</p>
<div class="highlight-po notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># b8f891b8443f4a45994c9c0a6bec14c3</span>
<span class="kd">#: ../../index.rst:4</span>
<span class="nv">msgid</span> <span class="s">&quot;&quot;</span>
<span class="s">&quot;Read the Docs hosts documentation for the open source community.&quot;</span>
<span class="s">&quot;It supports :ref:`Sphinx &lt;sphinx&gt;` docs written with reStructuredText.&quot;</span>
<span class="nv">msgstr</span> <span class="s">&quot;&quot;</span>
<span class="s">&quot;FILL HERE BY TARGET LANGUAGE FILL HERE BY TARGET LANGUAGE FILL HERE &quot;</span>
<span class="s">&quot;BY TARGET LANGUAGE :ref:`Sphinx &lt;sphinx&gt;` FILL HERE.&quot;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="using-transifex">
<h5>Using Transifex<a class="headerlink" href="#using-transifex" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.transifex.com/">Transifex</a> is a platform that simplifies the manipulation of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> files and offers many useful features to make the translation process as smooth as possible.
These features includes a great web based UI, <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.transifex.com/setup/translation-memory">Translation Memory</a>, collaborative translation, etc.</p>
<p>You need to create an account in their service and a new project before start.</p>
<p>After that, you need to install the <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.transifex.com/client/introduction">transifex-client</a> tool which will help you in the process to upload source files, update them and also download translated files.
To do this, run this command:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">pip<span class="w"> </span>install<span class="w"> </span>transifex-client</span>
</pre></div></div><p>After installing it, you need to configure your account.
For this, you need to create an API Token for your user to access this service through the command line.
This can be done under your <a class="reference external" href="https://www.transifex.com/user/settings/api/">User‚Äôs Settings</a>.</p>
<p>Now, you need to setup it to use this token:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>init<span class="w"> </span>--token<span class="w"> </span><span class="nv">$TOKEN</span><span class="w"> </span>--no-interactive</span>
</pre></div></div><p>The next step is to map every <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.pot</span></code> file you have created in the previous step to a resource under Transifex.
To achieve this, you need to run this command:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>config<span class="w"> </span>mapping-bulk<span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--project<span class="w"> </span><span class="nv">$TRANSIFEX_PROJECT</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--file-extension<span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;.pot&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--source-file-dir<span class="w"> </span>docs/_build/gettext<span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--source-lang<span class="w"> </span>en<span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--type<span class="w"> </span>PO<span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--expression<span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;locale/&lt;lang&gt;/LC_MESSAGES/{filepath}/{filename}.po&#39;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="se">\</span>
<span class="w">    </span>--execute</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This command will generate a file at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.tx/config</span></code> with all the information needed by the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">transifext-client</span></code> tool to keep your translation synchronized.</p>
<p>Finally, you need to upload these files to Transifex platform so translators can start their work.
To do this, you can run this command:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>push<span class="w"> </span>--source</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Now, you can go to your Transifex‚Äôs project and check that there is one resource per <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> file of your documentation.
After the source files are translated using Transifex, you can download all the translations for all the languages by running:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>pull<span class="w"> </span>--all</span>
</pre></div></div><p>This command will leave the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.po</span></code> files needed for building the documentation in the target language under <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">locale/&lt;lang&gt;/LC_MESSAGES</span></code>.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>It‚Äôs important to use always the same method to translate the documentation and do not mix them.
Otherwise, it‚Äôs very easy to end up with inconsistent translations or losing already translated text.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<section id="build-the-documentation-in-target-language">
<h4>Build the documentation in target language<a class="headerlink" href="#build-the-documentation-in-target-language" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Finally, to build our documentation in Spanish(Argentina) we need to tell Sphinx builder the target language with the following command:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">sphinx-build<span class="w"> </span>-b<span class="w"> </span>html<span class="w"> </span>-D<span class="w"> </span><span class="nv">language</span><span class="o">=</span>es_AR<span class="w"> </span>.<span class="w"> </span>_build/html/es_AR</span>
</pre></div></div><div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>There is no need to create a new <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> to redefine the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">language</span></code> for the Spanish version of this documentation,
but you need to set <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-locale_dirs">locale_dirs</a> to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">[&quot;locale&quot;]</span></code> for Sphinx to find the translated content.</p>
</div>
<p>After running this command, the Spanish(Argentina) version of your documentation will be under <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_build/html/es_AR</span></code>.</p>
</section>
<section id="summary">
<h4>Summary<a class="headerlink" href="#summary" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="update-sources-to-be-translated">
<h5>Update sources to be translated<a class="headerlink" href="#update-sources-to-be-translated" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Once you have done changes in your documentation, you may want to make these additions/modifications available for translators so they can update it:</p>
<ol class="arabic">
<li><p>Create the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.pot</span></code> files:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">sphinx-build<span class="w"> </span>-b<span class="w"> </span>gettext<span class="w"> </span>.<span class="w"> </span>_build/gettext</span>
</pre></div></div></li>
<li><p>Push new files to Transifex</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>push<span class="w"> </span>--sources</span>
</pre></div></div></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="build-documentation-from-up-to-date-translation">
<h5>Build documentation from up to date translation<a class="headerlink" href="#build-documentation-from-up-to-date-translation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>When translators have finished their job, you may want to update the documentation by pulling the changes from Transifex:</p>
<ol class="arabic">
<li><p>Pull up to date translations from Transifex:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">tx<span class="w"> </span>pull<span class="w"> </span>--all</span>
</pre></div></div></li>
<li><p>Commit and push these changes to our repo</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">git<span class="w"> </span>add<span class="w"> </span>locale/</span>
<span class="prompt1">git<span class="w"> </span>commit<span class="w"> </span>-m<span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&quot;Update translations&quot;</span></span>
<span class="prompt1">git<span class="w"> </span>push</span>
</pre></div></div></li>
</ol>
<p>The last <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">git</span> <span class="pre">push</span></code> will trigger a build per translation defined as part of your project under Read the Docs and make it immediately available.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/pdf-non-ascii-languages"></span><section id="how-to-support-unicode-in-sphinx-pdfs">
<h3>How to support Unicode in Sphinx PDFs<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-support-unicode-in-sphinx-pdfs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Sphinx offers different <a class="reference external" href="http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-latex_engine">LaTeX engines</a> that have better support for Unicode characters,
relevant for instance for Japanese or Chinese.</p>
<p>To build your documentation in PDF format, you need to configure Sphinx properly in your project‚Äôs <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>.
Read the Docs will execute the proper commands depending on these settings.
There are <a class="reference external" href="http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#options-for-latex-output">several settings that can be defined</a> (all the ones starting with <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latex_</span></code>),
to modify Sphinx and Read the Docs behavior to make your documentation to build properly.</p>
<p>For docs that are not written in Chinese or Japanese,
and if your build fails from a Unicode error,
then try <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">xelatex</span></code> as the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latex_engine</span></code> in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">latex_engine</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;xelatex&quot;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>When Read the Docs detects that your documentation is in Chinese or Japanese,
it automatically adds some defaults for you.</p>
<p>For <em>Chinese</em> projects, it appends to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> these settings:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">latex_engine</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;xelatex&quot;</span>
<span class="n">latex_use_xindy</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span>
<span class="n">latex_elements</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;preamble&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;</span><span class="se">\\</span><span class="s2">usepackage[UTF8]</span><span class="si">{ctex}</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>And for <em>Japanese</em> projects:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">latex_engine</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">&quot;platex&quot;</span>
<span class="n">latex_use_xindy</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">False</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>You can always override these settings if you define them by yourself in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file.</p>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">xindy</span></code> is currently not supported by Read the Docs,
but we plan to support it in the near future.</p>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx"></span><section id="how-to-use-cross-references-with-sphinx">
<h3>How to use cross-references with Sphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-cross-references-with-sphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>When writing documentation you often need to link to other pages of your documentation,
other sections of the current page, or sections from other pages.</p>
<p id="target-to-paragraph">An easy way is just to use the raw URL that Sphinx generates for each page/section.
This works, but it has some disadvantages:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Links can change, so they are hard to maintain.</p></li>
<li><p>Links can be verbose and hard to read, so it is unclear what page/section they are linking to.</p></li>
<li><p>There is no easy way to link to specific sections like paragraphs, figures, or code blocks.</p></li>
<li><p>URL links only work for the html version of your documentation.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Instead, Sphinx offers a powerful way to linking to the different elements of the document,
called <em>cross-references</em>.
Some advantages of using them:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Use a human-readable name of your choice, instead of a URL.</p></li>
<li><p>Portable between formats: html, PDF, ePub.</p></li>
<li><p>Sphinx will warn you of invalid references.</p></li>
<li><p>You can cross reference more than just pages and section headers.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>This page describes some best-practices for cross-referencing with Sphinx
with two markup options: reStructuredText and MyST (Markdown).</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>If you are not familiar with reStructuredText,
check <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span>reStructuredText Primer</span></a> for a quick introduction.</p></li>
<li><p>If you want to learn more about the MyST Markdown dialect,
check out <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/syntax/reference.html" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span>Syntax tokens</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</li>

</ul>

<section id="getting-started">
<h4>Getting started<a class="headerlink" href="#getting-started" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="explicit-targets">
<span id="my-target"></span><h5>Explicit targets<a class="headerlink" href="#explicit-targets" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Cross referencing in Sphinx uses two components, <strong>references</strong> and <strong>targets</strong>.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>references</strong> are pointers in your documentation to other parts of your documentation.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>targets</strong> are where the references can point to.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You can manually create a <em>target</em> in any location of your documentation, allowing
you to <em>reference</em> it from other pages. These are called <strong>explicit targets</strong>.</p>
<p>For example, one way of creating an explicit target for a section is:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="nt">_My target:</span>

<span class="gh">Explicit targets</span>
<span class="gh">~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~</span>

Reference <span class="s">`My target`_</span>.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>(My_target)=
<span class="gu">## Explicit targets</span>

Reference [](My_target).
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Then the reference will be rendered as <a class="reference internal" href="#my-target">My target</a>.</p>
<p>You can also add explicit targets before paragraphs (or any other part of a page).</p>
<p>Another example, add a target to a paragraph:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="nt">_target to paragraph:</span>

An easy way is just to use the final link of the page/section.
This works, but it has <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`some disadvantages &lt;target to paragraph&gt;`</span>:
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>(target_to_paragraph)=

An easy way is just to use the final link of the page/section.
This works, but it has [<span class="nt">some disadvantages</span>](<span class="na">target_to_paragraph</span>):
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Then the reference will be rendered as: <a class="reference external" href="targettoparagraph">some disadvantages</a>.</p>
<p>You can also create <span class="target" id="in-line-targets">in-line targets</span> within an element on your page,
allowing you to, for example, reference text <em>within</em> a paragraph.</p>
<p>For example, an in-line target inside a paragraph:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-2-2-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-2-2-0" name="2-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-2-2-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-2-2-0" name="2-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>You can also create _<span class="nv">`in-line targets`</span> within an element on your page,
allowing you to, for example, reference text <span class="ge">*within*</span> a paragraph.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Then you can reference it using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">`in-line</span> <span class="pre">targets`_</span></code>,
that will be rendered as: <a class="reference internal" href="#in-line-targets">in-line targets</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="implicit-targets">
<h5>Implicit targets<a class="headerlink" href="#implicit-targets" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You may also reference some objects by name
without explicitly giving them one
by using <em>implicit targets</em>.</p>
<p>When you create a section, a footnote, or a citation,
Sphinx will create a target with the title as the name:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-3-3-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-3-3-0" name="3-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-3-3-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-3-3-1" name="3-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-3-3-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-3-3-0" name="3-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>For example, to reference the previous section
you can use <span class="s">`Explicit targets`_</span>.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-3-3-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-3-3-1" name="3-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>For example, to reference the previous section
you can use [](#explicit-targets).
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This requires setting <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">myst_heading_anchors</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">2</span></code> in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>,
see <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/syntax/optional.html#syntax-header-anchors" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span>Auto-generated header anchors</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>The reference will be rendered as: <a class="reference internal" href="#explicit-targets">Explicit targets</a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="cross-referencing-using-roles">
<h4>Cross-referencing using roles<a class="headerlink" href="#cross-referencing-using-roles" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>All targets seen so far can be referenced only from the same page.
Sphinx provides some roles that allow you to reference any explicit target from any page.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Since Sphinx will make all explicit targets available globally,
all targets must be unique.</p>
</div>
<p>You can see the complete list of cross-referencing roles at <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#xref-syntax" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span>Cross-referencing syntax</span></a>.
Next, you will explore the most common ones.</p>
<section id="the-ref-role">
<h5>The ref role<a class="headerlink" href="#the-ref-role" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">ref</span></code> role can be used to reference any explicit targets. For example:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-4-4-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-4-4-0" name="4-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-4-4-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-4-4-1" name="4-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-4-4-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-4-4-0" name="4-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`my target`</span>.
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`Target to paragraph &lt;target to paragraph&gt;`</span>.
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`Target inside a paragraph &lt;in-line targets&gt;`</span>.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-4-4-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-4-4-1" name="4-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`my target`.
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`Target to paragraph &lt;target_to_paragraph&gt;`.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>That will be rendered as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#my-target"><span class="std std-ref">Explicit targets</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#target-to-paragraph"><span class="std std-ref">Target to paragraph</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#in-line-targets"><span class="std std-ref">Target inside a paragraph</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">ref</span></code> role also allow us to reference code blocks:</p>
<div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="nt">_target to code:</span>

<span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">code-block</span><span class="p">::</span> <span class="k">python</span>

   <span class="c1"># Add the extension</span>
   <span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
      <span class="s1">&#39;sphinx.ext.autosectionlabel&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span>
   <span class="p">]</span>

   <span class="c1"># Make sure the target is unique</span>
   <span class="n">autosectionlabel_prefix_document</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">True</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>We can reference it using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">:ref:`code</span> <span class="pre">&lt;target</span> <span class="pre">to</span> <span class="pre">code&gt;`</span></code>,
that will be rendered as: <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#target-to-code"><span class="std std-ref">code</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="the-doc-role">
