<h5>The doc role<a class="headerlink" href="#the-doc-role" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">doc</span></code> role allows us to link to a page instead of just a section.
The target name can be relative to the page where the role exists, or relative
to your documentation‚Äôs root folder (in both cases, you should omit the extension).</p>
<p>For example, to link to a page in the same directory as this one you can use:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-5-5-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-5-5-0" name="5-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-5-5-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-5-5-1" name="5-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-5-5-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-5-5-0" name="5-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:doc:</span><span class="nv">`intersphinx`</span>
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:doc:</span><span class="nv">`/guides/intersphinx`</span>
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:doc:</span><span class="nv">`Custom title &lt;/guides/intersphinx&gt;`</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-5-5-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-5-5-1" name="5-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{doc}`intersphinx`
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{doc}`/guides/intersphinx`
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{doc}`Custom title &lt;/guides/intersphinx&gt;`
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>That will be rendered as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">How to link to other documentation projects with Intersphinx</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">How to link to other documentation projects with Intersphinx</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">Custom title</span></a></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Using paths relative to your documentation root is recommended,
so you avoid changing the target name if the page is moved.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="the-numref-role">
<h5>The numref role<a class="headerlink" href="#the-numref-role" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">numref</span></code> role is used to reference <strong>numbered</strong> elements of your documentation.
For example, tables and images.</p>
<p>To activate numbered references, add this to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Enable numref</span>
<span class="n">numfig</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">True</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Next, ensure that an object you would like to reference has an explicit target.</p>
<p>For example, you can create a target for the next image:</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<span id="target-to-image"></span><a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/logo.png"><img alt="Logo" src="_images/logo.png" style="width: 240px;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Link me!</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-6-6-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-6-6-0" name="6-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-6-6-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-6-6-1" name="6-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-6-6-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-6-6-0" name="6-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="nt">_target to image:</span>

<span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">figure</span><span class="p">::</span> /img/logo.png
   <span class="nc">:alt:</span> Logo
   <span class="nc">:align:</span> center
   <span class="nc">:width:</span> 240px

   Link me!
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-6-6-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-6-6-1" name="6-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>(target_to_image)=

```{figure} /img/logo.png
:alt: Logo
:align: center
:width: 240px
```
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Finally, reference it using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">:numref:`target</span> <span class="pre">to</span> <span class="pre">image`</span></code>,
that will be rendered as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Fig.</span> <span class="pre">N</span></code>.
Sphinx will enumerate the image automatically.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="automatically-label-sections">
<h4>Automatically label sections<a class="headerlink" href="#automatically-label-sections" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Manually adding an explicit target to each section and making sure is unique
is a big task! Fortunately, Sphinx includes an extension to help us with that problem,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/autosectionlabel.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">autosectionlabel</span></a>.</p>
<p>To activate the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">autosectionlabel</span></code> extension, add this to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate" id="target-to-code"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Add the extension</span>
<span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;sphinx.ext.autosectionlabel&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>

<span class="c1"># Make sure the target is unique</span>
<span class="n">autosectionlabel_prefix_document</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">True</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Sphinx will create explicit targets for all your sections,
the name of target has the form <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">{path/to/page}:{title-of-section}</span></code>.</p>
<p>For example, you can reference the previous section using:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-7-7-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-7-7-0" name="7-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-7-7-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-7-7-1" name="7-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-7-7-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-7-7-0" name="7-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx:explicit targets`</span>.
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`Custom title &lt;guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx:explicit targets&gt;`</span>.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-7-7-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-7-7-1" name="7-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx:explicit targets`.
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`Custom title &lt;guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx:explicit targets&gt;`.
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>That will be rendered as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#explicit-targets"><span class="std std-ref">Explicit targets</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#explicit-targets"><span class="std std-ref">Custom title</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="invalid-targets">
<h4>Invalid targets<a class="headerlink" href="#invalid-targets" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you reference an invalid or undefined target Sphinx will warn us.
You can use the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/man/sphinx-build.html#cmdoption-sphinx-build-W" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><code class="xref std std-option docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">-W</span></code></a> option when building your docs
to fail the build if there are any invalid references.
On Read the Docs you can use the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#sphinx-fail-on-warning"><span class="std std-ref">sphinx.fail_on_warning</span></a> option.</p>
</section>
<section id="finding-the-reference-name">
<h4>Finding the reference name<a class="headerlink" href="#finding-the-reference-name" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When you build your documentation, Sphinx will generate an inventory of all
explicit and implicit links called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">objects.inv</span></code>. You can list all of these targets to
explore what is available for you to reference.</p>
<p>List all targets for built documentation with:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><style type="text/css">
span.prompt1:before {
  content: "$ ";
}
</style><span class="prompt1">python<span class="w"> </span>-m<span class="w"> </span>sphinx.ext.intersphinx<span class="w"> </span>&lt;link&gt;</span>
</pre></div></div><p>Where <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;link&gt;</span></code> is either a URL or a local path that points to your inventory file
(usually in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_build/html/objects.inv</span></code>).
For example, to see all targets from the Read the Docs documentation:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">python<span class="w"> </span>-m<span class="w"> </span>sphinx.ext.intersphinx<span class="w"> </span>https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/objects.inv</span>
</pre></div></div></section>
<section id="cross-referencing-targets-in-other-documentation-sites">
<h4>Cross-referencing targets in other documentation sites<a class="headerlink" href="#cross-referencing-targets-in-other-documentation-sites" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can reference to docs outside your project too! See <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">How to link to other documentation projects with Intersphinx</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/intersphinx"></span><section id="how-to-link-to-other-documentation-projects-with-intersphinx">
<h3>How to link to other documentation projects with Intersphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-link-to-other-documentation-projects-with-intersphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This section shows you how to maintain references to named sections of other external Sphinx projects.</p>
<p>You may be familiar with using the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#ref-role" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-ref">:ref: role</span></a> to
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx"><span class="doc">link to any location of your docs</span></a>.
It helps you to keep all links within your docs up to date and warns you if a reference target moves or changes
so you can ensure that your docs don‚Äôt have broken cross-references.</p>
<p>Sometimes you may need to link to a specific section of another project‚Äôs documentation.
While you could just hyperlink directly, there is a better way.
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">Intersphinx</span></a> allows you to use all <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#xref-syntax" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-ref">cross-reference roles</span></a> from Sphinx with objects in other projects.
That is, you could use the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">:ref:</span></code> role to link to sections of other documentation projects.
Sphinx will ensure that your cross-references to the other project exist and will raise a warning if they are deleted or changed so you can keep your docs up to date.</p>
<p>If you are publishing several Sphinx projects together using Read the Docs‚Äô <em>subprojects</em> (see <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-subprojects"><span class="doc">Subprojects: host multiple projects on a single domain</span></a>),
you should use Intersphinx to reference your subprojects from other projects.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You can also use Sphinx‚Äôs <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">linkcheck</span></code> builder to check for broken links.
By default it will also check the validity of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">#anchors</span></code> in links.</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">sphinx-build<span class="w"> </span>-b<span class="w"> </span>linkcheck<span class="w"> </span>.<span class="w"> </span>_build/linkcheck</span>
</pre></div></div><p>See all the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#options-for-the-linkcheck-builder">options for the linkcheck builder</a>.</p>
</div>
<section id="using-intersphinx">
<h4>Using Intersphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#using-intersphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To use Intersphinx you need to add it to the list of extensions in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file.</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;sphinx.ext.intersphinx&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>And use the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">intersphinx_mapping</span></code> configuration to indicate the name and link of the projects you want to use.</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="n">intersphinx_mapping</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;sphinx&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">),</span>
<span class="p">}</span>

<span class="c1"># We recommend adding the following config value.</span>
<span class="c1"># Sphinx defaults to automatically resolve *unresolved* labels using all your Intersphinx mappings.</span>
<span class="c1"># This behavior has unintended side-effects, namely that documentations local references can</span>
<span class="c1"># suddenly resolve to an external location.</span>
<span class="c1"># See also:</span>
<span class="c1"># https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html#confval-intersphinx_disabled_reftypes</span>
<span class="n">intersphinx_disabled_reftypes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&quot;*&quot;</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If you are using Read the Docs‚Äô subprojects, you also need to enable the Intersphinx extension on each of the subprojects.
For each subproject, you need to add the main project and all the other subprojects to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">intersphinx_mapping</span></code>.</p>
</div>
<p>Now you can use the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx</span></code> name with a cross-reference role:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`sphinx:ref-role`</span>
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:ref:</span><span class="nv">`:ref: role &lt;sphinx:ref-role&gt;`</span>
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:doc:</span><span class="nv">`sphinx:usage/extensions/intersphinx`</span>
<span class="m">-</span> <span class="na">:doc:</span><span class="nv">`Intersphinx &lt;sphinx:usage/extensions/intersphinx&gt;`</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`sphinx:ref-role`
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{ref}`:ref: role &lt;sphinx:ref-role&gt;`
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{doc}`sphinx:usage/extensions/intersphinx`
<span class="k">-</span><span class="w"> </span>{doc}`Intersphinx &lt;sphinx:usage/extensions/intersphinx&gt;`
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Result:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#ref-role" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span>Cross-referencing arbitrary locations</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#ref-role" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-ref">:ref: role</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span>sphinx.ext.intersphinx ‚Äì Link to other projects‚Äô documentation</span></a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">Intersphinx</span></a></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You can get the targets used in Intersphinx by inspecting the source file of the project or
using <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html#showing-all-links-of-an-intersphinx-mapping-file">this utility</a>
provided by Intersphinx:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">python<span class="w"> </span>-m<span class="w"> </span>sphinx.ext.intersphinx<span class="w"> </span>https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/objects.inv</span>
</pre></div></div></div>
</section>
<section id="intersphinx-in-read-the-docs">
<h4>Intersphinx in Read the Docs<a class="headerlink" href="#intersphinx-in-read-the-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can use Intersphinx to link to subprojects, translations, another version or any other project hosted in Read the Docs.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="n">intersphinx_mapping</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to &quot;v2&quot; version of the &quot;docs&quot; project.</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs-v2&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/v2&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to the French translation of the &quot;docs&quot; project.</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs-fr&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://docs.readthedocs.io/fr/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to the &quot;apis&quot; subproject of the &quot;docs&quot; project.</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;sub-apis&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://docs.readthedocs.io/projects/apis/en/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">),</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="intersphinx-with-private-projects">
<h4>Intersphinx with private projects<a class="headerlink" href="#intersphinx-with-private-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you are using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>,
Intersphinx will not be able to fetch the inventory file from private docs.</p>
<p>Intersphinx supports <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html#using-intersphinx-with-inventory-file-under-basic-authorization">URLs with Basic Authorization</a>,
which Read the Docs supports <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#basic-authorization"><span class="std std-ref">using a token</span></a>.
You need to generate a token for each project you want to use with Intersphinx.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go the project you want to use with Intersphinx</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Sharing</span></p></li>
<li><p>Select <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">HTTP</span> <span class="pre">Header</span> <span class="pre">Token</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Set an expiration date long enough to use the token when building your project</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Share!</span></code>.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Now we can add the link to the private project with the token like:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="n">intersphinx_mapping</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to a private project named &quot;docs&quot;</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;https://&lt;token-for-docs&gt;:@readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to the private French translation of the &quot;docs&quot; project</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;https://&lt;token-for-fr-translation&gt;:@readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/fr/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="p">),</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to the private &quot;apis&quot; subproject of the &quot;docs&quot; project</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;https://&lt;token-for-apis&gt;:@readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/projects/apis/en/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="p">),</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Sphinx will strip the token from the URLs when generating the links.</p>
</div>
<p>You can use your tokens with environment variables,
so you don‚Äôt have to hard code them in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> file.
See <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-environment-variables"><span class="doc">Understanding environment variables</span></a> to use environment variables inside Read the Docs.</p>
<p>For example,
if you create an environment variable named <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">RTD_TOKEN_DOCS</span></code> with the token from the ‚Äúdocs‚Äù project.
You can use it like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">os</span>

<span class="n">RTD_TOKEN_DOCS</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">os</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">environ</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">get</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">&quot;RTD_TOKEN_DOCS&quot;</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">intersphinx_mapping</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to a private project named &quot;docs&quot;</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span>
        <span class="sa">f</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://</span><span class="si">{</span><span class="n">RTD_TOKEN_DOCS</span><span class="si">}</span><span class="s2">:@readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="p">),</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Another way of using Intersphinx with private projects is to download the inventory file and keep it in sync when the project changes.
The inventory file is by default located at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">objects.inv</span></code>, for example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/objects.inv</span></code>.</p>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># conf.py file</span>

<span class="n">intersphinx_mapping</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="c1"># Links to a private project named &quot;docs&quot; using a local inventory file.</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;docs&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;https://readthedocs-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s2">&quot;path/to/local/objects.inv&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="p">),</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/jupyter"></span><section id="how-to-use-jupyter-notebooks-in-sphinx">
<h3>How to use Jupyter notebooks in Sphinx<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-jupyter-notebooks-in-sphinx" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://jupyter.org/">Jupyter</a> notebooks are a popular tool to describe computational narratives
that mix code, prose, images, interactive components, and more.
Embedding them in your Sphinx project allows using these rich documents as documentation,
which can provide a great experience for tutorials, examples, and other types of technical content.
There are a few extensions that allow integrating Jupyter and Sphinx,
and this document will explain how to achieve some of the most commonly requested features.</p>
<section id="including-classic-ipynb-notebooks-in-sphinx-documentation">
<span id="ipynb-notebooks-sphinx"></span><h4>Including classic <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> notebooks in Sphinx documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#including-classic-ipynb-notebooks-in-sphinx-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>There are two main extensions that add support Jupyter notebooks as source files in Sphinx:
<a class="reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/">nbsphinx</a> and <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/">MyST-NB</a>. They have similar intent and basic functionality:
both can read notebooks in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> and additional formats supported by <a class="reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/">jupytext</a>,
and are configured in a similar way
(see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#nb-background"><span class="std std-ref">Existing relevant extensions</span></a> for more background on their differences).</p>
<p>First of all, create a Jupyter notebook using the editor of your liking (for example, <a class="reference external" href="https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/">JupyterLab</a>).
For example, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">source/notebooks/Example</span> <span class="pre">1.ipynb</span></code>:</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/example-notebook.png"><img alt="Example Jupyter notebook created on JupyterLab" src="_images/example-notebook.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Example Jupyter notebook created on JupyterLab</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Next, you will need to enable one of the extensions, as follows:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">nbsphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST-NB</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id2">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id2" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;nbsphinx&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id3">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id3" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;myst_nb&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Finally, you can include the notebook in any <em>toctree</em>.
For example, add this to your root document:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-1-1-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-1-1-0" name="1-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">toctree</span><span class="p">::</span>
   <span class="nc">:maxdepth:</span> 2
   <span class="nc">:caption:</span> Contents:

   notebooks/Example 1
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-1-1-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-1-1-1" name="1-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gu">```{toctree}</span>
<span class="gu">---</span>
maxdepth: 2
<span class="gu">caption: Contents:</span>
<span class="gu">---</span>
notebooks/Example 1
```
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>The notebook will render as any other HTML page in your documentation
after doing <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">make</span> <span class="pre">html</span></code>.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id4">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/example-notebook-rendered.png"><img alt="Example Jupyter notebook rendered on HTML by nbsphinx" src="_images/example-notebook-rendered.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Example Jupyter notebook rendered on HTML by nbsphinx</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id4" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>To further customize the rendering process among other things,
refer to the <a class="reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/">nbsphinx</a> or <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/">MyST-NB</a> documentation.</p>
</section>
<section id="rendering-interactive-widgets">
<h4>Rendering interactive widgets<a class="headerlink" href="#rendering-interactive-widgets" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Widgets are eventful python objects that have a representation in the browser
and that you can use to build interactive GUIs for your notebooks.
Basic widgets using <a class="reference external" href="https://ipywidgets.readthedocs.io/">ipywidgets</a> include controls like sliders, textboxes, and buttons,
and more complex widgets include interactive maps, like the ones provided by <a class="reference external" href="https://ipyleaflet.readthedocs.io/">ipyleaflet</a>.</p>
<p>You can embed these interactive widgets on HTML Sphinx documentation.
For this to work, it‚Äôs necessary to <em>save the widget state</em>
before generating the HTML documentation,
otherwise the widget will appear as empty.
Each editor has a different way of doing it:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>The classical Jupyter Notebook interface
provides a ‚ÄúSave Notebook Widget State‚Äù action in the ‚ÄúWidgets‚Äù menu,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://ipywidgets.readthedocs.io/en/stable/embedding.html" title="(in Jupyter Widgets v8.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">as explained in the ipywidgets
documentation</span></a>.
You need to click it before exporting your notebook to HTML.</p></li>
<li><p>JupyterLab provides a ‚ÄúSave Widget State Automatically‚Äù option in the ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù menu.
You need to leave it checked so that widget state is automatically saved.</p></li>
<li><p>In Visual Studio Code <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/issues/4404">it‚Äôs not possible to save the widget
state</a>
at the time of writing (June 2021).</p></li>
</ul>
<figure class="align-center" id="id5">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/jupyterlab-save-widget-state.png"><img alt="JupyterLab option to save the interactive widget state automatically" src="_images/jupyterlab-save-widget-state.png" style="width: 30%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">JupyterLab option to save the interactive widget state automatically</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id5" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>For example, if you create a notebook with a simple
<a class="reference external" href="https://ipywidgets.readthedocs.io/en/stable/examples/Widget%20List.html#intslider">IntSlider</a>
widget from ipywidgets and save the widget state,
the slider will render correctly in Sphinx.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id6">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/widget-html.gif"><img alt="Interactive widget rendered in HTML by Sphinx" src="_images/widget-html.gif" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Interactive widget rendered in HTML by Sphinx</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id6" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>To see more elaborate examples:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://ipyleaflet.readthedocs.io/">ipyleaflet</a> provides several widgets for interactive maps,
and renders live versions of them <a class="reference external" href="https://ipyleaflet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/layers/velocity.html" title="(in ipyleaflet)"><span class="xref std std-doc">in their documentation</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://docs.pyvista.org/">PyVista</a> is used for scientific 3D visualization
with several interactive backends and <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.pyvista.org/index.html#maps-and-geoscience">examples in their
documentation</a> as well.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Although widgets themselves can be embedded in HTML,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://ipywidgets.readthedocs.io/en/stable/examples/Widget%20Events.html" title="(in Jupyter Widgets v8.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">events</span></a>
require a backend (kernel) to execute.
Therefore, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&#64;interact</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.observe</span></code>, and related functionalities relying on them
will not work as expected.</p>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If your widgets need some additional JavaScript libraries,
you can add them using <code class="xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">add_js_file()</span></code>.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="using-notebooks-in-other-formats">
<span id="other-formats"></span><h4>Using notebooks in other formats<a class="headerlink" href="#using-notebooks-in-other-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>For example, this is how a simple notebook looks like in MyST Markdown format:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id7">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">Example 3.md</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id7" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>---
jupytext:
  text_representation:
    extension: .md
    format_name: myst
    format_version: 0.13
    jupytext_version: 1.10.3
kernelspec:
  display_name: Python 3
  language: python
  name: python3
---

# Plain-text notebook formats

This is a example of a Jupyter notebook stored in MyST Markdown format.

```{code-cell} ipython3
import sys
print(sys.version)
```

```{code-cell} ipython3
from IPython.display import Image
```

```{code-cell} ipython3
Image(&quot;http://sipi.usc.edu/database/preview/misc/4.2.03.png&quot;)
```
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>To render this notebook in Sphinx
you will need to add this to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-2-2-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-2-2-0" name="2-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">nbsphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-2-2-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-2-2-1" name="2-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST-NB</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-2-2-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-2-2-0" name="2-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id8">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id8" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">nbsphinx_custom_formats</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;.md&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&quot;jupytext.reads&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">&quot;fmt&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;mystnb&quot;</span><span class="p">}],</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-2-2-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-2-2-1" name="2-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id9">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id9" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">nb_custom_formats</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;.md&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">&quot;jupytext.reads&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">&quot;fmt&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;mystnb&quot;</span><span class="p">}],</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Notice that the Markdown format does not store the outputs of the computation.
Sphinx will automatically execute notebooks without outputs,
so in your HTML documentation they appear as complete.</p>
</section>
<section id="creating-galleries-of-examples-using-notebooks">
<span id="notebook-galleries"></span><h4>Creating galleries of examples using notebooks<a class="headerlink" href="#creating-galleries-of-examples-using-notebooks" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/">nbsphinx</a> has support for <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/subdir/gallery.html" title="(in nbsphinx v0.9.1-12-gce39da6)"><span class="xref std std-doc">creating thumbnail galleries from a list of Jupyter
notebooks</span></a>.
This functionality relies on <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/">Sphinx-Gallery</a>
and extends it to work with Jupyter notebooks rather than Python scripts.</p>
<p>To use it, you will need to install both nbsphinx and Sphinx-Gallery,
and modify your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code> as follows:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id10">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id10" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-python notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;nbsphinx&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;sphinx_gallery.load_style&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After doing that, there are two ways to create the gallery:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>From a reStructuredText source file, using the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">..</span> <span class="pre">nbgallery::</span></code> directive,
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/a-normal-rst-file.html#thumbnail-galleries" title="(in nbsphinx v0.9.1-12-gce39da6)"><span class="xref std std-ref">as showcased in the
documentation</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>From a Jupyter notebook, adding a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&quot;nbsphinx-gallery&quot;</span></code> tag to the metadata of a cell.
Each editor has a different way of modifying the cell metadata (see figure below).</p></li>
</ul>
<figure class="align-center" id="id11">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/jupyterlab-metadata.png"><img alt="Panel to modify cell metadata in JupyterLab" src="_images/jupyterlab-metadata.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Panel to modify cell metadata in JupyterLab</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id11" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>For example, this reST markup would create a thumbnail gallery
with generic images as thumbnails,
thanks to the Sphinx-Gallery default style:</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-3-3-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-3-3-0" name="3-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">reStructuredText</button><button aria-controls="panel-3-3-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-3-3-1" name="3-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MyST (Markdown)</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-3-3-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-3-3-0" name="3-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-rst notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gh">Thumbnails gallery</span>
<span class="gh">==================</span>

<span class="p">..</span> <span class="ow">nbgallery</span><span class="p">::</span>
   notebooks/Example 1
   notebooks/Example 2
</pre></div>
</div>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-3-3-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-3-3-1" name="3-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><div class="highlight-md notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gh"># Thumbnails gallery</span>

```{nbgallery}
notebooks/Example 1
notebooks/Example 2
```
</pre></div>
</div>
</div></div>
<figure class="align-center" id="id12">
<a class="reference internal image-reference" href="_images/thumbnail-gallery.png"><img alt="Simple thumbnail gallery created using nbsphinx" src="_images/thumbnail-gallery.png" style="width: 80%;" /></a>
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">Simple thumbnail gallery created using nbsphinx</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id12" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>To see some examples of notebook galleries in the wild:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://docs.poliastro.space/">poliastro</a> offers tools for interactive Astrodynamics in Python,
and features <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.poliastro.space/en/stable/gallery.html" title="(in poliastro v0.17)"><span class="xref std std-doc">several examples and how-to guides using notebooks</span></a>
and displays them in an appealing thumbnail gallery.
In addition, <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/poliastro/poliastro/tree/0.15.x/docs/source/examples">poliastro uses unpaired MyST
Notebooks</a>
to reduce repository size and improve integration with git.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://qiskit.org/">Qiskit</a> is a framework for quantum computing
that leverages <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">nbgallery</span></code> <a class="reference external" href="https://qiskit.org/documentation/tutorials.html" title="(in Qiskit)"><span class="xref std std-doc">for its tutorials</span></a>
and uses a highly customized style to match the branding of the website.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="background">
<h4>Background<a class="headerlink" href="#background" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="existing-relevant-extensions">
<span id="nb-background"></span><h5>Existing relevant extensions<a class="headerlink" href="#existing-relevant-extensions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>In the first part of this document
we have seen that <a class="reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/">nbsphinx</a> and <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/">MyST-NB</a> are similar.
However, there are some differences between them:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>nsphinx uses <a class="reference external" href="https://pandoc.org/">pandoc</a>
to convert the Markdown from Jupyter notebooks to reStructuredText
and then to <a class="reference external" href="https://docutils.sourceforge.io/docs/ref/doctree.html">docutils AST</a>,
whereas MyST-NB uses <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/">MyST-Parser</a>
to directly convert the Markdown text to docutils AST.
Therefore, nbsphinx assumes <a class="reference external" href="https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#pandocs-markdown">pandoc flavored Markdown</a>,
whereas MyST-NB uses <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/index.html" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">MyST flavored Markdown</span></a>.
Both Markdown flavors are mostly equal,
but they have some differences.</p></li>
<li><p>nbsphinx executes each notebook during the parsing phase,
whereas MyST-NB can execute all notebooks up front
and cache them with <a class="reference external" href="https://jupyter-cache.readthedocs.io/">jupyter-cache</a>.
This can result in shorter build times when notebooks are modified
if using MyST-NB.</p></li>
<li><p>nbsphinx provides functionality to create thumbnail galleries,
whereas MyST-NB does not have such functionality at the moment
(see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#notebook-galleries"><span class="std std-ref">Creating galleries of examples using notebooks</span></a> for more information about galleries).</p></li>
<li><p>MyST-NB allows embedding Python objects coming from the notebook in the documentation
(read <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/render/glue.html" title="(in MyST-NB)"><span class="xref std std-doc">their ‚Äúglue‚Äù documentation</span></a>
for more information)
and provides more sophisticated <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/en/stable/computation/execute.html" title="(in MyST-NB)"><span class="xref std std-doc">error reporting</span></a>
than the one nbsphinx has.</p></li>
<li><p>The visual appearance of code cells and their outputs is slightly different:
nbsphinx renders the cell numbers by default,
whereas MyST-NB doesn‚Äôt.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Deciding which one to use depends on your use case. As general recommendations:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>If you want to use <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#other-formats"><span class="std std-ref">other notebook formats</span></a>
or <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#notebook-galleries"><span class="std std-ref">generate a thumbnail gallery from your notebooks</span></a>,
nbsphinx is the right choice.</p></li>
<li><p>If you want to leverage a more optimized execution workflow
and a more streamlined parsing mechanism,
as well as some of the unique MyST-NB functionalities,
you should use MyST-NB.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="alternative-notebook-formats">
<h5>Alternative notebook formats<a class="headerlink" href="#alternative-notebook-formats" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Jupyter notebooks in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> format
(as described in the <a class="reference external" href="https://nbformat.readthedocs.io/">nbformat
documentation</a>)
are by far the most widely used for historical reasons.</p>
<p>However, to compensate some of the disadvantages of the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> format
(like cumbersome integration with version control systems),
<a class="reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/">jupytext</a> offers <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/en/stable/formats.html" title="(in Jupytext)"><span class="xref std std-doc">other formats</span></a>
based on plain text rather than JSON.</p>
<p>As a result, there are three modes of operation:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Using classic <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> notebooks. It‚Äôs the most straightforward option,
since all the tooling is prepared to work with them,
and does not require additional pieces of software.
It is therefore simpler to manage, since there are fewer moving parts.
However, it requires some care when working with Version Control Systems (like git),
by doing one of these things:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Clear outputs before commit.
Minimizes conflicts, but might defeat the purpose of notebooks themselves,
since the computation results are not stored.</p></li>
<li><p>Use tools like <a class="reference external" href="https://nbdime.readthedocs.io/">nbdime</a> (open source)
or <a class="reference external" href="https://www.reviewnb.com/">ReviewNB</a> (proprietary)
to improve the review process.</p></li>
<li><p>Use a different collaboration workflow that doesn‚Äôt involve notebooks.</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Replace <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> notebooks with <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/en/stable/formats.html" title="(in Jupytext)"><span class="xref std std-doc">a text-based format</span></a>.
These formats behave better under version control
and they can also be edited with normal text editors
that do not support cell-based JSON notebooks.
However, text-based formats do not store the outputs of the cells,
and this might not be what you want.</p></li>
<li><p>Pairing <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.ipynb</span></code> notebooks with a text-based format,
and putting the text-based file in version control,
as suggested in the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/en/stable/paired-notebooks.html" title="(in Jupytext)"><span class="xref std std-doc">jupytext documentation</span></a>.
This solution has the best of both worlds.
In some rare cases you might experience synchronization issues between both files.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>These approaches are not mutually exclusive,
nor you have to use a single format for all your notebooks.
For the examples in this document, we have used the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://jupytext.readthedocs.io/en/stable/formats.html#myst-markdown" title="(in Jupytext)"><span class="xref std std-ref">MyST Markdown
format</span></a>.</p>
<p>If you are using alternative formats for Jupyter notebooks,
you can include them in your Sphinx documentation
using either <a class="reference external" href="https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/">nbsphinx</a> or <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-nb.readthedocs.io/">MyST-NB</a>
(see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#nb-background"><span class="std std-ref">Existing relevant extensions</span></a>
for more information about the differences between them).</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/migrate-rest-myst"></span><section id="how-to-migrate-from-restructuredtext-to-myst-markdown">
<h3>How to migrate from reStructuredText to MyST Markdown<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-migrate-from-restructuredtext-to-myst-markdown" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>In this guide, you will find
how you can start writing Markdown in your existing reStructuredText project,
or migrate it completely.</p>
<p>Sphinx is usually associated with reStructuredText, the markup language
<span class="target" id="index-0"></span><a class="pep reference external" href="https://peps.python.org/pep-0287/"><strong>designed for the CPython project in the early ‚Äô00s</strong></a>.
However, for quite some time Sphinx has been compatible with Markdown as well,
thanks to a number of extensions.</p>
<p>The most powerful of such extensions is <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/index.html" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">MyST-Parser</span></a>,
which implements a CommonMark-compliant, extensible Markdown dialect
with support for the Sphinx roles and directives that make it so useful.</p>
<p>If, <strong>instead of migrating</strong>, you are starting a new project from scratch,
have a look at <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/intro.html" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span>üöÄ Get Started</span></a>.
If you are starting a <strong>project for Jupyter</strong>, you can start with Jupyter Book, which uses <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">MyST-Parser</span></code>, see the official Jupyter Book tutorial: <a class="reference external" href="https://jupyterbook.org/en/stable/start/your-first-book.html" title="(in Python)"><span>Create your first book</span></a></p>
<section id="how-to-write-your-content-both-in-restructuredtext-and-myst">
<h4>How to write  your content both in reStructuredText and MyST<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-write-your-content-both-in-restructuredtext-and-myst" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>It is useful to ask whether a migration is necessary in the first place.
Doing bulk migrations of large projects with lots of work in progress
will create conflicts for ongoing changes.
On the other hand, your writers might prefer to have some files in Markdown
and some others in reStructuredText, for whatever reason.
Luckily, Sphinx supports reading both types of markup at the same time without problems.</p>
<p>To start using MyST in your existing Sphinx project,
first <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/intro.html#installation">install the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">myst-parser</span></code> Python package</a>
and then <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/intro.html#enable-myst-in-sphinx">enable it on your configuration</a>:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id1">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-py notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="c1"># Your existing extensions</span>
    <span class="o">...</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="hll">    <span class="s2">&quot;myst_parser&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Your reStructuredText documents will keep rendering,
and you will be able to add MyST documents with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> extension
that will be processed by MyST-Parser.</p>
<p>As an example, <em>this guide</em> is written in MyST
while the rest of the Read the Docs documentation is written in reStructuredText.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>By default, MyST-Parser registers the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> suffix for MyST source files.
If you want to use a different suffix, you can do so by changing your
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">source_suffix</span></code> configuration value in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="how-to-convert-existing-restructuredtext-documentation-to-myst">
<h4>How to convert existing reStructuredText documentation to MyST<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-convert-existing-restructuredtext-documentation-to-myst" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To convert existing reST documents to MyST, you can use
the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rst2myst</span></code> CLI script shipped by <a class="reference external" href="https://rst-to-myst.readthedocs.io/en/stable/index.html" title="(in RST-to-MyST v0.3.4)"><span>RST-to-MyST</span></a>.
The script supports converting the documents one by one,
or scanning a series of directories to convert them in bulk.</p>
<p>After <a class="reference external" href="https://rst-to-myst.readthedocs.io/en/stable/index.html" title="(in RST-to-MyST v0.3.4)"><span class="xref std std-doc">installing `rst-to-myst`</span></a>,
you can run the script as follows:</p>
<div class="highlight-console notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="gp">$ </span>rst2myst<span class="w"> </span>convert<span class="w"> </span>docs/source/index.rst<span class="w">  </span><span class="c1"># Converts index.rst to index.md</span>
<span class="gp">$ </span>rst2myst<span class="w"> </span>convert<span class="w"> </span>docs/**/*.rst<span class="w">  </span><span class="c1"># Convert every .rst file under the docs directory</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>This will create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> MyST file for every <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> source file converted.</p>
<section id="how-to-modify-the-behaviour-of-rst2myst">
<h5>How to modify the behaviour of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rst2myst</span></code><a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-modify-the-behaviour-of-rst2myst" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rst2myst</span></code> accepts several flags to modify its behavior.
All of them have sensible defaults, so you don‚Äôt have to specify them
unless you want to.</p>
<p>These are a few options you might find useful:</p>
<dl class="simple myst">
<dt><a class="reference external" href="https://rst-to-myst.readthedocs.io/en/stable/cli.html#cmdoption-rst2myst-convert-d" title="(in RST-to-MyST v0.3.4)"><code class="xref std std-option docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">-d,</span> <span class="pre">--dry-run</span></code></a></dt><dd><p>Only verify that the script would work correctly,
without actually writing any files.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference external" href="https://rst-to-myst.readthedocs.io/en/stable/cli.html#cmdoption-rst2myst-convert-R" title="(in RST-to-MyST v0.3.4)"><code class="xref std std-option docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">-R,</span> <span class="pre">--replace-files</span></code></a></dt><dd><p>Replace the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> files by their <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> equivalent,
rather than writing a new <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.md</span></code> file next to the old <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.rst</span></code> one.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>You can read the full list of options in
<a class="reference external" href="https://rst-to-myst.readthedocs.io/en/stable/cli.html" title="(in RST-to-MyST v0.3.4)"><span class="xref std std-doc">the `rst2myst` documentation</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="how-to-enable-optional-syntax">
<h4>How to enable optional syntax<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-enable-optional-syntax" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Some reStructuredText syntax will require you to enable certain MyST plugins.
For example, to write <a class="reference external" href="https://docutils.sourceforge.io/docs/user/rst/quickref.html#definition-lists">reST definition lists</a>, you need to add a
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">myst_enable_extensions</span></code> variable to your Sphinx configuration, as follows:</p>
<div class="literal-block-wrapper docutils container" id="id2">
<div class="code-block-caption"><span class="caption-text">conf.py</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id2" title="Permalink to this code">ÔÉÅ</a></div>
<div class="highlight-py notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">myst_enable_extensions</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;deflist&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>You can learn more about <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/syntax/optional.html" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">other MyST-Parser plugins</span></a>
in their documentation.</p>
</section>
<section id="how-to-write-restructuredtext-syntax-within-myst">
<h4>How to write reStructuredText syntax within MyST<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-write-restructuredtext-syntax-within-myst" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>There is a small chance that <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rst2myst</span></code> does not properly understand a piece of reST syntax,
either because there is a bug in the tool
or because that syntax does not have a MyST equivalent yet.
For example, <a class="reference external" href="https://myst-parser.readthedocs.io/en/stable/faq/index.html#howto-autodoc" title="(in MyST Parser v1.0.0)"><span class="xref std std-ref">as explained in the documentation</span></a>,
the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx.ext.autodoc</span></code> extension is incompatible with MyST.</p>
<p>Fortunately, MyST supports an <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">eval-rst</span></code> directive
that will parse the content as reStructuredText, rather than MyST.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>```{eval-rst}
.. note::

   Complete MyST migration.

```
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>will produce the following result:</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Complete MyST migration.</p>
</div>
<p>As a result, this allows you to conduct a gradual migration,
at the expense of having heterogeneous syntax in your source files.
In any case, the HTML output will be the same.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/adding-custom-css"></span><section id="how-to-add-custom-css-or-javascript-to-sphinx-documentation">
<h3>How to add custom CSS or JavaScript to Sphinx documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-add-custom-css-or-javascript-to-sphinx-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Adding additional CSS or JavaScript files to your Sphinx documentation
can let you customize the look and feel of your docs
or add additional functionality.
For example, with a small snippet of CSS,
your documentation could use a custom font or have a different background color.</p>
<p>If your custom stylesheet is <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_static/css/custom.css</span></code>,
you can add that CSS file to the documentation using the
Sphinx option <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/page/usage/configuration.html#confval-html_css_files">html_css_files</a>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## conf.py</span>

<span class="c1"># These folders are copied to the documentation&#39;s HTML output</span>
<span class="n">html_static_path</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;_static&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="c1"># These paths are either relative to html_static_path</span>
<span class="c1"># or fully qualified paths (eg. https://...)</span>
<span class="n">html_css_files</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s1">&#39;css/custom.css&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>A similar approach can be used to add JavaScript files:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">html_js_files</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span>
    <span class="s1">&#39;js/custom.js&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span>
<span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The Sphinx HTML options <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_css_files</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_js_files</span></code>
were added in Sphinx 1.8.
Unless you have a good reason to use an older version,
you are strongly encouraged to upgrade.
Sphinx is almost entirely backwards compatible.</p>
</div>
<section id="overriding-or-replacing-a-theme-s-stylesheet">
<h4>Overriding or replacing a theme‚Äôs stylesheet<a class="headerlink" href="#overriding-or-replacing-a-theme-s-stylesheet" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The above approach is preferred for adding additional stylesheets or JavaScript,
but it is also possible to completely replace a Sphinx theme‚Äôs stylesheet
with your own stylesheet.</p>
<p>If your replacement stylesheet exists at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_static/css/yourtheme.css</span></code>,
you can replace your theme‚Äôs CSS file by setting <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_style</span></code> in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## conf.py</span>

<span class="n">html_style</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">&#39;css/yourtheme.css&#39;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>If you only need to override a few styles on the theme,
you can include the theme‚Äôs normal CSS using the CSS
<a class="reference external" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/&#64;import">&#64;import rule</a> .</p>
<div class="highlight-css notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c">/** css/yourtheme.css **/</span>

<span class="c">/* This line is theme specific - it includes the base theme CSS */</span>
<span class="p">@</span><span class="k">import</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;../alabaster.css&#39;</span><span class="p">;</span><span class="w">  </span><span class="c">/* for Alabaster */</span>
<span class="c">/*@import &#39;theme.css&#39;;       /* for the Read the Docs theme */</span>

<span class="nt">body</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="c">/* ... */</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>You can also add custom classes to your html elements. See <a class="reference external" href="https://docutils.sourceforge.io/docs/ref/rst/directives.html#class">Docutils Class</a> and this related <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html#id2">Sphinx footnote‚Ä¶</a> for more information.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/remove-edit-buttons"></span><section id="how-to-remove-edit-on-buttons-from-documentation">
<h3>How to remove ‚ÄúEdit on ‚Ä¶‚Äù buttons from documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-remove-edit-on-buttons-from-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>When building your documentation, Read the Docs automatically adds buttons at
the top of your documentation and in the versions menu that point readers to your repository to make
changes. For instance, if your repository is on GitHub, a button that says ‚ÄúEdit
on GitHub‚Äù is added in the top-right corner to your documentation to make it easy for readers to author
new changes.</p>
<section id="remove-links-from-top-right-corner">
<h4>Remove links from top-right corner<a class="headerlink" href="#remove-links-from-top-right-corner" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The only way to remove these links currently is to override the Read the Docs
theme templates:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>In your Sphinx project path, create a directory called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_templates</span></code>. If you
use a different <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">templates_path</span></code> option in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>, substitute that
directory name.</p></li>
<li><p>Create a file in this path called <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">breadcrumbs.html</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>The new <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">breadcrumbs.html</span></code> should look like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%-</span> <span class="n">extends</span> <span class="s2">&quot;sphinx_rtd_theme/breadcrumbs.html&quot;</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>

<span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">block</span> <span class="n">breadcrumbs_aside</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
<span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">endblock</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="remove-on-section-from-versions-menu">
<h4>Remove ‚ÄúOn ‚Ä¶‚Äù section from versions menu<a class="headerlink" href="#remove-on-section-from-versions-menu" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>This section can be removed with a custom CSS rule to hide them.
Follow the instructions under <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/adding-custom-css"><span class="doc">How to add custom CSS or JavaScript to Sphinx documentation</span></a> and put the following content into the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.css</span></code> file:</p>
<div class="highlight-css notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c">/* Hide &quot;On GitHub&quot; section from versions menu */</span>
<span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">rst-versions</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">&gt;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">rst-other-versions</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">&gt;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nc">injected</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o">&gt;</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="nt">dl</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="nd">nth-child</span><span class="o">(</span><span class="nt">4</span><span class="o">)</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p">{</span>
<span class="w">    </span><span class="k">display</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="kc">none</span><span class="p">;</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>You may need to change the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">4</span></code> number in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">dl:nth-child(4)</span></code> for a different one in case your project has more sections in the versions menu.
For example, if your project has translations into different languages, you will need to use the number <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">5</span></code> there.</p>
</div>
<p>Now when you build your documentation, your documentation won‚Äôt include an edit
button or links to the page source.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/edit-source-links-sphinx"></span><section id="adding-edit-source-links-on-your-sphinx-theme">
<h3>Adding ‚ÄúEdit Source‚Äù links on your Sphinx theme<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-edit-source-links-on-your-sphinx-theme" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs injects some extra variables in the Sphinx <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_context</span></code>
that are used by <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-rtd-theme.readthedocs.io/">our Sphinx theme</a> to display ‚Äúedit source‚Äù links at the top of all pages.
You can use these variables in your own Sphinx theme as well.</p>
<p>More information can be found on <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-html_context">Sphinx documentation</a>.</p>
<section id="github">
<h4>GitHub<a class="headerlink" href="#github" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you want to integrate GitHub, these are the required variables to put into
