your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">html_context</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;display_github&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Integrate GitHub</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;github_user&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyUserName&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Username</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;github_repo&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyDoc&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Repo name</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;github_version&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;master&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Version</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;conf_py_path&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;/source/&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Path in the checkout to the docs root</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>They can be used like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">display_github</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
    <span class="o">&lt;</span><span class="n">li</span><span class="o">&gt;&lt;</span><span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://github.com/{{ github_user }}/{{ github_repo }}</span>
    <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">blob</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">github_version</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">conf_py_path</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">pagename</span> <span class="p">}}</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rst</span><span class="s2">&quot;&gt;</span>
    <span class="n">Show</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="n">GitHub</span><span class="o">&lt;/</span><span class="n">a</span><span class="o">&gt;&lt;/</span><span class="n">li</span><span class="o">&gt;</span>
<span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">endif</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="bitbucket">
<h4>Bitbucket<a class="headerlink" href="#bitbucket" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you want to integrate Bitbucket, these are the required variables to put into
your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">html_context</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;display_bitbucket&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Integrate Bitbucket</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;bitbucket_user&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyUserName&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Username</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;bitbucket_repo&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyDoc&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Repo name</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;bitbucket_version&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;master&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Version</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;conf_py_path&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;/source/&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Path in the checkout to the docs root</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>They can be used like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">display_bitbucket</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
    <span class="o">&lt;</span><span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://bitbucket.org/{{ bitbucket_user }}/{{ bitbucket_repo }}</span>
    <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">src</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">bitbucket_version</span><span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">conf_py_path</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">pagename</span> <span class="p">}}</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rst</span><span class="s1">&#39;&quot;</span>
    <span class="n">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">&quot;icon icon-bitbucket&quot;</span><span class="o">&gt;</span> <span class="n">Edit</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="n">Bitbucket</span><span class="o">&lt;/</span><span class="n">a</span><span class="o">&gt;</span>
<span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">endif</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="gitlab">
<h4>Gitlab<a class="headerlink" href="#gitlab" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you want to integrate Gitlab, these are the required variables to put into
your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">conf.py</span></code>:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">html_context</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;display_gitlab&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Integrate Gitlab</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;gitlab_user&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyUserName&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Username</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;gitlab_repo&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;MyDoc&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Repo name</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;gitlab_version&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;master&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Version</span>
    <span class="s2">&quot;conf_py_path&quot;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s2">&quot;/source/&quot;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1"># Path in the checkout to the docs root</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>They can be used like this:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">display_gitlab</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
    <span class="o">&lt;</span><span class="n">a</span> <span class="n">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">&quot;https://{{ gitlab_host|default(&quot;</span><span class="n">gitlab</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="s2">&quot;) }}/</span>
    <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">gitlab_user</span> <span class="p">}}</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">gitlab_repo</span> <span class="p">}}</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">blob</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">gitlab_version</span> <span class="p">}}</span>
    <span class="p">{{</span> <span class="n">conf_py_path</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">pagename</span> <span class="p">}}{{</span> <span class="n">suffix</span> <span class="p">}}</span><span class="s2">&quot; class=&quot;</span><span class="n">fa</span> <span class="n">fa</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">gitlab</span><span class="s2">&quot;&gt;</span>
    <span class="n">Edit</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="n">GitLab</span><span class="o">&lt;/</span><span class="n">a</span><span class="o">&gt;</span>
<span class="p">{</span><span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">endif</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="additional-variables">
<h4>Additional variables<a class="headerlink" href="#additional-variables" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">'pagename'</span></code> - Sphinx variable representing the name of the page you‚Äôre on.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/access/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-security-and-access">
<h2>How-to guides: security and access<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-security-and-access" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/setup-single-sign-on-github-gitlab-bitbucket"><span class="doc">Single Sign-On (SSO) with GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket</span></a></dt><dd><p>When using an <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">organization</span></a> on  Read the Docs for Business,
you can configure SSO for your users to authenticate to Read the Docs.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/setup-single-sign-on-google-email"><span class="doc">Single Sign-On (SSO) with Google Workspace</span></a></dt><dd><p>When using an <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">organization</span></a> on  Read the Docs for Business,
you can configure SSO for your users to authenticate to Read the Docs.
This guide is written for Google Workspace.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"><span class="doc">Managing Read the Docs teams</span></a></dt><dd><p>When using an <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">organization</span></a> on  Read the Docs for Business,
it‚Äôs possible to create different teams with custom access levels.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/importing-private-repositories"><span class="doc">Manually importing private repositories</span></a></dt><dd><p>You can grant access to private Git repositories using Read the Docs for Business using a custom process if required.
Here is how you set it up.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/private-submodules"><span class="doc">Using private Git submodules</span></a></dt><dd><p>If you are using private Git repositories and they also contain private Git submodules,
you need to follow a few special steps.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/private-python-packages"><span class="doc">Installing private python packages</span></a></dt><dd><p>If you have private dependencies, you can install them from
a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#from-a-git-repository"><span class="std std-ref">private Git repository</span></a> or
a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#from-a-repository-manager-other-than-pypi"><span class="std std-ref">private repository manager</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/setup-single-sign-on-github-gitlab-bitbucket"></span><section id="how-to-setup-single-sign-on-sso-with-github-gitlab-or-bitbucket">
<h3>How to setup Single Sign-On (SSO) with GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-setup-single-sign-on-sso-with-github-gitlab-or-bitbucket" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>This how-to guide will provide instructions on how to enable <abbr title="Single Sign-on">SSO</abbr> with GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.
If you want more information on this feature,
please read <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/single-sign-on"><span class="doc">Choosing a Single Sign-On (SSO) approach for your organization</span></a></p>
<section id="prerequisites">
<h4>Prerequisites<a class="headerlink" href="#prerequisites" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="organization-permissions">
<h5>Organization permissions<a class="headerlink" href="#organization-permissions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>To change your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">Organization‚Äôs</span></a> settings,
you need to be an <em>owner</em> of that organization.</p>
<p>You can validate your ownership of the Organization with these steps:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span></p></li>
<li><p>Look at the <span class="guilabel">Owners</span> section on the right menu.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>If you‚Äôd like to modify this setting and are not an owner,
you can ask an existing organization owner to take the actions listed.</p>
</section>
<section id="user-setup">
<h5>User setup<a class="headerlink" href="#user-setup" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Users in your organization must have their GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-connected-accounts"><span class="doc">account connected</span></a>,
otherwise they won‚Äôt have access to any project on Read the Docs after performing this change.
You can read more about <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-organizations-and-teams/repository-permission-levels-for-an-organization">granting permissions on GitHub</a> in their documentation.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="enabling-sso">
<h4>Enabling SSO<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-sso" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can enable this feature in your organization by:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Authorization</span></p></li>
<li><p>Select <span class="guilabel">GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket</span> on the <span class="guilabel">Provider</span> dropdown.</p></li>
<li><p>Select <span class="guilabel">Save</span></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Once you enable this option,
your existing Read the Docs <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"><span class="doc">teams</span></a> will not be used.
While testing you can enable SSO and then disable it without any data loss.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="grant-access-to-read-private-documentation">
<h4>Grant access to read private documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#grant-access-to-read-private-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>By granting <strong>read</strong> permissions to a user in your git repository,
you are giving the user access to read the documentation of the associated project on Read the Docs.
By default, private git repositories are built as private documentation websites.
Having <strong>read</strong> permissions to the git repository translates to having <strong>view</strong> permissions to a private documentation website.</p>
</section>
<section id="grant-access-to-administer-a-project">
<h4>Grant access to administer a project<a class="headerlink" href="#grant-access-to-administer-a-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>By granting <strong>write</strong> permission to a user in the git repository,
you are giving the user access to read the documentation <em>and</em> to be an administrator of the associated project on Read the Docs.</p>
</section>
<section id="grant-access-to-import-a-project">
<h4>Grant access to import a project<a class="headerlink" href="#grant-access-to-import-a-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When SSO with a Git provider is enabled, only owners of the Read the Docs organization can import projects.</p>
<p>To be able to import a project,
a user must have:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p><strong>admin</strong> permissions in the associated Git repository.</p></li>
<li><p>Ownership rights to the Read the Docs organization</p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="revoke-access-to-a-project">
<h4>Revoke access to a project<a class="headerlink" href="#revoke-access-to-a-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If a user should not have access to a project,
you can revoke access to the git repository,
and this will be automatically reflected in Read the Docs.</p>
<p>The same process is followed in case you need to remove admin access,
but still want that user to have access to read the documentation.
Instead of revoking access completely,
downgrade their permissions to <em>read only</em>.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>To learn more about choosing a Single Sign-on approach,
please read <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/single-sign-on"><span class="doc">Choosing a Single Sign-On (SSO) approach for your organization</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/setup-single-sign-on-google-email"></span><section id="how-to-setup-single-sign-on-sso-with-google-workspace">
<h3>How to setup Single Sign-On (SSO) with Google Workspace<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-setup-single-sign-on-sso-with-google-workspace" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>This how-to guide will provide instructions on how to enable <abbr title="Single Sign-on">SSO</abbr> with Google Workspace.
If you want more information on this feature,
please read <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/single-sign-on"><span class="doc">Choosing a Single Sign-On (SSO) approach for your organization</span></a></p>
<section id="prerequisites">
<h4>Prerequisites<a class="headerlink" href="#prerequisites" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="organization-permissions">
<h5>Organization permissions<a class="headerlink" href="#organization-permissions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>To change your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">Organization‚Äôs</span></a> settings,
you need to be an <em>owner</em> of that organization.</p>
<p>You can validate your ownership of the Organization with these steps:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span></p></li>
<li><p>Look at the <span class="guilabel">Owners</span> section on the right menu.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>If you‚Äôd like to modify this setting and are not an owner,
you can ask an existing organization owner to take the actions listed.</p>
</section>
<section id="user-setup">
<h5>User setup<a class="headerlink" href="#user-setup" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Using this setup,
all users who have access to the configured Google Workspace will be granted a subset of permissions on your organization automatically on account creation.</p>
<p>You can still add outside collaborators and manage their access.
There are two ways to manage this access:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"><span class="doc">teams</span></a> to provide access for ongoing contribution.</p></li>
<li><p>Using <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/sharing"><span class="doc">sharing</span></a> to provide short-term access requiring a login.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
<section id="enabling-sso">
<h4>Enabling SSO<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-sso" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>By default, users that sign up with a Google account do not have any permissions over any project.
However, you can define which teams users matching your company‚Äôs domain email address will auto-join when they sign up.</p>
<p>You can enable this feature in your organization:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="menuselection">&lt;Username dropdown&gt; &gt; Organizations ‚Ä£ &lt;Organization Name&gt; ‚Ä£ Settings ‚Ä£ Authorization</span></p></li>
<li><p>Select <strong>Google</strong> in the <span class="guilabel">Provider</span> drop-down.</p></li>
<li><p>Specify your Google Workspace domain in the <span class="guilabel">Domain</span> input field and press <span class="guilabel">Save</span>.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="configure-team-for-all-users-to-join">
<h4>Configure team for all users to join<a class="headerlink" href="#configure-team-for-all-users-to-join" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can mark one or many teams that users are automatically joined when they sign up with a matching email address.
Configure this option by:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigating to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Teams</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Team name&gt;</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Edit team</span></p></li>
<li><p>Enable <em>Auto join users with an organization‚Äôs email address to this team</em>.</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Save</span></p></li>
</ul>
<p>With this enabled,
all users that sign up with their <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">employee&#64;company.com</span></code> email will automatically join this team.
These teams can have either <em>read-only</em> or <em>admin</em> permissions over a set of projects.</p>
</section>
<section id="revoke-user-s-access-to-all-the-projects">
<h4>Revoke user‚Äôs access to all the projects<a class="headerlink" href="#revoke-user-s-access-to-all-the-projects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>By disabling the Google Workspace account with email <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">employee&#64;company.com</span></code>,
you revoke access to all the projects that user had access and disable login on Read the Docs completely for that user.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"><span class="doc">How to manage Read the Docs teams</span></a></dt><dd><p>Additional user management options</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/single-sign-on"><span class="doc">Choosing a Single Sign-On (SSO) approach for your organization</span></a></dt><dd><p>Information about choosing a Single Sign-on approach</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"></span><section id="how-to-manage-read-the-docs-teams">
<h3>How to manage Read the Docs teams<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manage-read-the-docs-teams" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Read the Docs uses teams within an organization to group users and provide permissions to projects.
This guide will cover how to do team management,
including adding and removing people from teams.
You can read more about organizations and teams in our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">Organizations: permissions for projects and teams</span></a> documentation.</p>
<section id="adding-a-user-to-a-team">
<h4>Adding a user to a team<a class="headerlink" href="#adding-a-user-to-a-team" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Adding a user to a team gives them all the permissions available to that team,
whether it‚Äôs <em>read-only</em> or <em>admin</em>.
This can be done by:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigating to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Teams</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Team name&gt;</span></p></li>
<li><p>Clicking <span class="guilabel">Invite Member</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>Input the user‚Äôs Read the Docs username or email address.</p></li>
<li><p>Clicking <span class="guilabel">Add member</span>.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="removing-a-user-from-a-team">
<h4>Removing a user from a team<a class="headerlink" href="#removing-a-user-from-a-team" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Removing a user from a team removes all permissions that team gave them</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Navigating to <span class="guilabel">&lt;Username dropdown&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Organizations</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Organization name&gt;</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Teams</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">&lt;Team name&gt;</span></p></li>
<li><p>Clicking <span class="guilabel">Remove</span> next to the user.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="grant-access-to-users-to-import-a-project">
<h4>Grant access to users to import a project<a class="headerlink" href="#grant-access-to-users-to-import-a-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Make the user a member of any team with <em>admin</em> permissions,
they will be granted access to import a project on that team.</p>
</section>
<section id="automating-this-process">
<h4>Automating this process<a class="headerlink" href="#automating-this-process" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can manage teams more easily using our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/single-sign-on"><span class="doc">Single Sign-On</span></a> features.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/organizations"><span class="doc">Organizations: permissions for projects and teams</span></a></dt><dd><p>General information about the <em>organizations</em> feature.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/importing-private-repositories"></span><section id="how-to-import-private-repositories">
<h3>How to import private repositories<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-import-private-repositories" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>This guide is for users of <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.
<strong>If you are using GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket</strong>,
we recommend <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-connected-accounts"><span class="doc">connecting your account</span></a> and importing your project from
<a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/import">https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/import</a> instead of importing it manually.</p>
</div>
<p>You can grant access to private Git repositories using Read the Docs for Business.
Here is how you set it up.</p>
<p>If you are using an unsupported integration, or don‚Äôt want to connect your account,
you‚Äôll need to do some <strong>extra steps in order to have your project working</strong>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p><strong>Manually import your project using an SSH URL</strong></p></li>
<li><p><strong>Allow access to your project using an SSH key</strong></p></li>
<li><p><strong>Setup a webhook to build your documentation on every commit</strong></p></li>
</ol>
<nav class="contents local" id="table-of-contents">
<p class="topic-title">Table of contents</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#importing-your-project" id="id1">Importing your project</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#giving-access-to-your-project-with-an-ssh-key" id="id2">Giving access to your project with an SSH key</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key" id="id3">Copy your project‚Äôs public key</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#add-the-public-key-to-your-project" id="id4">Add the public key to your project</a></p>
<ul>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#github" id="id5">GitHub</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#gitlab" id="id6">GitLab</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#bitbucket" id="id7">Bitbucket</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#azure-devops" id="id8">Azure DevOps</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#others" id="id9">Others</a></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#webhooks" id="id10">Webhooks</a></p></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<section id="importing-your-project">
<h4>Importing your project<a class="headerlink" href="#importing-your-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go to <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/import/manual/">https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/import/manual/</a></p></li>
<li><p>Fill the <span class="guilabel">Repository URL</span> field with the SSH form of your repository‚Äôs URL,
e.g <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">git&#64;github.com:readthedocs/readthedocs.org.git</span></code></p></li>
<li><p>Fill the other required fields</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Next</span></p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="giving-access-to-your-project-with-an-ssh-key">
<h4>Giving access to your project with an SSH key<a class="headerlink" href="#giving-access-to-your-project-with-an-ssh-key" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>After importing your project the build will fail,
because Read the Docs doesn‚Äôt have access to clone your repository.
To give access, you‚Äôll need to add your project‚Äôs public SSH key to your VCS provider.</p>
<section id="copy-your-project-s-public-key">
<h5>Copy your project‚Äôs public key<a class="headerlink" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You can find the public SSH key of your Read the Docs project by:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Going to the <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> tab of your project</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">SSH Keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on the fingerprint of the SSH key (it looks like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">6d:ca:6d:ca:6d:ca:6d:ca</span></code>)</p></li>
<li><p>Copy the text from the <span class="guilabel">Public key</span> section</p></li>
</ol>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The private part of the SSH key is kept secret.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="add-the-public-key-to-your-project">
<h5>Add the public key to your project<a class="headerlink" href="#add-the-public-key-to-your-project" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<section id="github">
<h6>GitHub<a class="headerlink" href="#github" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>For GitHub, you can use
<a class="reference external" href="https://docs.github.com/en/developers/overview/managing-deploy-keys#deploy-keys">deploy keys with read only access</a>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go to your project on GitHub</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Settings</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Deploy Keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add deploy key</span></p></li>
<li><p>Put a descriptive title and paste the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add key</span></p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="gitlab">
<h6>GitLab<a class="headerlink" href="#gitlab" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>For GitLab, you can use <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/deploy_keys/index.html">deploy keys with read only access</a>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go to your project on GitLab</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Settings</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Repository</span></p></li>
<li><p>Expand the <span class="guilabel">Deploy Keys</span> section</p></li>
<li><p>Put a descriptive title and paste the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add key</span></p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="bitbucket">
<h6>Bitbucket<a class="headerlink" href="#bitbucket" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>For Bitbucket, you can use <a class="reference external" href="https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/access-keys-294486051.html">access keys with read only access</a>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go your project on Bitbucket</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Repository Settings</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Access keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add key</span></p></li>
<li><p>Put a descriptive label and paste the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add SSH key</span></p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="azure-devops">
<h6>Azure DevOps<a class="headerlink" href="#azure-devops" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>For Azure DevOps, you can use <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/repos/git/use-ssh-keys-to-authenticate?view=azure-devops">SSH key authentication</a>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go your Azure DevOps page</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">User settings</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">SSH public keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">New key</span></p></li>
<li><p>Put a descriptive name and paste the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add</span></p></li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="others">
<h6>Others<a class="headerlink" href="#others" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>If you are not using any of the above providers,
Read the Docs will still generate a pair of SSH keys.
You‚Äôll need to add the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a>
to your repository.
Refer to your provider‚Äôs documentation for the steps required to do this.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<section id="webhooks">
<h4>Webhooks<a class="headerlink" href="#webhooks" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To build your documentation on every commit,
you‚Äôll need to manually add a webhook, see <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-integrations"><span class="doc">Continuous Documentation Deployment</span></a>.
If you are using an unsupported integration,
you may need to setup a custom integration
using our <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#webhook-integration-generic"><span class="std std-ref">generic webhook</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/private-submodules"></span><section id="how-to-use-private-git-submodules">
<h3>How to use private Git submodules<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-use-private-git-submodules" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>This guide is for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<p>If you are using private Git repositories and they also contain private Git submodules,
you need to follow a few special steps.</p>
<p>Read the Docs uses SSH keys (with read only permissions) in order to clone private repositories.
A SSH key is automatically generated and added to your main repository, but not to your submodules.
In order to give Read the Docs access to clone your submodules you‚Äôll need to add the public SSH key to each repository of your submodules.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>You can manage which submodules Read the Docs should clone using a configuration file.
See <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#submodules"><span class="std std-ref">submodules</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Make sure you are using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">SSH</span></code> URLs for your submodules
(<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">git&#64;github.com:readthedocs/readthedocs.org.git</span></code> for example)
in your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.gitmodules</span></code> file, not <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">http</span></code> URLs.</p></li>
</ul>
</div>
<nav class="contents local" id="table-of-contents">
<p class="topic-title">Table of contents</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#github" id="id1">GitHub</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#azure-devops" id="id2">Azure DevOps</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference internal" href="#others" id="id3">Others</a></p></li>
</ul>
</nav>
<section id="github">
<h4>GitHub<a class="headerlink" href="#github" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Since GitHub doesn‚Äôt allow you to reuse a deploy key across different repositories,
you‚Äôll need to use <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.github.com/v3/guides/managing-deploy-keys/#machine-users">machine users</a>
to give read access to several repositories using only one SSH key.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Remove the SSH deploy key that was added to the main repository on GitHub</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go to your project on GitHub</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Settings</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Deploy Keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Delete the key added by <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Read</span> <span class="pre">the</span> <span class="pre">Docs</span> <span class="pre">Commercial</span> <span class="pre">(readthedocs.com)</span></code></p></li>
</ol>
</li>
<li><p>Create a GitHub user and give it read only permissions to all the necessary repositories.
You can do this by adding the account as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>A <a class="reference external" href="https://help.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-your-github-user-account/inviting-collaborators-to-a-personal-repository">collaborator</a></p></li>
<li><p>An <a class="reference external" href="https://help.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-organizations-and-teams/adding-outside-collaborators-to-repositories-in-your-organization">outside collaborator</a></p></li>
<li><p>A <a class="reference external" href="https://help.github.com/en/github/setting-up-and-managing-organizations-and-teams/adding-organization-members-to-a-team">team in an organization</a></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Attach the public SSH key from your project on Read the Docs to the GitHub user you just created</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Go to the user‚Äôs settings</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">SSH and GPG keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">New SSH key</span></p></li>
<li><p>Put a descriptive title and paste the
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#copy-your-project-s-public-key"><span class="std std-ref">public SSH key from your Read the Docs project</span></a></p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">Add SSH key</span></p></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="azure-devops">
<h4>Azure DevOps<a class="headerlink" href="#azure-devops" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Azure DevOps does not have per-repository SSH keys, but keys can be added to a user instead.
As long as this user has access to your main repository and all its submodules,
Read the Docs can clone all the repositories with the same key.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#azure-devops"><span class="std std-ref">Allow access to your Azure DevOps repository with an SSH key</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="others">
<h4>Others<a class="headerlink" href="#others" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>GitLab and Bitbucket allow you to reuse the same SSH key across different repositories.
Since Read the Docs already added the public SSH key on your main repository,
you only need to add it to each submodule repository.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#giving-access-to-your-project-with-an-ssh-key"><span class="std std-ref">Giving access to your project with an SSH key</span></a></p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/private-python-packages"></span><section id="how-to-install-private-python-packages">
<h3>How to install private python packages<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-install-private-python-packages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>This guide is for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Read the Docs uses <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/" title="(in pip v23.1)"><span class="xref std std-doc">pip</span></a> to install your Python packages.
If you have private dependencies, you can install them from
a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#from-a-git-repository"><span class="std std-ref">private Git repository</span></a> or
a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#from-a-repository-manager-other-than-pypi"><span class="std std-ref">private repository manager</span></a>.</p>
<section id="from-a-git-repository">
<h4>From a Git repository<a class="headerlink" href="#from-a-git-repository" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Pip supports installing packages from a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/topics/vcs-support/#vcs-support" title="(in pip v23.1)"><span class="xref std std-ref">Git repository</span></a> using the URI form:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">git</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="n">https</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="o">//</span><span class="n">gitprovider</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">user</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">project</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">git</span><span class="o">@</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="n">version</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Or if your repository is private:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">git</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="n">https</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="o">//</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="n">token</span><span class="p">}</span><span class="nd">@gitprovider</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">user</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">project</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">git</span><span class="o">@</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="n">version</span><span class="p">}</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Where <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">version</span></code> can be a tag, a branch, or a commit.
And <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">token</span></code> is a personal access token with read only permissions from your provider.</p>
<p>To install the package,
you need to add the URI in your <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#requirements-file"><span class="std std-ref">requirements file</span></a>.
Pip will automatically expand environment variables in your URI,
so you don‚Äôt have to hard code the token in the URI.
See <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-environment-variables"><span class="doc">using environment variables in Read the Docs</span></a> for more information.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You have to use the POSIX format for variable names (only uppercase letters and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">_</span></code> are allowed),
and including a dollar sign and curly brackets around the name (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">${API_TOKEN}</span></code>)
for <a class="reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/requirements-file-format/#using-environment-variables">pip to be able to recognize them</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Below you can find how to get a personal access token from our supported providers.
We will be using environment variables for the token.</p>
<section id="github">
<h5>GitHub<a class="headerlink" href="#github" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You need to create a personal access token with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">repo</span></code> scope.
Check the <a class="reference external" href="https://help.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/creating-a-personal-access-token-for-the-command-line#creating-a-token">GitHub documentation</a>
on how to create a personal token.</p>
<p>URI example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git+https://${GITHUB_USER}:${GITHUB_TOKEN}@github.com/user/project.git@{version}
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>GitHub doesn‚Äôt support tokens per repository.
A personal token will grant read and write access to all repositories the user has access to.
You can create a <a class="reference external" href="https://developer.github.com/v3/guides/managing-deploy-keys/#machine-users">machine user</a>
to give read access only to the repositories you need.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="gitlab">
<h5>GitLab<a class="headerlink" href="#gitlab" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You need to create a deploy token with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">read_repository</span></code> scope for the repository you want to install the package from.
Check the <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/deploy_tokens/#creating-a-deploy-token">GitLab documentation</a>
on how to create a deploy token.</p>
<p>URI example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git+https://${GITLAB_TOKEN_USER}:${GITLAB_TOKEN}@gitlab.com/user/project.git@{version}
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Here <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">GITLAB_TOKEN_USER</span></code> is the user from the deploy token you created, not your GitLab user.</p>
</section>
<section id="bitbucket">
<h5>Bitbucket<a class="headerlink" href="#bitbucket" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You need to create an app password with <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Read</span> <span class="pre">repositories</span></code> permissions.
Check the <a class="reference external" href="https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/app-passwords-828781300.html">Bitbucket documentation</a>
on how to create an app password.</p>
<p>URI example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git+https://${BITBUCKET_USER}:${BITBUCKET_APP_PASSWORD}@bitbucket.org/user/project.git@{version}&#39;
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Here <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">BITBUCKET_USER</span></code> is your Bitbucket user.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Bitbucket doesn‚Äôt support app passwords per repository.
An app password will grant read access to all repositories the user has access to.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<section id="from-a-repository-manager-other-than-pypi">
<h4>From a repository manager other than PyPI<a class="headerlink" href="#from-a-repository-manager-other-than-pypi" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Pip by default will install your packages from <a class="reference external" href="https://pypi.org/">PyPI</a>.
If you are using a repository manager like <em>pypiserver</em>, or <em>Nexus Repository</em>,
you need to set the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/cli/pip_download/#cmdoption-i" title="(in pip v23.1)"><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">--index-url</span></code></a> option.
You have two ways of set that option:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Set the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">PIP_INDEX_URL</span></code> <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-environment-variables"><span class="doc">environment variable in Read the Docs</span></a> with the index URL.
See <a class="reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/requirements-file-format#using-environment-variables">https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/requirements-file-format#using-environment-variables</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Put <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">--index-url=https://my-index-url.com/</span></code> at the top of your requirements file.
See <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/requirements-file-format/#requirements-file-format" title="(in pip v23.1)"><span>Requirements File Format</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Check your repository manager‚Äôs documentation to obtain the appropriate index URL.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/management/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-account-management">
<h2>How-to guides: account management<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-account-management" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/subscriptions"><span class="doc">Managing your Read the Docs for Business subscription</span></a></dt><dd><p>Solving the most common tasks for managing Read the Docs subscriptions.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-commercial/subscriptions"></span><section id="how-to-manage-your-read-the-docs-for-business-subscription">
<h3>How to manage your Read the Docs for Business subscription<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-manage-your-read-the-docs-for-business-subscription" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>We want to make it easy to manage your billing information.
All <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/subscriptions"><span class="doc">organization owners</span></a> can manage the subscription for that organization.
It‚Äôs easy to achieve a number of common tasks in this dashboard:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Update your credit card information.</p></li>
<li><p>Upgrade, downgrade, or cancel your plan.</p></li>
<li><p>View, download, and pay invoices.</p></li>
<li><p>Add additional tax (VAT/EIN) or contact email addresses on your invoices.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You can always find our most up to date pricing information on our <a class="reference external" href="https://about.readthedocs.com/pricing/">pricing page</a>.</p>
<section id="managing-your-subscription">
<h4>Managing your subscription<a class="headerlink" href="#managing-your-subscription" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/organizations/">https://readthedocs.com/organizations/</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Select your organization from this list.</p></li>
<li><p>Select <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> at the top of the page.</p></li>
<li><p>Select the <span class="guilabel">Subscription</span> tab on the left.</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Manage Subscription</span>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>This action will take you to the Stripe billing portal where you can manage your subscription.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You will need to be an organization owner to view subscription information.
If you do not have permission,
you can ask one of your existing organization owners to make any required changes.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="cancelling-your-subscription">
<h4>Cancelling your subscription<a class="headerlink" href="#cancelling-your-subscription" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Cancelling your subscription can be done following the instructions in <a class="reference internal" href="#managing-your-subscription">Managing your subscription</a>.
Your subscription will remain active for the remainder of the current billing period,
and will not renew for the next billing period.</p>
<p><strong>We can not cancel subscriptions through an email request,
as email is an insecure method of verifying a user‚Äôs identity.</strong>
If you email us about this,
we require you to verify your identity by logging into your Read the Docs account and submitting an official support request there.</p>
</section>
<section id="billing-information">
<h4>Billing information<a class="headerlink" href="#billing-information" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>We provide both monthly and annual subscriptions for all plans.
Annual plans are given a 2 month discount compared to monthly billing.
We only support credit card billing for our Basic and Advanced plans.
For our Pro and Enterprise users, we support invoice-based and PO billing.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>We recommend paying by credit card for all users,
as this greatly simplifies the billing process.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="discounts-and-credits">
<h4>Discounts and credits<a class="headerlink" href="#discounts-and-credits" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>We do not generally discount our software.
We provide an ad-supported service to the community with Read the Docs Community,
but we do have one standard discount that we offer.</p>
<section id="non-profit-and-academic-organizations">
<h5>Non-profit and academic organizations<a class="headerlink" href="#non-profit-and-academic-organizations" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Our community hosting,
provided for free and open source projects,
is generally where we recommend most academic projects to host their projects.
If you have constraints on how public your documentation can be,
our commercial hosting is probably a better fit.</p>
<p>We offer a 50% discount on our all of our commercial plans to certified academic and non-profit organizations.
Please contact <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-support"><span class="doc">Site support</span></a> to request this discount.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/best-practice/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-best-practices">
<h2>How-to guides: best practices<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-best-practices" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>Over the years,
we have become familiar with a number of methods that work well and which we consider <strong>best practice</strong>.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/best-practice/links"><span class="doc">Best practices for linking to your documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>Documentation changes over time,
and links and cross-references can become challenging manage for various reasons.
Here is a set of best practices explaining and addressing these challenges.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/deprecating-content"><span class="doc">Deprecating content</span></a></dt><dd><p>Best practice for removing or deprecating documentation content.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">Creating reproducible builds</span></a></dt><dd><p>Every documentation project has dependencies that are required to build it.
Using an unspecified versions of these dependencies means that your project can start breaking.
In this guide,
learn how to protect your project against breaking randomly.
<strong>This is one of our most popular guides!</strong></p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/technical-docs-seo-guide"><span class="doc">Search Engine Optimization (SEO) for documentation projects</span></a></dt><dd><p>This article explains how documentation can be optimized to appear in search results,
increasing traffic to your docs.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/hiding-a-version"><span class="doc">Hiding a version</span></a></dt><dd><p>Learn how you can keep your entire version history online without overwhelming the reader with version choices.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/deprecating-content"></span><section id="how-to-deprecate-content">
<h3>How to deprecate content<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-deprecate-content" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>When you deprecate a feature from your project,
you may want to deprecate its docs as well,
and stop your users from reading that content.</p>
<p>Deprecating content may sound as easy as delete it,
but doing that will break existing links,
and you don‚Äôt necessary want to make the content inaccessible.
Here you‚Äôll find some tips on how to use Read the Docs to deprecate your content
progressively and in non harmful ways.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/best-practice/links"><span class="doc">Best practices for linking to your documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>More information about handling URL structures, renaming and removing content.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="deprecating-versions">
<h4>Deprecating versions<a class="headerlink" href="#deprecating-versions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you have multiple versions of your project,
it makes sense to have its <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">documentation versioned</span></a> as well.
For example, if you have the following versions and want to deprecate v1.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://project.readthedocs.io/en/v1/</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://project.readthedocs.io/en/v2/</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://project.readthedocs.io/en/v3/</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>For cases like this you can <em>hide</em> a version.
Hidden versions won‚Äôt be listed in the versions menu of your docs,
and they will be listed in a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/robots"><span class="doc">robots.txt file</span></a>
to stop search engines of showing results for that version.</p>
<p>Users can still see all versions in the dashboard of your project.
To hide a version go to your project and click on <span class="guilabel">Versions</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Edit</span>,
and mark the <span class="guilabel">Hidden</span> option. Check <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#version-states"><span class="std std-ref">Version states</span></a> for more information.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If the versions of your project follow the <a class="reference external" href="https://semver.org/">semver</a> convention,
you can activate the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#version-warning"><span class="std std-ref">Version warning</span></a> option for your project.
A banner with a warning and linking to the stable version
will be shown on all versions that are lower than the stable one.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="deprecating-pages">
<h4>Deprecating pages<a class="headerlink" href="#deprecating-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You may not always want to deprecate a version, but deprecate some pages.
For example, if you have documentation about two APIs and you want to deprecate v1:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://project.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/v1.html</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://project.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/v2.html</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>A simple way is just adding a warning at the top of the page,
this will warn users visiting that page,
but it won‚Äôt stop users from being redirected to that page from search results.
You can add an entry of that page in a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/robots"><span class="doc">custom robots.txt</span></a> file
to avoid search engines of showing those results. For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># robots.txt</span>

<span class="n">User</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">agent</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">*</span>

<span class="n">Disallow</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">latest</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">api</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">v1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span> <span class="c1"># Deprecated API</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>But your users will still see search results from that page if they use the search from your docs.
With Read the Docs you can set a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#search-ranking"><span class="std std-ref">custom rank per pages</span></a>.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-yaml notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># .readthedocs.yaml</span>

<span class="nt">version</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">2</span>
<span class="nt">search</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">   </span><span class="nt">ranking</span><span class="p">:</span>
<span class="w">      </span><span class="nt">api/v1.html</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="l l-Scalar l-Scalar-Plain">-1</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>This won‚Äôt hide results from that page, but it will give priority to results from other pages.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>You can make use of Sphinx <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/directives.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">directives</span></a>
(like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">warning</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">deprecated</span></code>, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">versionchanged</span></code>)
or MkDocs <a class="reference external" href="https://python-markdown.github.io/extensions/admonition/">admonitions</a>
to warn your users about deprecated content.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="moving-and-deleting-pages">
<h4>Moving and deleting pages<a class="headerlink" href="#moving-and-deleting-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>After you have deprecated a feature for a while,
you may want to get rid of its documentation,
that‚Äôs OK, you don‚Äôt have to maintain that content forever.
But be aware that users may have links of that page saved,
and it will be frustrating and confusing for them to get a 404.</p>
<p>To solve that problem you can create a redirect to a page with a similar feature/content,
like redirecting to the docs of the v2 of your API when your users visit the deleted docs from v1,
this is a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#id2"><span class="std std-ref">page redirect</span></a> from <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/api/v1.html</span></code> to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/api/v2.html</span></code>.
See <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-user-defined-redirects"><span class="doc">Custom and built-in redirects on Read the Docs</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/best-practice/links"></span><section id="best-practices-for-linking-to-your-documentation">
<span id="automatic-redirects"></span><h3>Best practices for linking to your documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#best-practices-for-linking-to-your-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Once you start to publish documentation,
external sources will inevitably link to specific pages in your documentation.</p>
<p>Sources of incoming links vary greatly depending on the type of documentation project that is published.
They can include everything from old emails to GitHub issues, wiki articles, software comments, PDF publications, or StackOverflow answers.
Most of these incoming sources are not in your control.</p>
<p>Read the Docs makes it easier to create and manage incoming links by redirecting certain URLs automatically
and giving you access to define your own redirects.</p>
<p>In this article,
we explain how our built-in redirects work and what we consider ‚Äúbest practice‚Äù for managing incoming links.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">Versioned documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>Read more about how to handle versioned documentation and URL structures.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-user-defined-redirects"><span class="doc">Custom and built-in redirects on Read the Docs</span></a></dt><dd><p>Overview of all the redirect features available on Read the Docs.
Many of the redirect features are useful either for building external links or handling requests to old URLs.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/redirects"><span class="doc">How to use custom URL redirects in documentation projects</span></a></dt><dd><p>How to add a user-defined redirect, step-by-step.
Useful if your content changes location!</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="best-practice-permalink-your-pages">
<h4>Best practice: ‚Äúpermalink‚Äù your pages<a class="headerlink" href="#best-practice-permalink-your-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You might be familiar with the concept of <a class="reference external" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permalink">permalinks</a> from blogging.
The idea is that a blog post receives a unique link as soon as it‚Äôs published and that the link does not change afterward.
Incoming sources can reference the blog post even though the blog changes structure or the post title changes.</p>
<p>When creating an external link to a specific documentation page,
chances are that the page is moved as the documentation changes over time.</p>
<p>How should a permalink look for a documentation project?
Firstly, you should know that a <em>permalink</em> does not really exist in documentation but it is the result of careful actions to avoid breaking incoming links.</p>
<p>As a documentation owner,
you most likely want users clicking on incoming links to see the latest version of the page.</p>
<section id="good-practice">
<h5>Good practice ‚úÖ<a class="headerlink" href="#good-practice" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Use <a class="reference external" href="user-defined-redirects:Pageredirects">page redirects</a> if you are linking to the page in the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-default-version"><span class="xref std std-term">default version</span></a> of the default language. This allows links to continue working even if those defaults change.</p></li>
<li><p>If you move a page that likely has incoming references, <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/redirects"><span class="doc">create a custom redirect rule</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Links to other Sphinx projects should use <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">intersphinx</span></a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Use minimal filenames that don‚Äôt require renaming often.</p></li>
<li><p>When possible,
keep original file names rather than going for low-impact URL renaming.
Renaming an article‚Äôs title is great for the reader and great for SEO,
but this does not have to involve the URL.</p></li>
<li><p>Establish your understanding of the <em>latest</em> and <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-default-version"><span class="xref std std-term">default version</span></a> of your documentation at the beginning. Changing their meaning is very disruptive to incoming links.</p></li>
<li><p>Keep development versions <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#hidden"><span class="std std-ref">hidden</span></a> so people do not find them on search engines by mistake.
This is the best way to ensure that nobody links to URLs that are intended for development purposes.</p></li>
<li><p>Use a <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#version-warning"><span class="std std-ref">version warning</span></a> to ensure the reader is aware in case they are reading an old (archived) version.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Using Sphinx?</dt><dd><p>If you are using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">:ref:</span></code> for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/cross-referencing-with-sphinx"><span class="doc">cross-referencing</span></a>, you may add as many reference labels to a headline as you need,
keeping old reference labels. This will make refactoring documentation easier and avoid that external projects
referencing your documentation through <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/intersphinx"><span class="doc">intersphinx</span></a> break.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<section id="questionable-practice">
<h5>Questionable practice üü°<a class="headerlink" href="#questionable-practice" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Avoid using specific versions in links unless users need that exact version.
Versions get outdated.</p></li>
<li><p>Avoid using a public <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> for development versions and do not make your <em>default version</em> a development branch.
Publishing development branches can mean that users are reading instructions for unreleased software or draft documentation.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<dl>
<dt>404 pages are also okay!</dt><dd><p>If documentation pages have been removed or moved,
it can make the maintainer of the referring website aware that they need to update their link.
Users will be aware that the documentation <strong>project</strong> still exists but has changed.</p>
<p>The default Read the Docs 404 page is designed to be helpful,
but you can also design your own, see <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/404-not-found"><span class="doc">404 Not Found pages</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/troubleshooting/index"></span><section id="how-to-guides-troubleshooting-problems">
<h2>How-to guides: troubleshooting problems<a class="headerlink" href="#how-to-guides-troubleshooting-problems" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<p>In the following guides,
you can learn how to fix common problems using Read the Docs.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/build-troubleshooting"><span class="doc">Troubleshooting build errors</span></a></dt><dd><p>A list of common errors and resolutions encountered in the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">build process</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/build-using-too-many-resources"><span class="doc">Troubleshooting slow builds</span></a></dt><dd><p>A list of the most common issues that are slowing down builds.
Even if you are not facing any immediate performance issues,
it‚Äôs always good to be familiar with the most common ones.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-guides/build-troubleshooting"></span><section id="troubleshooting-build-errors">
<h3>Troubleshooting build errors<a class="headerlink" href="#troubleshooting-build-errors" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Please help us keep this section updated and contribute your own error resolutions, performance improvements, etc.
Send in your helpful comments or ideas üí° to <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>org</a>
or contribute directly by clicking <span class="guilabel">Edit on GitHub</span> in the top right corner of this page.</p>
</div>
<p>This guide provides some common errors and resolutions encountered in the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-builds"><span class="doc">build process</span></a>.</p>
<section id="git-errors">
<h4>Git errors<a class="headerlink" href="#git-errors" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>In the examples below, we use <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">github.com</span></code>, however error messages are similar for GitLab, Bitbucket etc.</p>
<section id="terminal-prompts-disabled">
<h5>terminal prompts disabled<a class="headerlink" href="#terminal-prompts-disabled" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<div class="highlight-text notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>fatal: could not read Username for &#39;https://github.com&#39;: terminal prompts disabled
</pre></div>
</div>
<p><strong>Resolution:</strong> This error can be quite misleading. It usually occurs when a repository could not be found because of a typo in the reposistory name or because the repository has been deleted. Verify your repository URL in <span class="guilabel">Admin &gt; Advanced Settings</span>.</p>
<p>This error also occurs if you have changed a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">public</span></code> repository to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">private</span></code> and you are using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://</span></code> in your git repository URL.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>To use private repositories, you need a plan on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="error-pathspec">
<h5>error: pathspec<a class="headerlink" href="#error-pathspec" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<div class="highlight-text notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>error: pathspec &#39;main&#39; did not match any file(s) known to git
</pre></div>
</div>
<p><strong>Resolution:</strong> A specified branch does not exist in the git repository.
This might be because the git repository was recently created (and has no commits nor branches) or because the default branch has changed name. If for instance, the default branch on GitHub changed from <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">master</span></code> to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code>, you need to visit <span class="guilabel">Admin &gt; Advanced Settings</span> to change the name of the default branch that Read the Docs expects to find when cloning the repository.</p>
</section>
<section id="permission-denied-publickey">
<h5>Permission denied (publickey)<a class="headerlink" href="#permission-denied-publickey" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
