<div class="highlight-text notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>git@github.com: Permission denied (publickey).

fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
</pre></div>
</div>
<p><strong>Resolution:</strong> The git repository URL points to a repository, user account or organization that Read the Docs does not have credentials for. Verify that the public SSH key from your Read the Docs project is installed as a <em>deploy key</em> on your VCS (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket etc):</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="guilabel">Admin &gt; SSH Keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Copy the contents of the public key.</p></li>
<li><p>Ensure that the key exists as a deploy key at your VCS provider. Here are direct links to access settings for verifying and changing deploy keys - customize the URLs for your VCS host and repository details:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://github.com/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/settings/keys</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://gitlab.com/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/-/settings/repository</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://bitbucket.org/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/admin/access-keys/</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
</section>
<section id="error-repository-not-found">
<h5>ERROR: Repository not found.<a class="headerlink" href="#error-repository-not-found" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<div class="highlight-text notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>ERROR: Repository not found.
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
</pre></div>
</div>
<p><strong>Resolution:</strong> This error usually occurs on private git repositories that no longer have the public SSH key from their Read the Docs project installed as a <em>deploy key</em>.</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Navigate to <span class="guilabel">Admin &gt; SSH Keys</span></p></li>
<li><p>Copy the contents of the public key.</p></li>
<li><p>Ensure that the key exists as a deploy key at your VCS provider. Here are direct links to access settings for verifying and changing deploy keys - customize the URLs for your VCS host and repository details:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://github.com/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/settings/keys</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://gitlab.com/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/-/settings/repository</span></code></p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://bitbucket.org/&lt;username&gt;/&lt;repo&gt;/admin/access-keys/</span></code></p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<p>This error is rare for public repositories. If your repository is public and you see this error, it may be because you have specified a wrong domain or forgotten a component in the path.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-guides/build-using-too-many-resources"></span><section id="troubleshooting-slow-builds">
<h3>Troubleshooting slow builds<a class="headerlink" href="#troubleshooting-slow-builds" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This page contains a list of the most common issues that are slowing down builds.</p>
<p>In case you are waiting a long time for your builds to finish
or your builds are terminated by exceeding general resource limits,
this troubleshooting guide will help you resolve some of the most common issues causing slow builds.
Even if you are not facing any immediate performance issues,
it‚Äôs always good to be familiar with the most common ones.</p>
<p>Build resources on Read the Docs are limited to make sure that users don‚Äôt overwhelm our build systems.
The current build limits can be found on our <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#build-resources"><span class="std std-ref">Build resources reference</span></a>.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>Please help us keep this section updated and contribute your own error resolutions, performance improvements, etc.
Send in your helpful comments or ideas üí° to <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>org</a>
or contribute directly by clicking <span class="guilabel">Edit on GitHub</span> in the top right corner of this page.</p>
</div>
<section id="reduce-formats-you-re-building">
<h4>Reduce formats you‚Äôre building<a class="headerlink" href="#reduce-formats-you-re-building" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can change the formats of docs that you‚Äôre building with our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-config-file/index"><span class="doc">Configuration file</span></a>,
see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#formats"><span class="std std-ref">formats</span></a>.</p>
<p>In particular, the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">htmlzip</span></code> takes up a decent amount of memory and time,
so disabling that format might solve your problem.</p>
</section>
<section id="reduce-documentation-build-dependencies">
<h4>Reduce documentation build dependencies<a class="headerlink" href="#reduce-documentation-build-dependencies" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>A lot of projects reuse their requirements file for their documentation builds.
If there are extra packages that you don‚Äôt need for building docs,
you can create a custom requirements file just for documentation.
This should speed up your documentation builds,
as well as reduce your memory footprint.</p>
</section>
<section id="use-mamba-instead-of-conda">
<h4>Use mamba instead of conda<a class="headerlink" href="#use-mamba-instead-of-conda" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you need conda packages to build your documentation,
you can <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#making-builds-faster-with-mamba"><span class="std std-ref">use mamba as a drop-in replacement to conda</span></a>,
which requires less memory and is noticeably faster.</p>
</section>
<section id="document-python-modules-api-statically">
<h4>Document Python modules API statically<a class="headerlink" href="#document-python-modules-api-statically" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you are installing a lot of Python dependencies just to document your Python modules API using <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sphinx.ext.autodoc</span></code>,
you can give a try to <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-autoapi.readthedocs.io/">sphinx-autoapi</a> Sphinx‚Äôs extension instead which should produce the exact same output but running statically.
This could drastically reduce the memory and bandwidth required to build your docs.</p>
</section>
<section id="requests-more-resources">
<h4>Requests more resources<a class="headerlink" href="#requests-more-resources" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you still have problems building your documentation,
we can increase build limits on a per-project basis,
sending an email to <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>org</a> providing a good reason why your documentation needs more resources.</p>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
</div>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-reference/features"></span><section id="feature-reference">
<h2>Feature reference<a class="headerlink" href="#feature-reference" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h2>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-custom-domains"><span class="doc">Custom domains</span></a></dt><dd><p>Documentation projects can use their own domain name.
A project may define multiple domains,
as well as define the <em>canonical domain</em> where all other domains will redirect.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">Versioned documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>We support multiple versions and translations,
integrated nicely into the URL of your documentation.
This is served at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/</span></code> by default.
If you only have 1 version and translation,
we also support <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-single-version"><span class="doc">single version projects</span></a> served at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">Preview documentation from pull requests</span></a></dt><dd><p>Your project can be configured to build and host documentation for every new pull request.
Previewing changes during review makes it easier to catch formatting and display issues.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-build-notifications"><span class="doc">Build Notifications and Webhooks</span></a></dt><dd><p>Build notifications can alert you when your builds fail so you can take immediate action.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/analytics"><span class="doc">Analytics for search and traffic</span></a></dt><dd><p>Traffic and Search analytics are built into the platform.
This allows you to easily see what the most popular pages are,
and what people are searching for.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-user-defined-redirects"><span class="doc">Custom and built-in redirects on Read the Docs</span></a></dt><dd><p>Projects may define their own custom URL redirects,
with advanced functionality like folder redirects.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/sharing"><span class="doc">Private documentation sharing</span></a></dt><dd><p>It is possible to host private and password protected documentation on Read the Docs for Business.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/cdn"><span class="doc">Content Delivery Network (CDN) and caching</span></a></dt><dd><p>Documentation projects are primarily static HTML pages along with media files.
This allows us to cache them with our CDN,
making them <em>load faster</em> for your users.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/sitemaps"><span class="doc">sitemap.xml support</span></a></dt><dd><p>Sitemaps are generated and hosted automatically,
improving search engine optimization.
This helps your users find content more effectively on your site.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/404-not-found"><span class="doc">404 Not Found pages</span></a></dt><dd><p>A 404 page is served when we can‚Äôt find a page on your site.
We provide a default 404 page,
but you can also customize it.</p>
</dd>
<dt>‚è©Ô∏è <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/robots"><span class="doc">robots.txt support</span></a></dt><dd><p><code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> files allow you to customize how your documentation is indexed in search engines.
We provide a default robots.txt file,
but you can also customize it.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-custom-domains"></span><section id="custom-domains">
<h3>Custom domains<a class="headerlink" href="#custom-domains" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>You can serve your documentation project from your own domain,
for instance <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code>.
This is great for maintaining a consistent brand for your product and its documentation.</p>
<p class="rubric" id="default-subdomain">Default subdomains</p>
<p><em>By default</em>, your documentation is served from a Read the Docs <em>subdomain</em> using the project‚Äôs <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-slug"><span class="xref std std-term">slug</span></a>:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;slug&gt;.readthedocs.io</span></code> for Read the Docs Community</p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;slug&gt;.readthedocs-hosted.com</span></code> for Read the Docs for Business.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">How to manage custom domains</span></a></dt><dd><p>Information on creating and managing custom domains,
and common configurations you might use to set up your domain</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="how-custom-domains-work">
<h4>How custom domains work<a class="headerlink" href="#how-custom-domains-work" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>To use a custom domain, two actions are needed from you:</p>
<ol class="arabic simple">
<li><p>Enter the domain in your Read the Docs project‚Äôs <span class="guilabel">Admin</span></p></li>
<li><p>Update your DNS provider with a new DNS entry. The name and value of the DNS entry is found in Read the Docs‚Äô <span class="guilabel">Admin</span>.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Once the new DNS record has propagated,
Read the Docs automatically issues an SSL certificate through Cloudflare and starts serving your documentation.</p>
<img alt="Diagram of the process of adding a custom domain on Read the Docs" src="_images/mermaid-custom-domains.png" />
<p>Your documentation can have multiple secondary domains but only one <strong>canonical</strong> domain name.
Additional domains or subdomains will redirect to the canonical domain.</p>
<p>To make this work, Read the Docs generates a special text that you are responsible for copy-pasting to your domain‚Äôs DNS.
In most cases, the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">CNAME</span></code> record is used.
This is all that‚Äôs needed for a web browser to resolve your domain name to Read the Docs‚Äô servers and for our servers to match the right documentation project.
You can find step-by-step instructions for this in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/custom-domains"><span class="doc">How to manage custom domains</span></a>.</p>
<p>Read the Docs uses a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-reference/cdn"><span class="doc">Content Delivery Network (CDN) and caching</span></a> to host and serve your documentation pages.
This final step isn‚Äôt changed by a custom domain
and therefore the response times are unaffected as the delivery of resources happens through the same CDN setup.</p>
</section>
<section id="considerations-for-custom-domain-usage">
<h4>Considerations for custom domain usage<a class="headerlink" href="#considerations-for-custom-domain-usage" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Some open source projects have seen their domains expire.
Even prominent ones.
<strong>It‚Äôs important that you give the responsibility for managing your domain to someone reliable in your organization.</strong></p>
<p>The <strong>canonical domain</strong> feature allows you to have several domains and the canonical domain will be indexed by search engines.
The domain that you choose as your canonical domain is by far the most important one.
If you lose the canonical domain,
someone else can set up a website that search results will end up referring to.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p>In a URL, both the domain and the path (<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://&lt;domain&gt;/&lt;path&gt;</span></code>) are important.
In combination, they are referred to as the <em>canonical URL</em> of a resource.</p>
<p>Most documentation projects are versioned.
Therefore, it‚Äôs important to ensure that incoming links and search engine results point to the canonical URL of the resource
and not a specific version that becomes outdated.</p>
<p>To learn more about canonical URLs, see: <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-canonical-urls"><span class="doc">Canonical URLs</span></a></p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-versions"></span><section id="versioned-documentation">
<h3>Versioned documentation<a class="headerlink" href="#versioned-documentation" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs supports multiple versions of your repository.
On initial import,
we will create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version.
This will point at the default branch defined in your VCS control
(by default, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code> on Git and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">default</span></code> in Mercurial).</p>
<p>If your project has any tags or branches with a name following <a class="reference external" href="https://semver.org/">semantic versioning</a>,
we also create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version, tracking your most recent release.
If you want a custom <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version,
create either a tag or branch in your project with that name.</p>
<p>When you have <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-integrations"><span class="doc">Continuous Documentation Deployment</span></a> configured for your repository,
we will automatically build each version when you push a commit.</p>
<section id="how-we-envision-versions-working">
<h4>How we envision versions working<a class="headerlink" href="#how-we-envision-versions-working" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>In the normal case,
the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version will always point to the most up to date development code.
If you develop on a branch that is different than the default for your VCS,
you should set the <strong>Default Branch</strong> to that branch.</p>
<p>You should push a <strong>tag</strong> for each version of your project.
These tags should be numbered in a way that is consistent with semantic versioning.
This will map to your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> branch by default.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>We in fact are parsing your tag names against the rules given by
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/">PEP 440</a>. This spec allows ‚Äúnormal‚Äù version numbers like <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">1.4.2</span></code> as
well as pre-releases. An alpha version or a release candidate are examples
of pre-releases and they look like this: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0a1</span></code>.</p>
<p>We only consider non pre-releases for the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">stable</span></code> version of your
documentation.</p>
</div>
<p>If you have documentation changes on a <strong>long-lived branch</strong>,
you can build those too.
This will allow you to see how the new docs will be built in this branch of the code.
Generally you won‚Äôt have more than 1 active branch over a long period of time.
The main exception here would be <strong>release branches</strong>,
which are branches that are maintained over time for a specific release number.</p>
</section>
<section id="version-states">
<h4>Version states<a class="headerlink" href="#version-states" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>States define the visibility of a version across the site.
You can change the states of a version from the <span class="guilabel">Versions</span> tab of your project.</p>
<section id="active">
<h5>Active<a class="headerlink" href="#active" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>Active</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><p>Docs for this version are visible</p></li>
<li><p>Builds can be triggered for this version</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p><strong>Inactive</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><p>Docs for this version aren‚Äôt visible</p></li>
<li><p>Builds can‚Äôt be triggered for this version</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>When you deactivate a version, its docs are removed.</p>
</section>
<section id="hidden">
<h5>Hidden<a class="headerlink" href="#hidden" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>Not hidden and Active</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><p>This version is listed on the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a> on the docs site</p></li>
<li><p>This version is shown in search results on the docs site</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p><strong>Hidden and Active</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><p>This version isn‚Äôt listed on the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a> on the docs site</p></li>
<li><p>This version isn‚Äôt shown in search results from another version on the docs site
(like on search results from a superproject)</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Hiding a version doesn‚Äôt make it private,
any user with a link to its docs would be able to see it.
This is useful when:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>You no longer support a version, but you don‚Äôt want to remove its docs.</p></li>
<li><p>You have a work in progress version and don‚Äôt want to publish its docs just yet.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Active versions that are hidden will be listed as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Disallow:</span> <span class="pre">/path/to/version/</span></code>
in the default <a class="reference external" href="https://www.robotstxt.org/">robots.txt file</a> created by Read the Docs.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<section id="privacy-levels">
<h4>Privacy levels<a class="headerlink" href="#privacy-levels" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Privacy levels are only supported on <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">About Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<section id="public">
<h5>Public<a class="headerlink" href="#public" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>It means that everything is available to be seen by everyone.</p>
</section>
<section id="private">
<h5>Private<a class="headerlink" href="#private" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Private versions are available only to people who have permissions to see them.
They will not display on any list view, and will 404 when you link them to others.
If you want to share your docs temporarily, see <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/sharing"><span class="doc">Private documentation sharing</span></a>.</p>
<p>In addition, if you want other users to view the build page of your public versions,
you‚Äôll need to the set the <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/privacy-level"><span class="doc">privacy level of your project</span></a> to public.</p>
<section id="logging-out">
<h6>Logging out<a class="headerlink" href="#logging-out" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>When you log in to a documentation site, you will be logged in until close your browser.
To log out, click on the <span class="guilabel">Log out</span> link in your documentation‚Äôs <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-flyout-menu"><span class="xref std std-term">flyout menu</span></a>.
This is usually located in the bottom right or bottom left, depending on the theme design.
This will log you out from the current domain,
but not end any other session that you have active.</p>
<figure class="align-center">
<img alt="_images/logout-button.png" src="_images/logout-button.png" />
</figure>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<section id="tags-and-branches">
<h4>Tags and branches<a class="headerlink" href="#tags-and-branches" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs supports two workflows for versioning: based on tags or branches.
If you have at least one tag,
tags will take preference over branches when selecting the stable version.</p>
<section id="version-control-support-matrix">
<h5>Version Control Support Matrix<a class="headerlink" href="#version-control-support-matrix" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>

</section>
<section id="version-warning">
<h4>Version warning<a class="headerlink" href="#version-warning" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>This is a banner that appears on the top of every page of your docs that aren‚Äôt stable or latest.
This banner has a text with a link redirecting the users to the latest version of your docs.</p>
<p>This feature is disabled by default on new projects,
you can enable it in the admin section of your docs (<span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Advanced Settings</span>).</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The banner will be injected in an HTML element with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code> role or in the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">main</span></code> tag.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-html notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">div</span> <span class="na">role</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">&quot;main&quot;</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
  <span class="cm">&lt;!-- The banner would be injected here --&gt;</span>
  ...
<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="highlight-html notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">&lt;</span><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
  <span class="cm">&lt;!-- The banner would be injected here --&gt;</span>
  ...
<span class="p">&lt;/</span><span class="nt">main</span><span class="p">&gt;</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
<section id="redirects-on-root-urls">
<h4>Redirects on root URLs<a class="headerlink" href="#redirects-on-root-urls" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When a user hits the root URL for your documentation,
for example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://pip.readthedocs.io/</span></code>,
they will be redirected to the <strong>Default version</strong>.
This defaults to <strong>latest</strong>,
but could also point to your latest released version.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-pull-requests"></span><section id="preview-documentation-from-pull-requests">
<h3>Preview documentation from pull requests<a class="headerlink" href="#preview-documentation-from-pull-requests" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Your project can be configured to build and host documentation for every new
pull request. Previewing changes during review makes it
easier to catch formatting and display issues before they go live.</p>
<section id="features">
<h4>Features<a class="headerlink" href="#features" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<dl>
<dt>Build on pull request events</dt><dd><p>We create and build a new version when a pull request is opened,
and rebuild the version whenever a new commit is pushed.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Build status report</dt><dd><p>Your project‚Äôs pull request build status will show as one of your pull
request‚Äôs checks. This status will update as the build is running, and will
show a success or failure status when the build completes.</p>
<figure class="align-center" id="id1" style="width: 80%">
<img alt="GitHub build status reporting for pull requests." src="_images/github-build-status-reporting.gif" />
<figcaption>
<p><span class="caption-text">GitHub build status reporting</span><a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this image">ÔÉÅ</a></p>
</figcaption>
</figure>
</dd>
<dt>Warning banner</dt><dd><p>A warning banner is shown at the top of documentation pages
to let readers know that this version isn‚Äôt the main version for the project.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Warning banners are available only for <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-intro/getting-started-with-sphinx"><span class="doc">Sphinx projects</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/pull-requests"><span class="doc">How to configure pull request builds</span></a></dt><dd><p>A guide to configuring pull request builds on Read the Docs.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-build-notifications"></span><section id="build-notifications-and-webhooks">
<h3>Build Notifications and Webhooks<a class="headerlink" href="#build-notifications-and-webhooks" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs features a number of build notification mechanisms.
Build notifications can alert you when your builds fail so you can take immediate action.</p>
<dl>
<dt>Email notifications:</dt><dd><p>Read the Docs allows you to configure emails that can be sent on failing builds.
This makes sure you know when your builds have failed.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Build Status Webhooks:</dt><dd><p>Build notifications can happen via <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-webhook"><span class="xref std std-term">webhooks</span></a>.
This means that we are able to support a wide variety of services that receive notifications.</p>
<p>Slack and Discord are supported through ready-made templates.</p>
<p>Webhooks can be customized through your own template and a variety of variable substitutions.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/build-notifications"><span class="doc">How to setup build notifications and webhooks</span></a></dt><dd><p>All the practical steps for setting up build notifications</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-pull-requests"><span class="doc">Preview documentation from pull requests</span></a></dt><dd><p>Similarly to build notifications, you can also configure automated feedback for your pull requests.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-user-defined-redirects"></span><section id="custom-and-built-in-redirects-on-read-the-docs">
<h3>Custom and built-in redirects on Read the Docs<a class="headerlink" href="#custom-and-built-in-redirects-on-read-the-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Over time, a documentation project may want to rename and move contents around.
Redirects allow changes in a documentation project to happen without bad user experiences.</p>
<p>If you do not manage URL structures,
users will eventually encounter 404 File Not Found errors.
While this may be acceptable in some cases,
the bad user experience of a 404 page is usually best to avoid.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="#built-in-redirects">Built-in redirects</a> ‚¨áÔ∏è</dt><dd><p>Allows for simple and long-term sharing of external references to your documentation.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="#user-defined-redirects">User-defined redirects</a> ‚¨áÔ∏è</dt><dd><p>Makes it easier to move contents around</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/redirects"><span class="doc">How to use custom URL redirects in documentation projects</span></a></dt><dd><p>This guide shows you how to add redirects with practical examples.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/best-practice/links"><span class="doc">Best practices for linking to your documentation</span></a></dt><dd><p>Information and tips about creating and handling external references.</p>
</dd>
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/deprecating-content"><span class="doc">How to deprecate content</span></a></dt><dd><p>A guide to deprecating features and other topics in a documentation.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="special-features">
<h4>Special features<a class="headerlink" href="#special-features" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>By default, redirects are followed only if the requested page doesn‚Äôt exist
(<em>404 File Not Found</em> error).
If you need to apply a redirect for files that exist,
<strong>This option is only available on some plan levels</strong>.
Please ask support if you need it for some reason.</p></li>
<li><p><a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#id2"><span class="std std-ref">Page redirects</span></a> and <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#exact-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Exact redirects</span></a>
can redirect to URLs outside Read the Docs,
just include the protocol in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">To</span> <span class="pre">URL</span></code>, e.g <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://example.com</span></code>.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="built-in-redirects">
<h4>Built-in redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#built-in-redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>This section explains the redirects that are automatically active for all projects and how they are useful.
Built-in redirects are especially useful for creating and sharing incoming links,
which is discussed indepth in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/best-practice/links"><span class="doc">Best practices for linking to your documentation</span></a>.</p>
<section id="page-redirects-at-page">
<span id="page-redirects"></span><h5>Page redirects at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/page/</span></code><a class="headerlink" href="#page-redirects-at-page" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>You can link to a specific page and have it redirect to your default version,
allowing you to create links on external sources that are always up to date.
This is done with the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/page/</span></code> URL prefix.</p>
<p>For instance, you can reach the page you are reading now by going to <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/page/guides/best-practice/links.html">https://docs.readthedocs.io/page/guides/best-practice/links.html</a>.</p>
<p>Another way to handle this is the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version.
You can set your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> version to a specific version and just always link to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code>.
You can reach this page by going to <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/best-practice/links.html">https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guides/best-practice/links.html</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="root-url-redirect-at">
<span id="root-url-redirect"></span><h5>Root URL redirect at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code><a class="headerlink" href="#root-url-redirect-at" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>A link to the root of your documentation (<code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;slug&gt;.readthedocs.io/</span></code>) will redirect to the  <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-default-version"><span class="xref std std-term">default version</span></a>,
as set in your project settings.</p>
<p>This works for both readthedocs.io (Read the Docs Community), readthedocs-hosted.com (Read the Docs for Business), and <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-custom-domains"><span class="doc">custom domains</span></a>.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">readthedocs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">io</span> <span class="o">-&gt;</span> <span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">readthedocs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">io</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">stable</span><span class="o">/</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>You cannot use the root redirect to reference specific pages.
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code> <em>only</em> redirects to the default version,
whereas <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/some/page.html</span></code> will <em>not</em> redirect to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/some/page.html</span></code>.
Instead, use <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#page-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Page redirects at /page/</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<p>You can choose which is the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-default-version"><span class="xref std std-term">default version</span></a> for Read the Docs to display.
This usually corresponds to the most recent official release from your project.</p>
</section>
<section id="shortlink-with-https-slug-rtfd-io">
<h5>Shortlink with <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://&lt;slug&gt;.rtfd.io</span></code><a class="headerlink" href="#shortlink-with-https-slug-rtfd-io" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Links to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">rtfd.io</span></code> are treated the same way as <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">readthedocs.io</span></code>.
They are intended to be easy and short for people to type.</p>
<p>You can reach these docs at <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.rtfd.io">https://docs.rtfd.io</a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="user-defined-redirects">
<span id="id1"></span><h4>User-defined redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#user-defined-redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="prefix-redirects">
<h5>Prefix redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#prefix-redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>The most useful and requested feature of redirects was when migrating to Read the Docs from an old host.
You would have your docs served at a previous URL,
but that URL would break once you moved them.
Read the Docs includes a language and version slug in your documentation,
but not all documentation is hosted this way.</p>
<p>Say that you previously had your docs hosted at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.example.com/dev/</span></code>,
you move <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code> to point at Read the Docs.
So users will have a bookmark saved to a page at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.example.com/dev/install.html</span></code>.</p>
<p>You can now set a <em>Prefix Redirect</em> that will redirect all 404‚Äôs with a prefix to a new place.
The example configuration would be:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Type</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">Prefix</span> <span class="n">Redirect</span>
<span class="n">From</span> <span class="n">URL</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Your users query would now redirect in the following manner:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span> <span class="o">-&gt;</span>
<span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">latest</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Where <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">en</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> are the default language and version values for your project.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>If you were hosting your docs without a prefix, you can create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code> Prefix Redirect,
which will prepend <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/$lang/$version/</span></code> to all incoming URLs.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="id2">
<h5>Page redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#id2" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>A more specific case is when you move a page around in your docs.
The old page will start 404‚Äôing,
and your users will be confused.
<em>Page Redirects</em> let you redirect a specific page.</p>
<p>Say you move the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">example.html</span></code> page into a subdirectory of examples: <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">examples/intro.html</span></code>.
You would set the following configuration:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Type</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">Page</span> <span class="n">Redirect</span>
<span class="n">From</span> <span class="n">URL</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
<span class="n">To</span> <span class="n">URL</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">examples</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">intro</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p><strong>Page Redirects apply to all versions of you documentation.</strong>
Because of this,
the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code> at the start of the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">From</span> <span class="pre">URL</span></code> doesn‚Äôt include the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/$lang/$version</span></code> prefix (e.g.
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest</span></code>), but just the version-specific part of the URL.
If you want to set redirects only for some languages or some versions, you should use
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#exact-redirects"><span class="std std-ref">Exact redirects</span></a> with the fully-specified path.</p>
</section>
<section id="exact-redirects">
<h5>Exact redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#exact-redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p><em>Exact Redirects</em> are for redirecting a single URL,
taking into account the full URL (including language and version).</p>
<p>You can also redirect a subset of URLs by including the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">$rest</span></code> keyword
at the end of the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">From</span> <span class="pre">URL</span></code>.</p>
<section id="exact-redirects-examples">
<h6>Exact redirects examples<a class="headerlink" href="#exact-redirects-examples" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<section id="redirecting-a-single-url">
<h6 aria-level="7">Redirecting a single URL<a class="headerlink" href="#redirecting-a-single-url" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>Say you‚Äôre moving <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">docs.example.com</span></code> to Read the Docs and want to redirect traffic
from an old page at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.example.com/dev/install.html</span></code> to a new URL
of <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.example.com/en/latest/installing-your-site.html</span></code>.</p>
<p>The example configuration would be:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">Type</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">Exact</span> <span class="n">Redirect</span>
<span class="n">From</span> <span class="n">URL</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
<span class="n">To</span> <span class="n">URL</span><span class="p">:</span>   <span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">latest</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">installing</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">your</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">site</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Your users query would now redirect in the following manner:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span> <span class="o">-&gt;</span>
<span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">latest</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">installing</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">your</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">site</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Note that you should insert the desired language for ‚Äúen‚Äù and version for ‚Äúlatest‚Äù to
achieve the desired redirect.</p>
</section>
<section id="redirecting-a-whole-sub-path-to-a-different-one">
<h6 aria-level="7">Redirecting a whole sub-path to a different one<a class="headerlink" href="#redirecting-a-whole-sub-path-to-a-different-one" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p><em>Exact Redirects</em> could be also useful to redirect a whole sub-path to a different one by using a special <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">$rest</span></code> keyword in the ‚ÄúFrom URL‚Äù.
Let‚Äôs say that you want to redirect your readers of your version <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">2.0</span></code> of your documentation under <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/2.0/</span></code> because it‚Äôs deprecated,
to the newest <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">3.0</span></code> version of it at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/3.0/</span></code>.</p>
<p>This example would be:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>Type: Exact Redirect
From URL: /en/2.0/$rest
To URL: /en/3.0/
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>The readers of your documentation will now be redirected as:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mf">2.0</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span> <span class="o">-&gt;</span>
<span class="n">docs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">com</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">en</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mf">3.0</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">dev</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">install</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">html</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Similarly, if you maintain several branches of your documentation (e.g. <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">3.0</span></code> and
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code>) and decide to move pages in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">latest</span></code> but not the older branches, you can use
<em>Exact Redirects</em> to do so.</p>
</section>
<section id="migrating-your-documentation-to-another-domain">
<h6 aria-level="7">Migrating your documentation to another domain<a class="headerlink" href="#migrating-your-documentation-to-another-domain" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>You can use an exact redirect to migrate your documentation to another domain,
for example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span>Type: Exact Redirect
From URL: /$rest
To URL: https://newdocs.example.com/
Force Redirect: True
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Then all pages will redirect to the new domain, for example
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.example.com/en/latest/install.html</span></code> will redirect to
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://newdocs.example.com/en/latest/install.html</span></code>.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<section id="sphinx-redirects">
<h5>Sphinx redirects<a class="headerlink" href="#sphinx-redirects" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We also support redirects for changing the type of documentation Sphinx is building.
If you switch between <em>HTMLDir</em> and <em>HTML</em>, your URLs will change.
A page at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/install.html</span></code> will be served at <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/en/latest/install/</span></code>,
or vice versa.
The built in redirects for this will handle redirecting users appropriately.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-reference/analytics"></span><section id="analytics-for-search-and-traffic">
<h3>Analytics for search and traffic<a class="headerlink" href="#analytics-for-search-and-traffic" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs supports analytics for search and traffic.
When someone reads your documentation,
we collect data about the vist and the referer
with full respect of the privacy of the visitor.</p>
<section id="traffic-analytics">
<h4>Traffic analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#traffic-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs aggregates statistics about visits to your documentation.
This is mainly information about how often pages are viewed,
and which return a <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404</span> <span class="pre">Not</span> <span class="pre">Found</span></code> error code.</p>
<p>Traffic Analytics lets you see <em>which</em> documents your users are reading.
This allows you to understand how your documentation is being used,
so you can focus on expanding and updating parts people are reading most.</p>
<p>If you require more detailed analytics, Read the Docs has native support for Google Analytics.
It‚Äôs also possible to customize your documentation to include other analytics frameworks.</p>
<p>Learn more in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-analytics"><span class="doc">How to use traffic analytics</span></a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="search-analytics">
<h4>Search analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#search-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When someone visits your documentation and uses the built-in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-server-side-search/index"><span class="doc">server side search</span></a> feature,
Read the Docs will collect analytics on their search term.</p>
<p>Those are aggregated into a simple view of the
‚ÄúTop queries in the past 30 days‚Äù.
You can also download this data.</p>
<p>This is helpful to optimize your documentation in alignment with your readers‚Äô interests.
You can discover new trends and expand your documentation to new needs.</p>
<p>Learn more in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/search-analytics"><span class="doc">How to use search analytics</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-commercial/sharing"></span><section id="private-documentation-sharing">
<h3>Private documentation sharing<a class="headerlink" href="#private-documentation-sharing" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>You can share your project with users outside of your company:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>by sending them a <em>secret link</em>,</p></li>
<li><p>by giving them a <em>password</em>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>These methods will allow them to view specific projects or versions of a project inside your organization.</p>
<p>Additionally, you can use a HTTP Authorization Header.
This is useful to have access from a script.</p>
<section id="enabling-sharing">
<h4>Enabling sharing<a class="headerlink" href="#enabling-sharing" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go into your project‚Äôs <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> page and click on <span class="guilabel">Sharing</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>Click on <span class="guilabel">New Share</span></p></li>
<li><p>Select access type (secret link, password, or HTTP header token),
add an expiration date and a <em>Description</em> so you remember who you‚Äôre sharing it with.</p></li>
<li><p>Check <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Allow</span> <span class="pre">access</span> <span class="pre">to</span> <span class="pre">all</span> <span class="pre">versions?</span></code> if you want to grant access to all versions,
or uncheck that option and select the specific versions you want grant access to.</p></li>
<li><p>Click <span class="guilabel">Save</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>Get the info needed to share your documentation with other users:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>If you have selected secret link, copy the link that is generated</p></li>
<li><p>In case of password, copy the link and password</p></li>
<li><p>For HTTP header token, you need to pass the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Authorization</span></code> header in your HTTP request.</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Give that information to the person who you want to give access.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>You can always revoke access in the same panel.</p>
</div>
<p>Users can log out by using the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#logging-out"><span class="std std-ref">Log Out</span></a> link in the RTD flyout menu.</p>
</section>
<section id="sharing-methods">
<h4>Sharing methods<a class="headerlink" href="#sharing-methods" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<section id="secret-link">
<h5>Secret link<a class="headerlink" href="#secret-link" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Once the person you send the link to clicks the link,
they will have access to the documentation while their browser window is open.</p>
<p>If you want to link to a specific page,
you can do this by passing the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">next</span></code> query parameter in the URL.
For example <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://mydocs.readthedocs-hosted.com/_/sharing/xxxxxxxxx?next=/en/latest/page.html</span></code>.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>This is useful for sharing access to an entire set of documentation for a user.
You can embed these links in an internal wiki, for example,
and all your employees will be able to browse the docs without a login.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="password">
<h5>Password<a class="headerlink" href="#password" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Once the person you send the link to clicks on the link, they will see
an <em>Authorization required</em> page asking them for the password you
generated. When the user enters the password, they will have access to
view your project.</p>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>This is useful for when you have documentation you want users to bookmark.
They can enter a URL directly and enter the password when prompted.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="http-authorization-header">
<h5>HTTP Authorization Header<a class="headerlink" href="#http-authorization-header" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<div class="admonition tip">
<p class="admonition-title">Tip</p>
<p>This approach is useful for automated scripts.
It only allows access to a page when the header is present,
so it doesn‚Äôt allow browsing docs inside of a browser.</p>
</div>
<section id="token-authorization">
<h6>Token Authorization<a class="headerlink" href="#token-authorization" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>You need to send the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Authorization</span></code> header with the token on each HTTP request.
The header has the form <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Authorization:</span> <span class="pre">Token</span> <span class="pre">&lt;ACCESS_TOKEN&gt;</span></code>.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><style type="text/css">
span.prompt1:before {
  content: "$ ";
}
</style><span class="prompt1">curl<span class="w"> </span>-H<span class="w"> </span><span class="s2">&quot;Authorization: Token 19okmz5k0i6yk17jp70jlnv91v&quot;</span><span class="w"> </span>https://docs.example.com/en/latest/example.html</span>
</pre></div></div></section>
<section id="basic-authorization">
<h6>Basic Authorization<a class="headerlink" href="#basic-authorization" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>You can also use basic authorization, with the token as user and an empty password.
For example:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span class="prompt1">curl<span class="w"> </span>--url<span class="w"> </span>https://docs.example.com/en/latest/example.html<span class="w"> </span>--user<span class="w"> </span><span class="s1">&#39;19okmz5k0i6yk17jp70jlnv91v:&#39;</span></span>
</pre></div></div></section>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-reference/cdn"></span><section id="content-delivery-network-cdn-and-caching">
<h3>Content Delivery Network (CDN) and caching<a class="headerlink" href="#content-delivery-network-cdn-and-caching" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>A CDN is used for making documentation pages <em>fast</em> for your users.
CDNs increase speed by caching documentation content in multiple data centers around the world,
and then serving docs from the data center closest to the user.</p>
<p>We support CDNs on both of our sites:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><dl class="simple">
<dt>On Read the Docs Community,</dt><dd><p>we are able to provide a CDN to all the projects that we host.
This service is graciously sponsored by <a class="reference external" href="https://www.cloudflare.com/">Cloudflare</a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</li>
<li><dl class="simple">
<dt>On Read the Docs for Business,</dt><dd><p>the CDN is included as part of our all of our plans.
We use <a class="reference external" href="https://www.cloudflare.com/">Cloudflare</a> for this as well.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<section id="cdn-benefits">
<h4>CDN benefits<a class="headerlink" href="#cdn-benefits" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Having a CDN in front of your documentation has many benefits:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>Improved reliability</strong>: Since docs are served from multiple places, one can go down and the docs are still accessible.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Improved performance</strong>: Data takes time to travel across space, so connecting to a server closer to the user makes documentation load faster.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="automatic-cache-refresh">
<h4>Automatic cache refresh<a class="headerlink" href="#automatic-cache-refresh" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>We automatically refresh the cache on the CDN when the following actions happen:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Your project is saved.</p></li>
<li><p>Your domain is saved.</p></li>
<li><p>A new version of your documentation is built.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>By refreshing the cache according to these rules,
readers should <strong>never see outdated content</strong>.
This makes the end-user experience seamless, and fast.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-reference/sitemaps"></span><section id="sitemap-xml-support">
<h3><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sitemap.xml</span></code> support<a class="headerlink" href="#sitemap-xml-support" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.sitemaps.org/">Sitemaps</a> allow you to inform search engines about URLs that are available for crawling.
This makes your content more <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-discoverability"><span class="xref std std-term">discoverable</span></a>,
and improves your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/technical-docs-seo-guide"><span class="doc">Search Engine Optimization (SEO)</span></a>.</p>
<section id="how-it-works">
<h4>How it works<a class="headerlink" href="#how-it-works" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sitemap.xml</span></code> file is read by search engines in order to index your documentation.
It contains information such as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>When a URL was last updated.</p></li>
<li><p>How often that URL changes.</p></li>
<li><p>How important this URL is in relation to other URLs in the site.</p></li>
<li><p>What translations are available for a page.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Read the Docs automatically generates a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sitemap.xml</span></code> for your project,</p>
<p>By default the sitemap includes:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Each version of your documentation and when it was last updated, sorted by version number.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>This allows search engines to prioritize results based on the version number,
sorted by <a class="reference external" href="https://semver.org/">semantic versioning</a>.</p>
</section>
<section id="custom-sitemap-xml">
<h4>Custom <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">sitemap.xml</span></code><a class="headerlink" href="#custom-sitemap-xml" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you need a custom sitemap,
please let us know by contacting <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-support"><span class="doc">Site support</span></a>.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-reference/404-not-found"></span><section id="not-found-pages">
<h3><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404</span> <span class="pre">Not</span> <span class="pre">Found</span></code> pages<a class="headerlink" href="#not-found-pages" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>If you want your project to use a custom or branded <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404</span> <span class="pre">Not</span> <span class="pre">Found</span></code> page,
you can put a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code> at the top level of your project‚Äôs HTML output.</p>
<section id="how-it-works">
<h4>How it works<a class="headerlink" href="#how-it-works" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>When our servers return a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404</span> <span class="pre">Not</span> <span class="pre">Found</span></code> error,
we check if there is a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code> in the root of your project‚Äôs output.</p>
<p>The following locations are checked, in order:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/404.html</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code> in the <em>current</em> documentation version.</p></li>
<li><p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/404.html</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code> in the  <em>default</em> documentation version.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="tool-integration">
<h4>Tool integration<a class="headerlink" href="#tool-integration" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Documentation tools will have different ways of generating a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> or <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code> file.
We have examples for some of the most popular tools below.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">Sphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MkDocs</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>We recommend the <a class="reference external" href="https://pypi.org/project/sphinx-notfound-page">sphinx-notfound-page</a> extension,
which Read the Docs maintains.
It automatically creates a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> page for your documentation,
matching the theme of your project.
See its <a class="reference external" href="https://sphinx-notfound-page.readthedocs.io/">documentation</a> for how to install and customize it.</p>
<p>If you want to create a custom <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code>,
Sphinx uses <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-html_extra_path">html_extra_path</a> option to add static files to the output.
You need to create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> file and put it under the path defined in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_extra_path</span></code>.</p>
<p>If you are using the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">DirHTML</span></code> builder,
no further steps are required.
Sphinx will automatically apply the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">&lt;page-name&gt;/index.html</span></code> folder structure to your 404 page:
<code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404/index.html</span></code>.
Read the Docs also detects 404 pages named this way.</p>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>MkDocs automatically generates a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">404.html</span></code> which Read the Docs will use.
However, assets will not be loaded correctly unless you define the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#site_url">site_url</a> configuration value as your site‚Äôs
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#mkdocs"><span class="std std-ref">canonical base URL</span></a>.</p>
</div></div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-reference/robots"></span><section id="robots-txt-support">
<h3><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> support<a class="headerlink" href="#robots-txt-support" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>The <a class="reference external" href="https://developers.google.com/search/reference/robots_txt">robots.txt</a> files allow you to customize how your documentation is indexed in search engines.
It‚Äôs useful for:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Hiding various pages from search engines</p></li>
<li><p>Disabling certain web crawlers from accessing your documentation</p></li>
<li><p>Disallowing any indexing of your documentation</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Read the Docs automatically generates one for you with a configuration that works for most projects.
By default, the automatically created <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code>:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Hides versions which are set to <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#hidden"><span class="std std-ref">Hidden</span></a> from being indexed.</p></li>
<li><p>Allows indexing of all other versions.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p><code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> files are respected by most search engines,
but they aren‚Äôt a guarantee that your pages will not be indexed.
Search engines may choose to ignore your <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file,
and index your docs anyway.</p>
<p>If you require <em>private</em> documentation, please see <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/sharing"><span class="doc">Private documentation sharing</span></a>.</p>
</div>
<section id="how-it-works">
<h4>How it works<a class="headerlink" href="#how-it-works" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can customize this file to add more rules to it.
The <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file will be served from the <strong>default version</strong> of your project.
This is because the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file is served at the top-level of your domain,
so we must choose a version to find the file in.
The <strong>default version</strong> is the best place to look for it.</p>
</section>
<section id="tool-integration">
<h4>Tool integration<a class="headerlink" href="#tool-integration" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Documentation tools will have different ways of generating a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file.
We have examples for some of the most popular tools below.</p>
<div class="sphinx-tabs docutils container">
<div aria-label="Tabbed content" class="closeable" role="tablist"><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-0" aria-selected="true" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tab" tabindex="0">Sphinx</button><button aria-controls="panel-0-0-1" aria-selected="false" class="sphinx-tabs-tab" id="tab-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tab" tabindex="-1">MkDocs</button></div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-0" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" id="panel-0-0-0" name="0-0" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>Sphinx uses the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/configuration.html#confval-html_extra_path">html_extra_path</a> configuration value to add static files to its final HTML output.
You need to create a <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> file and put it under the path defined in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">html_extra_path</span></code>.</p>
</div><div aria-labelledby="tab-0-0-1" class="sphinx-tabs-panel" hidden="true" id="panel-0-0-1" name="0-1" role="tabpanel" tabindex="0"><p>MkDocs needs the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">robots.txt</span></code> to be at the directory defined by the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/configuration/#docs_dir">docs_dir</a> configuration value.</p>
</div></div>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<p><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/technical-docs-seo-guide"><span class="doc">How to do Search Engine Optimization (SEO) for documentation projects</span></a></p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
</div>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-commercial/organizations"></span><section id="organizations-permissions-for-projects-and-teams">
<h3>Organizations: permissions for projects and teams<a class="headerlink" href="#organizations-permissions-for-projects-and-teams" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>In this article, we explain how the <em>organizations</em> feature on Read the Docs allows you to manage access to your projects.
On Read the Docs for Business, your account is linked to an <em>organization</em>.
Organizations allow you to define both individual and team permissions for your projects.</p>
<p>In this article, we use ACME Corporation as our example organization.
ACME has a few people inside their organization,
some who need full access and some who just need access to one project.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/manage-read-the-docs-teams"><span class="doc">How to manage Read the Docs teams</span></a></dt><dd><p>A step-by-step guide to managing teams.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="member-types">
<h4>Member types<a class="headerlink" href="#member-types" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>Owners</strong> ‚Äì Get full access to both view and edit the Organization and all Projects</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Members</strong> ‚Äì Get access to a subset of the Organization projects</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Teams</strong> ‚Äì Where you give members access to a set of projects.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>The best way to think about this relationship is:</p>
<p><em>Owners</em> will create <em>Teams</em> to assign permissions to all <em>Members</em>.</p>
<div class="admonition warning">
<p class="admonition-title">Warning</p>
<p>Owners, Members and Teams behave differently if you are using
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#sso-git-provider"><span class="std std-ref">Single Sign-on with GitHub, Bitbucket, or GitLab</span></a>.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="team-types">
<h4>Team types<a class="headerlink" href="#team-types" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>You can create two types of Teams:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>Admins</strong> ‚Äì These teams have full access to administer the projects in the team. They are allowed to change all of the settings, set notifications, and perform any action under the <strong>Admin</strong> tab.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Read Only</strong> ‚Äì These teams are only able to read and search inside the documents.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="example">
<h4>Example<a class="headerlink" href="#example" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>ACME would set up <em>Owners</em> of their organization,
for example Frank Roadrunner would be an owner.
He has full access to the organization and all projects.</p>
<p>Wile E. Coyote is a contractor,
and will just have access to the new project Road Builder.</p>
<p>Roadrunner would set up a <em>Team</em> called <em>Contractors</em>.
That team would have <em>Read Only</em> access to the <em>Road Builder</em> project.
Then he would add <em>Wile E. Coyote</em> to the team.
This would give him access to just this one project inside the organization.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-commercial/privacy-level"></span><section id="project-privacy-level">
<h3>Project privacy level<a class="headerlink" href="#project-privacy-level" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>This feature is only available on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/">Read the Docs for Business</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>By default, only users that belong to your organization can see the dashboard of your project and its builds.
If you want users outside your organization and anonymous users to be able to see the dashboard of your project,
and the build output of <em>public versions</em> you can set the privacy level of your project to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Public</span></code>.</p>
<p>You can administer this in your <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#term-dashboard"><span class="xref std std-term">dashboard</span></a> by navigating to <span class="menuselection">Admin ‚Ä£ Advanced Settings</span>
and changing <span class="guilabel">Privacy level</span> to <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">Public</span></code>.</p>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
