<span id="document-dmca/index"></span><section id="dmca-takedown-policy">
<h4>DMCA takedown policy<a class="headerlink" href="#dmca-takedown-policy" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>These are the guidelines that Read the Docs follows when handling DMCA takedown
requests and takedown counter requests. If you are a copyright holder wishing to
submit a takedown request, or an author that has been notified of a takedown
request, please familiarize yourself with <a class="reference internal" href="#takedown-process">our process</a>.
You will be asked to confirm that you have reviewed information if you submit a
request or counter request.</p>
<p>We aim to keep this entire process as transparent as possible. Our process is
modeled after <a class="reference external" href="https://help.github.com/articles/dmca-takedown-policy/">GitHub‚Äôs DMCA takedown process</a>, which we
appreciate for its focus on transparency and fairness. All requests and counter
requests will be posted to this page below, in the <a class="reference internal" href="#request-archive">Request Archive</a>. These
requests will be redacted to remove all identifying information, except for Read
the Docs user and project names.</p>
<section id="takedown-process">
<h5>Takedown process<a class="headerlink" href="#takedown-process" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Here are the steps the Read the Docs will follow in the takedown request process:</p>
<dl>
<dt>Copyright holder submits a request</dt><dd><p>This request, if valid, will be posted publicly on this page, <a class="reference internal" href="#request-archive">down below</a>.
The author affected by the takedown request will be
notified with a link to the takedown request.</p>
<p>For more information on submitting a takedown request, see: <a class="reference internal" href="#submitting-a-request">Submitting a
Request</a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dt>Author is contacted</dt><dd><p>The author of the content in question will be asked to make changes to the
content specified in the takedown request. The author will have 24 hours to
make these changes. The copyright holder will be notified if and when this
process begins</p>
</dd>
<dt>Author acknowledges changes have been made</dt><dd><p>The author must notify Read the Docs that changes have been made within 24
hours of receiving a takedown request. If the author does not respond to this
request, the default action will be to disable the Read the Docs project and
remove any hosted versions</p>
</dd>
<dt>Copyright holder review</dt><dd><p>If the author has made changes, the copyright holder will be notified of
these changes. If the changes are sufficient, no further action is required,
though copyright holders are welcome to submit a formal retraction. If the
changes are not sufficient, the author‚Äôs changes can be rejected. If the
takedown request requires alteration, a new request must be submitted.  If
Read the Docs does not receive a review response from the copyright holder
within 2 weeks, the default action at this step is to assume the takedown
request has been retracted.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Content may be disabled</dt><dd><p>If the author does not respond to a request for changes, or if the copyright
holder has rejected the author‚Äôs changes during the review process, the
documentation project in question will be disabled.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Author submits a counter request</dt><dd><p>If the author believes their content was disabled as a result of a mistake,
a counter request may be submitted. It would be advised that authors seek
legal council before continuing. If the submitted counter request is
sufficiently detailed, this counter will also be added to <a class="reference internal" href="#request-archive">this page</a>.
The copyright holder will be notified, with a link to
this counter request.</p>
<p>For more information on submitting a counter request, see: <a class="reference internal" href="#submitting-a-counter">Submitting a
Counter</a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Copyright holder may file legal action</dt><dd><p>At this point, if the copyright holder wishes to keep the offending content
disabled, the copyright holder must file for legal action ordering the
author refrain from infringing activities on Read the Docs. The copyright
holder will have 2 weeks to supply Read the Docs with a copy of a valid legal
complaint against the author. The default action here, if the copyright
holder does not respond to this request, is to re-enable the author‚Äôs
project.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<section id="submitting-a-request">
<h6>Submitting a request<a class="headerlink" href="#submitting-a-request" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>Your request must:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Acknowledge this process</dt><dd><p>You must first acknowledge you are familiar with our DMCA takedown request
process. If you do not acknowledge that you are familiar with our process,
you will be instructed to review this information.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Identify the infringing content</dt><dd><p>You should list URLs to each piece of infringing content. If you allege that
the entire project is infringing on copyrights you hold, please specify the
entire project as infringing.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Identify infringement resolution</dt><dd><p>You will need to specify what a user must do in order to avoid having the
rest of their content disabled. Be as specific as possible with this.
Specify if this means adding attribution, identify specific files or content
that should be removed, or if you allege the entire project is infringing,
your should be specific as to why it is infringing.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Include your contact information</dt><dd><p>Include your name, email, physical address, and phone number.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Include your signature</dt><dd><p>This can be a physical or electronic signature.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Please complete this <a class="reference download internal" download="" href="_downloads/c568c67bebb9a716e636019c4c17efb3/takedown-template.txt"><code class="xref download docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">takedown</span> <span class="pre">request</span> <span class="pre">template</span></code></a> and send it to: <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;com">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>com</a></p>
</section>
<section id="submitting-a-counter">
<h6>Submitting a counter<a class="headerlink" href="#submitting-a-counter" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>Your counter request must:</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Acknowledge this process</dt><dd><p>You must first acknowledge you are familiar with our DMCA takedown request
process. If you do not acknowledge that you are familiar with our process,
you will be instructed to review this information.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Identify the infringing content that was removed</dt><dd><p>Specify URLs in the original takedown request that you wish to challenge.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Include your contact information</dt><dd><p>Include your name, email, physical address, and phone number.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Include your signature</dt><dd><p>This can be a physical or electronic signature.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Requests can be submitted to: <a class="reference external" href="mailto:support&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;com">support<span>&#64;</span>readthedocs<span>&#46;</span>com</a></p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="request-archive">
<h5>Request archive<a class="headerlink" href="#request-archive" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>For better transparency into copyright ownership and the DMCA takedown process,
Read the Docs maintains this archive of previous DMCA takedown requests. This is
modeled after <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/github/dmca">GitHub‚Äôs DMCA archive</a>.</p>
<p>The following DMCA takedown requests have been submitted:</p>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-dmca/archive/2022-06-07"></span><section id="id1">
<h6>2022-06-07<a class="headerlink" href="#id1" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>The project maintainer was notified about this report and instructed to
submit a counter if they believed this request was invalid. The user removed
the project manually, and no further action was required.</p>
</div>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>Are you the copyright owner or authorized to act on the copyright owner‚Äôs behalf?</dt><dd><p>Yes</p>
</dd>
<dt>What work was allegedly infringed? If possible, please provide a URL:</dt><dd><p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.dicomstandard.org/current">https://www.dicomstandard.org/current</a></p>
</dd>
<dt>What files or project should be taken down? You should list URLs to each piece of infringing content. If you allege that the entire project is infringing on copyrights you hold, please specify the entire project as infringing:</dt><dd><p><a class="reference external" href="https://dicom-standard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html">https://dicom-standard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html</a></p>
</dd>
<dt>Is the work licensed under an open source license?</dt><dd><p>No</p>
</dd>
<dt>What would be the best solution for the alleged infringement?</dt><dd><p>Complete Removal.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Do you have the alleged infringer‚Äôs contact information? Yes. If so, please provide it:</dt><dd><p>[private]</p>
</dd>
<dt>Type (or copy and paste) the following statement: ‚ÄúI have a good faith belief that use of the copyrighted materials described above on the infringing web pages is not authorized by the copyright owner, or its agent, or the law. I have taken fair use into consideration.‚Äù</dt><dd><p>I have a good faith belief that use of the copyrighted materials described above on the infringing web pages is not authorized by the copyright owner, or its agent, or the law. I have taken fair use into consideration.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Type (or copy and paste) the following statement: ‚ÄúI swear, under penalty of perjury, that the information in this notification is accurate and that I am the copyright owner, or am authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed.‚Äù</dt><dd><p>I swear, under penalty of perjury, that the information in this notification is accurate and that I am the copyright owner, or am authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Please confirm that you have read our Takedown Policy: <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dmca/index.html">https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dmca/index.html</a></dt><dd><p>Yes</p>
</dd>

<span id="document-advertising/index"></span><section id="advertising">
<h3>Advertising<a class="headerlink" href="#advertising" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Advertising is the single largest source of funding for Read the Docs.
It allows us to:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Serve over <strong>35 million pages</strong> of documentation per month</p></li>
<li><p>Serve over <strong>40 TB</strong> of documentation per month</p></li>
<li><p>Host over <strong>80,000 open source projects</strong> and support over <strong>100,000 users</strong></p></li>
<li><p>Pay a <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-team"><span class="doc">small team</span></a> of dedicated full-time staff</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Many advertising models involve tracking users around the internet,
selling their data, and privacy intrusion in general.
Instead of doing that, we built an <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-advertising/ethical-advertising"><span class="doc">Ethical Advertising</span></a> model
that respects user privacy.</p>
<p>We recognize that advertising is not for everyone.
You may <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#opting-out"><span class="std std-ref">opt out of paid advertising</span></a>
although you will still see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#community-ads"><span class="std std-ref">community ads</span></a>.
You can go ad-free by <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/gold/">becoming a Gold member</a> or a <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/sustainability/#donations">Supporter</a> of Read the Docs.
Gold members can also remove advertising from their projects for all visitors.</p>
<p>For businesses looking to remove advertising,
please consider <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs for Business</span></a>.</p>
<div class="toctree-wrapper compound">
<span id="document-advertising/ethical-advertising"></span><section id="ethicalads">
<h4>EthicalAds<a class="headerlink" href="#ethicalads" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs is a large, free web service.
There is one proven business model to support this kind of site: <strong>Advertising</strong>.
We are building the advertising model we want to exist,
and we‚Äôre calling it <strong>EthicalAds</strong>.</p>
<p><strong>EthicalAds respect users while providing value to advertisers.</strong>
We don‚Äôt track you, sell your data, or anything else.
We simply show ads to users, based on the content of the pages you look at.
We also give 10% of our ad space to <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#community-ads"><span class="std std-ref">community projects</span></a>,
as our way of saying thanks to the open source community.</p>
<p>We talk a bit below about <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#our-worldview"><span class="std std-ref">our worldview on advertising</span></a>,
if you want to know more.</p>
<div class="admonition-are-you-a-marketer admonition">
<p class="admonition-title">Are you a marketer?</p>
<p>We built a <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ethicalads.io/?ref=rtd-docs">whole business</a>
around privacy-focused advertising.
If you‚Äôre trying to reach developers, we have a network of hand-approved sites (including Read the Docs)
where your ads are shown.</p>
</div>
<section id="feedback">
<h5>Feedback<a class="headerlink" href="#feedback" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We‚Äôre a community,
and we value your feedback.
If you ever want to reach out about this effort,
feel free to <a class="reference external" href="mailto:rev&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">shoot us an email</a>.</p>
<p>You can <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#opting-out"><span class="std std-ref">opt out</span></a> of having paid ads on your projects,
or seeing paid ads if you want.
You will still see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#community-ads"><span class="std std-ref">community ads</span></a>,
which we run for free that promote community projects.</p>
</section>
<section id="our-worldview">
<h5>Our worldview<a class="headerlink" href="#our-worldview" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We‚Äôre building the advertising model we want to exist:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>We don‚Äôt track you</p></li>
<li><p>We don‚Äôt sell your data</p></li>
<li><p>We host everything ourselves, no third-party scripts or images</p></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>We‚Äôre doing newspaper advertising,
on the internet.</strong>
For a hundred years,
newspapers put an ad on the page,
some folks would see it,
and advertisers would pay for this.
This is our model.</p>
<p>So much ad tech has been built to track users.
Following them across the web,
from site to site,
showing the same ads and gathering data about them.
Then retailers sell your purchase data to try and attribute sales to advertising.
Now there is an industry in doing <a class="reference external" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Click_fraud">fake ad clicks</a> and other scams,
which leads the ad industry to track you even more intrusively to know more about you.
The current advertising industry is in a vicious downward spiral.</p>
<p>As developers,
we understand the <a class="reference external" href="http://idlewords.com/talks/what_happens_next_will_amaze_you.htm">massive downsides</a> of the current advertising industry.
This includes malware,
slow site performance,
and huge databases of your personal data being sold to the highest bidder.</p>
<p>The trend in advertising is to have larger and larger ads.
They should run before your content,
they should take over the page,
the bigger, weirder, or flashier the better.</p>
<section id="we-opt-out">
<h6>We opt out<a class="headerlink" href="#we-opt-out" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>We don‚Äôt store personal information about you.</p></li>
<li><p>We only keep track of views and clicks.</p></li>
<li><p>We don‚Äôt build a profile of your personality to sell ads against.</p></li>
<li><p>We only show high quality ads from companies that are of interest to developers.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We are running a single,
small,
unobtrusive ad on documentation pages.
The products should be interesting to you.
The ads won‚Äôt flash or move.</p>
<p>We run the ads we want to have on our site,
in a way that makes us feel good.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="additional-details">
<h5>Additional details<a class="headerlink" href="#additional-details" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>We have additional documentation on the
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-advertising/advertising-details"><span class="doc">technical details of our advertising</span></a>
including our Do Not Track policy and our use of analytics.</p></li>
<li><p>We have an <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ethicalads.io/advertisers/faq/?ref=rtd-docs">advertising FAQ</a> written for advertisers.</p></li>
<li><p>We have gone into more detail about our views in our
<a class="reference external" href="https://blog.readthedocs.com/ads-on-read-the-docs/">blog post</a> about this topic.</p></li>
<li><p>Eric Holscher, one of our co-founders
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2016/aug/31/funding-oss-marketing-money/">talks a bit more</a>
about funding open source this way on his blog.</p></li>
<li><p>After proving our ad model as a way to fund open source and building our ad serving infrastructure,
we launched the <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ethicalads.io?ref=rtd-docs">EthicalAds network</a>
to help other projects be sustainable.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="join-us">
<h5>Join us<a class="headerlink" href="#join-us" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We‚Äôre building the advertising model we want to exist.
We hope that others will join us in this mission:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><strong>If you‚Äôre a developer</strong>,
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2016/aug/31/funding-oss-marketing-money/">talk to your marketing folks</a> about using advertising that respects your privacy.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>If you‚Äôre a marketer</strong>,
vote with your dollars and support us in building the ad model we want to exist.
<a class="reference external" href="https://www.ethicalads.io/advertisers/?ref=rtd-docs">Get more information</a> on what we offer.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="community-ads">
<h5>Community Ads<a class="headerlink" href="#community-ads" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>There are a large number of projects, conferences, and initiatives
that we care about in the software and open source ecosystems.
A large number of them operate like we did in the past, with almost no income.
Our Community Ads program will highlight some of these projects.</p>
<p>There are a few qualifications for our Community Ads program:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Your organization and the linked site should not be trying to entice
visitors to buy a product or service.
We make an exception for conferences around open source projects
if they are run not for profit and soliciting donations for open source projects.</p></li>
<li><p>A software project should have an <a class="reference external" href="https://opensource.org/licenses">OSI approved license</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>We will not run a community ad for an organization tied
to one of our paid advertisers.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We‚Äôll show 10% of our ad inventory each month to support initiatives that we care about.
Please <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ethicalads.io/community-ads/?ref=docs.readthedocs.io">complete an application</a> to be considered for our Community Ads program.</p>
</section>
<section id="opting-out">
<h5>Opting out<a class="headerlink" href="#opting-out" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We have added multiple ways to opt out of the advertising on Read the Docs.</p>
<ol class="arabic">
<li><p>You can go completely ad-free
by becoming a <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/gold/">Gold member</a>
or a <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/sustainability/#donations">Supporter</a>.
Additionally, Gold members may remove advertising from their projects for all visitors.</p></li>
<li><p>You can opt out of seeing paid advertisements on documentation pages:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to the drop down user menu in the top right of the Read the Docs dashboard and clicking <span class="guilabel">Settings</span> (<a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/edit/">https://readthedocs.org/accounts/edit/</a>).</p></li>
<li><p>On the <span class="guilabel">Advertising</span> tab, you can deselect <strong>See paid advertising</strong>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You will still see <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#community-ads"><span class="std std-ref">community ads</span></a>
for open source projects and conferences.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Project owners can also opt out of paid advertisements for their projects.
You can change these options:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Go to your <strong>project</strong> page (<code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/projects/&lt;slug&gt;/</span></code>)</p></li>
<li><p>Go to <span class="guilabel">Admin</span> &gt; <span class="guilabel">Advertising</span></p></li>
<li><p>Change your advertising settings</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>If you are part of a company that uses Read the Docs to host documentation for a commercial product,
we offer <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-commercial/index"><span class="doc">Read the Docs for Business</span></a> that offers a completely ad-free experience,
additional build resources, and other great features like CDN support and private documentation.</p></li>
<li><p>If you would like to completely remove advertising from your open source project,
but our commercial plans don‚Äôt seem like the right fit,
please <a class="reference external" href="mailto:ads&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org?subject=Alternatives%20to%20advertising">get in touch</a> to discuss alternatives to advertising.</p></li>
</ol>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-advertising/advertising-details"></span><section id="advertising-details">
<h4>Advertising details<a class="headerlink" href="#advertising-details" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs largely funds our operations and development through advertising.
However, we aren‚Äôt willing to compromise our values, document authors,
or site visitors simply to make a bit more money.
That‚Äôs why we created our
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-advertising/ethical-advertising"><span class="doc">ethical advertising</span></a> initiative.</p>
<p>We get a lot of inquiries about our approach to advertising which range
from questions about our practices to requests to partner.
The goal of this document is to shed light on the advertising industry,
exactly what we do for advertising, and how what we do is different.
If you have questions or comments,
<a class="reference external" href="mailto:ads&#37;&#52;&#48;readthedocs&#46;org">send us an email</a>
or <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/issues">open an issue on GitHub</a>.</p>
<section id="other-ad-networks-targeting">
<h5>Other ad networks‚Äô targeting<a class="headerlink" href="#other-ad-networks-targeting" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Some ad networks build a database of user data in order to predict the types
of ads that are likely to be clicked.
In the advertising industry, this is called <em>behavioral targeting</em>.
This can include data such as:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>sites a user has visited</p></li>
<li><p>a user‚Äôs search history</p></li>
<li><p>ads, pages, or stories a user has clicked on in the past</p></li>
<li><p>demographic information such as age, gender, or income level</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Typically, getting a user‚Äôs page visit history is accomplished by the use of trackers
(sometimes called beacons or pixels).
For example, if a site uses a tracker from an ad network and a user visits that site,
the site can now target future advertising to that user ‚Äì a known past visitor ‚Äì
with that network. This is called <em>retargeting</em>.</p>
<p>Other ad predictions are made by grouping similar users
together based on user data using machine learning.
Frequently this involves an advertiser uploading personal data on users
(often past customers of the advertiser)
to an ad network and telling the network to target similar users.
The idea is that two users with similar demographic information
and similar interests would like the same products.
In ad tech, this is known as <em>lookalike audiences</em> or <em>similar audiences</em>.</p>
<p>Understandably, many people have concerns about these targeting techniques.
The modern advertising industry has built enormous value by centralizing
massive amounts of data on as many people as possible.</p>
</section>
<section id="our-targeting-details">
<h5>Our targeting details<a class="headerlink" href="#our-targeting-details" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p><strong>Read the Docs doesn‚Äôt use the above techniques</strong>.
Instead, we target based solely upon:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Details of the page where the advertisement is shown including:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>The name, keywords, or programming language associated with the project being viewed</p></li>
<li><p>Content of the page (eg. H1, title, theme, etc.)</p></li>
<li><p>Whether the page is being viewed from a mobile device</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>General geography</p>
<ul>
<li><p>We allow advertisers to target ads to a list of countries or to exclude
countries from their advertising. For ads targeting the USA, we also support
targeting by state or by metro area (DMA specifically).</p></li>
<li><p>We geolocate a user‚Äôs IP address to a country when a request is made.</p></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="where-ads-are-shown">
<h5>Where ads are shown<a class="headerlink" href="#where-ads-are-shown" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>We can place ads in:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>the sidebar navigation</p></li>
<li><p>the footer of the page</p></li>
<li><p>on search result pages</p></li>
<li><p>a small footer fixed to the bottom of the viewport</p></li>
<li><p>on 404 pages (rare)</p></li>
</ul>
<p>We show no more than one ad per page so you will never see both
a sidebar ad and a footer ad on the same page.</p>
</section>
<section id="do-not-track-policy">
<h5>Do Not Track Policy<a class="headerlink" href="#do-not-track-policy" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Read the Docs supports Do Not Track (DNT) and respects users‚Äô tracking preferences.
For more details, see the <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#do-not-track"><span class="std std-ref">Do Not Track section</span></a>
of our privacy policy.</p>
</section>
<section id="ad-serving-infrastructure">
<h5>Ad serving infrastructure<a class="headerlink" href="#ad-serving-infrastructure" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Our <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/ethical-ad-server">entire ad server</a> is open source,
so you can inspect how we‚Äôre doing things.
We believe strongly in open source, and we practice what we preach.</p>
</section>
<section id="analytics">
<h5>Analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Analytics are a sensitive enough issue that they require their own section.
In the spirit of full transparency, Read the Docs uses Google Analytics (GA).
We go into a bit of detail on our use of GA in our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-privacy-policy"><span class="doc">Privacy Policy</span></a>.</p>
<p>GA is a contentious issue inside Read the Docs and in our community.
Some users are very sensitive and privacy conscious to usage of GA.
Some authors want their own analytics on their docs to see the usage their docs get.
The developers at Read the Docs understand that different users have different priorities
and we try to respect the different viewpoints as much as possible while also accomplishing
our own goals.</p>
<p>We have taken steps to address some of the privacy concerns surrounding GA.
These steps apply both to analytics collected by Read the Docs and when
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#enabling-google-analytics-on-your-project"><span class="std std-ref">authors enable analytics on their docs</span></a>.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Users can opt-out of analytics by using the Do Not Track feature of their browser.</p></li>
<li><p>Read the Docs instructs Google to anonymize IP addresses sent to them.</p></li>
<li><p>The cookie set by GA is a session (non-persistent) cookie rather than the default 2 years.</p></li>
<li><p>Project maintainers can completely disable analytics on their own projects.
Follow the steps in <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#disabling-google-analytics-on-your-project"><span class="std std-ref">Disabling Google Analytics on your project</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<section id="why-we-use-analytics">
<h6>Why we use analytics<a class="headerlink" href="#why-we-use-analytics" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>Advertisers ask us questions that are easily answered with an analytics solution like
‚Äúhow many users do you have in Switzerland browsing Python docs?‚Äù. We need to be able
to easily get this data. We also use data from GA for some development decisions such
as what browsers to support (or not) or how much usage a particular page or feature gets.</p>
</section>
<section id="alternatives">
<h6>Alternatives<a class="headerlink" href="#alternatives" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h6>
<p>We are always exploring our options with respect to analytics.
There are alternatives but none of them are without downsides.
Some alternatives are:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Run a different cloud analytics solution from a provider other than Google
(eg. Parse.ly, Matomo Cloud, Adobe Analytics).
We priced a couple of these out based on our load and they are very expensive.
They also just substitute one problem of data sharing with another.</p></li>
<li><p>Send data to GA (or another cloud analytics provider) on the server side and
strip or anonymize personal data such as IPs before sending them.
This would be a complex solution and involve additional infrastructure,
but it would have many advantages. It would result in a loss of data on
‚Äúsessions‚Äù and new vs. returning visitors which are of limited value to us.</p></li>
<li><p>Run a local JavaScript based analytics solution (eg. Matomo community).
This involves additional infrastructure that needs to be always up.
Frequently there are very large databases associated with this.
Many of these solutions aren‚Äôt built to handle Read the Docs‚Äô load.</p></li>
<li><p>Run a local analytics solution based on web server log parsing.
This has the same infrastructure problems as above while also
not capturing all the data we want (without additional engineering) like the
programming language of the docs being shown or
whether the docs are built with Sphinx or something else.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-advertising/ad-blocking"></span><section id="ad-blocking">
<h4>Ad blocking<a class="headerlink" href="#ad-blocking" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Ad blockers fulfill a legitimate need
to mitigate the significant downsides of advertising
from tracking across the internet,
security implications of third-party code,
and impacting the UX and performance of sites.</p>
<p>At Read the Docs, we specifically didn‚Äôt want those things.
That‚Äôs why we built the our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-advertising/ethical-advertising"><span class="doc">Ethical Ad initiative</span></a>
with only relevant, unobtrusive ads that respect your privacy
and don‚Äôt do creepy behavioral targeting.</p>
<p>Advertising is the single largest source of funding for Read the Docs.
To keep our operations sustainable, we ask that you either
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#allowing-ethicalads"><span class="std std-ref">allow our EthicalAds</span></a>
or <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#going-ad-free"><span class="std std-ref">go ad-free</span></a>.</p>
<section id="allowing-ethicalads">
<h5>Allowing EthicalAds<a class="headerlink" href="#allowing-ethicalads" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>If you use AdBlock or AdBlockPlus
and you allow <a class="reference external" href="https://adblockplus.org/en/acceptable-ads">acceptable ads</a> or <a class="reference external" href="https://adblockplus.org/en/acceptable-ads#privacy-friendly-acceptable-ads">privacy-friendly acceptable ads</a>
then you‚Äôre all set.
Advertising on Read the Docs complies with both of these programs.</p>
<p>If you prefer not to allow acceptable ads
but would consider allowing <a class="reference external" href="https://ads-for-open-source.readthedocs.io/en/latest/">ads that benefit open source</a>,
please consider subscribing to either the wider <strong>Open Source Ads list</strong>
or simply the <strong>Read the Docs Ads list</strong>.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://ads-for-open-source.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation.html#installing-on-adblock">Setup for AdBlock</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://ads-for-open-source.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation.html#installing-on-adblockplus">Setup for AdBlockPlus</a></p></li>
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://ads-for-open-source.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation.html#installing-on-ublock-origin">Setup for uBlock Origin</a></p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p>Because of the way Read the Docs is structured
where docs are hosted on many different domains,
adding a normal ad block exception
will only allow that single domain not Read the Docs as a whole.</p>
</div>
</section>
<section id="going-ad-free">
<h5>Going ad-free<a class="headerlink" href="#going-ad-free" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>Users can go completely ad-free when logged in
by becoming a <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/accounts/gold/">Gold member</a>
or a <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/sustainability/#donations">Supporter</a>.
Gold members may also completely remove advertising for all visitors to their projects.
Thank you for supporting Read the Docs.</p>
</section>
<section id="statistics-and-data">
<h5>Statistics and data<a class="headerlink" href="#statistics-and-data" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h5>
<p>It can be really hard to find good data on ad blocking.
In the spirit of transparency,
here is the data we have on ad blocking at Read the Docs.</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p><a class="reference external" href="https://blog.readthedocs.com/ads-and-adblocking/">32% of Read the Docs users use an ad blocker</a></p></li>
<li><p>Of those, <a class="reference external" href="https://blog.readthedocs.com/ad-blocker-update/">a little over 50% allow acceptable ads</a></p></li>
<li><p>Read the Docs users running ad blockers click on ads at about the same rate
as those not running an ad blocker.</p></li>
<li><p>Comparing with our server logs,
roughly 28% of our hits did not register a Google Analytics (GA) pageview
due to an ad blocker, privacy plugin, disabling JavaScript, or another reason.</p></li>
<li><p>Of users who do not block GA,
about 6% opt out of analytics on Read the Docs by enabling
<a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="index.html#do-not-track"><span class="std std-ref">Do Not Track</span></a>.</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
</section>
</div>
</section>
<span id="document-story"></span><section id="the-story-of-read-the-docs">
<h3>The story of Read the Docs<a class="headerlink" href="#the-story-of-read-the-docs" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Documenting projects is hard, hosting them shouldn‚Äôt be. Read the Docs was created to make hosting documentation simple.</p>
<p>Read the Docs was <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2010/aug/16/announcing-read-docs/">started</a> with a couple main goals in mind. The first goal was
to encourage people to write documentation, by removing the barrier of entry to
hosting. The other goal was to create a central platform for people to find
documentation. Having a shared platform for all documentation allows for
innovation at the platform level, allowing work to be done once and benefit
everyone.</p>
<p><a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2012/jan/22/why-read-docs-matters/">Documentation matters</a>, but its often overlooked. We think that we can help a
documentation culture flourish.
Great projects, such as <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.djangoproject.com/">Django</a> and <a class="reference external" href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/">SQLAlchemy</a>, and projects from companies
like <a class="reference external" href="https://www.mozilla.org">Mozilla</a>, are already using Read the Docs to serve their documentation to
the world.</p>
<p>The site has grown quite a bit over the past year.
Our <a class="reference external" href="https://www.ericholscher.com/blog/2013/dec/23/read-the-docs-2013-stats/">look back at 2013</a> shows some numbers that show our progress.
The job isn‚Äôt anywhere near done yet,
but it‚Äôs a great honor to be able to have such an impact already.</p>
<p>We plan to keep building a great experience for people hosting their docs with us,
and for users of the documentation that we host.</p>
</section>

<span id="document-open-source-philosophy"></span><section id="read-the-docs-open-source-philosophy">
<h3>Read the Docs open source philosophy<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-open-source-philosophy" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>Read the Docs is open source software.
We have <a class="reference external" href="https://github.com/readthedocs/readthedocs.org/blob/main/LICENSE">licensed</a> the code base as MIT,
which provides almost no restrictions on the use of the code.</p>
<p>However,
as a project there are things that we care about more than others.
We built Read the Docs to support documentation in the open source community.
The code is open for people to contribute to,
so that they may build features into <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org">https://readthedocs.org</a> that they want.
We also believe sharing the code openly is a valuable learning tool,
especially for demonstrating how to collaborate and maintain an enormous website.</p>
<section id="official-support">
<h4>Official support<a class="headerlink" href="#official-support" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>The time of the core developers of Read the Docs is limited.
We provide official support for the following things:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Local development on the Python code base</p></li>
<li><p>Usage of <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org">https://readthedocs.org</a> for open source projects</p></li>
<li><p>Bug fixes in the code base, as it applies to running it on <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org">https://readthedocs.org</a></p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="unsupported">
<h4>Unsupported<a class="headerlink" href="#unsupported" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>There are use cases that we don‚Äôt support,
because it doesn‚Äôt further our goal of promoting documentation in the open source community.</p>
<p>We do not support:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Specific usage of Sphinx and Mkdocs, that don‚Äôt affect our hosting</p></li>
<li><p>Custom installations of Read the Docs at your company</p></li>
<li><p>Installation of Read the Docs on other platforms</p></li>
<li><p>Any installation issues outside of the Read the Docs Python Code</p></li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="rationale">
<h4>Rationale<a class="headerlink" href="#rationale" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>Read the Docs was founded to improve documentation in the open source community.
We fully recognize and allow the code to be used for internal installs at companies,
but we will not spend our time supporting it.
Our time is limited,
and we want to spend it on the mission that we set out to originally support.</p>
<p>If you feel strongly about installing Read the Docs internal to a company,
we will happily link to third party resources on this topic.
Please open an issue with a proposal if you want to take on this task.</p>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-team"></span><section id="read-the-docs-team">
<h3>Read the Docs team<a class="headerlink" href="#read-the-docs-team" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>readthedocs.org is the largest open source documentation hosting service.
Today we:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Serve over <strong>55 million pages</strong> of documentation a month</p></li>
<li><p>Serve over <strong>40 TB</strong> of documentation a month</p></li>
<li><p>Host over <strong>80,000 open source projects</strong> and support over <strong>100,000 users</strong></p></li>
</ul>
<p>Read the Docs is provided as a free service to the open source community,
and we hope to maintain a reliable and stable hosting platform for years to come.</p>
<div class="admonition seealso">
<p class="admonition-title">See also</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt><a class="reference external" href="https://about.readthedocs.com/company/">Our website: Who we are</a></dt><dd><p>More information about the staff and contributors of Read the Docs.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
</div>
<section id="teams">
<h4>Teams<a class="headerlink" href="#teams" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>The <strong>Backend Team</strong> folks develop the Django code that powers the backend of the project.</p></li>
<li><p>The members of the <strong>Frontend Team</strong> care about UX, CSS, HTML, and JavaScript,
and they maintain the project UI as well as the Sphinx theme.</p></li>
<li><p>As part of operating the site, members of the <strong>Operations Team</strong> maintain a 24/7 on-call rotation.
This means that folks have to be available and have their phone in service.</p></li>
<li><p>The members of the <strong>Advocacy Team</strong> spread the word about all the work we do,
and seek to understand the users priorities and feedback.</p></li>
<li><p>The <strong>Support Team</strong> helps our thousands of users using the service,
addressing tasks like resetting passwords, enable experimental features, or troubleshooting build errors.</p></li>
</ul>
<div class="admonition note">
<p class="admonition-title">Note</p>
<p><strong>Please don‚Äôt email us personally for support on Read the Docs.</strong>
You can <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/support/">use our support form</a>
for any issues you may have.</p>
</div>
</section>
</section>
<span id="document-support"></span><section id="site-support">
<h3>Site support<a class="headerlink" href="#site-support" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<section id="usage-questions">
<h4>Usage questions<a class="headerlink" href="#usage-questions" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h4>
<p>If you have questions about how to use Read the Docs, or have an issue that
isn‚Äôt related to a bug, <a class="reference external" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/read-the-docs">Stack Overflow</a> is the best place to ask.  Tag
questions with <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">read-the-docs</span></code> so other folks can find them easily.</p>
<p>Good questions for Stack Overflow would be:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>‚ÄúWhat is the best way to structure the table of contents across a project?‚Äù</p></li>
<li><p>‚ÄúHow do I structure translations inside of my project for easiest contribution from users?‚Äù</p></li>
<li><p>‚ÄúHow do I use Sphinx to use SVG images in HTML output but PNG in PDF output?‚Äù</p></li>
</ul>
<p>You might also find the answers you are looking for in our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/index"><span class="doc">documentation guides</span></a>.
These provide step-by-step solutions to common user requirements.</p>
</section>
<section id="user-support">

like more resources, change of the project‚Äôs slug or username.</p>

<span id="document-glossary"></span><section id="glossary">
<h3>Glossary<a class="headerlink" href="#glossary" title="Permalink to this heading">ÔÉÅ</a></h3>
<p>This page includes a number of terms that we use in our documentation,
so that you have a reference for how we‚Äôre using them.</p>
<dl class="glossary">
<dt id="term-CI-CD">CI/CD<a class="headerlink" href="#term-CI-CD" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>CI/CD is a common way to write <em>Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment</em>.
In some scenarios, they exist as two separate platforms.
Read the Docs is a combined CI/CD platform made for documentation.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-dashboard">dashboard<a class="headerlink" href="#term-dashboard" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>The ‚Äúadmin‚Äù site where Read the Docs projects are managed and configured.
This varies for our two properties:</p>
<blockquote>
<div><ul class="simple">
<li><p>Read the Docs for Business: <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/">https://readthedocs.com/dashboard/</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Read the Docs Community: <a class="reference external" href="https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/">https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/</a>.</p></li>
</ul>
</div></blockquote>
</dd>
<dt id="term-default-version">default version<a class="headerlink" href="#term-default-version" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Projects have a <em>default version</em>, usually the latest stable version of a project.
The <em>default version</em> is the URL that is redirected to when a users loads the <code class="xref py py-obj docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/</span></code> URL for your project.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-discoverability">discoverability<a class="headerlink" href="#term-discoverability" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A documentation page is said to be <em>discoverable</em> when a user that needs it can find it through various methods:
Navigation, search, and links from other pages are the most typical ways of making content <em>discoverable</em>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-Docs-as-Code">Docs as Code<a class="headerlink" href="#term-Docs-as-Code" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A term used to describe the workflow of keeping documentation in a Git repository,
along with source code.
Popular in the open source software movement,
and used by many technology companies.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-flyout-menu">flyout menu<a class="headerlink" href="#term-flyout-menu" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Menu displayed on the documentation, readily accessible for readers, containing the list active versions, links to static downloads, and other useful links.
Read more in our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-flyout-menu"><span class="doc">Flyout menu</span></a> page.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-GitOps">GitOps<a class="headerlink" href="#term-GitOps" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Denotes the use of code maintained in Git to automate building, testing, and deployment of infrastructure.
In terms of documentation,
GitOps is applicable for Read the Docs,
as the configuration for building documentation is stored in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.yaml</span></code>,
and rules for publication of documentation can be <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-automation-rules"><span class="doc">automated</span></a>.
Similar to <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#term-Docs-as-Code"><span class="xref std std-term">Docs as Code</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-pinning">pinning<a class="headerlink" href="#term-pinning" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>To <em>pin</em> a requirement means to explicitly specify which version should be used.
<em>Pinning</em> software requirements is the most important technique to make a project <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#term-reproducible"><span class="xref std std-term">reproducible</span></a>.</p>
<p>When documentation builds,
software dependencies are installed in their latest versions permitted by the pinning specification.
Since software packages are frequently released,
we are usually trying to avoid incompatibilities in a new release from suddenly breaking a documentation build.</p>
<p>Examples of Python dependencies:</p>
<div class="highlight-default notranslate"><div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Exact pinning: Only allow Sphinx 5.3.0</span>
<span class="n">sphinx</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mf">5.3.0</span>

<span class="c1"># Loose pinning: Lower and upper bounds result in the latest 5.3.x release</span>
<span class="n">sphinx</span><span class="o">&gt;=</span><span class="mf">5.3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="o">&lt;</span><span class="mf">5.4</span>

<span class="c1"># Very loose pinning: Lower and upper bounds result in the latest 5.x release</span>
<span class="n">sphinx</span><span class="o">&gt;=</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="o">&lt;</span><span class="mi">6</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
<p>Read the Docs recommends using <strong>exact pinning</strong>.</p>
<p>See: <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">How to create reproducible builds</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-pre-defined-build-jobs">pre-defined build jobs<a class="headerlink" href="#term-pre-defined-build-jobs" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Commands executed by Read the Docs when performing the build process.
They cannot be overwritten by the user.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-project-home">project home<a class="headerlink" href="#term-project-home" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Page where you can access all the features of Read the Docs,
from having an overview to browsing the latest builds or administering your project.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-project-page">project page<a class="headerlink" href="#term-project-page" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Another name for <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" href="#term-project-home"><span class="xref std std-term">project home</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-reproducible">reproducible<a class="headerlink" href="#term-reproducible" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A documentation project is said to be <em>reproducible</em> when its sources build correctly on Read the Docs over a periode of many years.
You can also think of being <em>reproducible</em> as being <em>robust</em> or <em>resillient</em>.</p>
<p>Being ‚Äúreproducible‚Äù is an important positive quality goal of documentation.</p>
<p>When builds are not reproducible and break due to external factors,
they need frequent troubleshooting and manual fixing.</p>
<p>The most common external factor is that new versions of software dependencies are released.</p>
<p>See: <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/reproducible-builds"><span class="doc">How to create reproducible builds</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-root-URL">root URL<a class="headerlink" href="#term-root-URL" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Home URL of your documentation without the <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/&lt;lang&gt;</span></code> and <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/&lt;version&gt;</span></code> segments.
For projects without custom domains, the one ending in <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">.readthedocs.io/</span></code>
(for example, <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.readthedocs.io</span></code> as opposed to <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest</span></code>).</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-slug">slug<a class="headerlink" href="#term-slug" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A unique identifier for a project or version. This value comes from the
project or version name, which is reduced to lowercase letters, numbers,
and hyphens. You can retrieve your project or version slugs from
<a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-api/v3"><span class="doc">our API</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-static-website">static website<a class="headerlink" href="#term-static-website" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A static site or static website is a collection of HTML files, images, CSS and JavaScript that are served statically,
as opposed to dynamic websites that generate a unique response for each request, using databases and user sessions.</p>
<p>Static websites are highly portable, as they do not depend on the webserver.
They can also be viewed offline.</p>
<p>Documentation projects served on Read the Docs are <em>static websites</em>.</p>
<p>Tools to manage and generate static websites are commonly known as <em>static site generators</em> and there is a big overlap with documentation tools.
Some static site generators are also documentation tools,
and some documentation tools are also used to generate normal websites.</p>
<p>For instance, <a class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference external" href="https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/index.html" title="(in Sphinx v7.1.0)"><span class="xref std std-doc">Sphinx</span></a> is made for documentation but also used for blogging.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-subproject">subproject<a class="headerlink" href="#term-subproject" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Project A can be configured such that when requesting a URL <code class="docutils literal notranslate"><span class="pre">/projects/&lt;subproject-slug&gt;</span></code>,
the root of project B is returned.
In this case, <em>project B</em> is the subproject.
Read more in <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-subprojects"><span class="doc">Subprojects: host multiple projects on a single domain</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-user-defined-build-jobs">user-defined build jobs<a class="headerlink" href="#term-user-defined-build-jobs" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>Commands defined by the user that Read the Docs will execute when performing the build process.</p>
</dd>
<dt id="term-webhook">webhook<a class="headerlink" href="#term-webhook" title="Permalink to this term">ÔÉÅ</a></dt><dd><p>A webhook is a special URL that can be called from another service,
usually with a secret token.
It is commonly used to start a build or a deployment or to send a status update.</p>
<p>There are two important types of webhooks for Read the Docs:</p>
<ul class="simple">
<li><p>Git providers have webhooks which are special URLs that Read the Docs can call in order to notify about documentation builds.</p></li>
<li><p>Read the Docs has a unique webhook for each project that the Git provider calls when changes happen in Git.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>See also: <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-guides/git-integrations"><span class="doc">How to manually connect your Git repository</span></a> and <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-build-notifications"><span class="doc">Build Notifications and Webhooks</span></a></p>
</dd>
</dl>
</section>
</div>
</section>
</div>
<a style="display: none;" rel="me" href="https://fosstodon.org/@readthedocs">Mastodon</a><p>Read the Docs simplifies software documentation
by building, versioning, and hosting of your docs, automatically.
Treating documentation like code keeps your team in the same tools,
and your documentation up to date.</p>
<dl class="simple">
<dt>üîÑ Up to date documentation</dt><dd><p>Whenever you push code to Git,
Read the Docs will automatically build your docs
so your code and documentation are always up-to-date.
Get started with our <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-tutorial/index"><span class="doc">tutorial</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>üóÇÔ∏è Documentation for every version</dt><dd><p>Read the Docs can host multiple versions of your docs.
Keep your 1.0 and 2.0 documentation online,
pulled directly from Git.
Start hosting all your <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-versions"><span class="doc">versions</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>üíì Open source and user focused</dt><dd><p>Our company is bootstrapped and 100% user-focused,
so our product gets better for our users instead of our investors.
Read the Docs Community hosts documentation for over 100,000 large
and small open source projects.
Read the Docs for Business supports hundreds of organizations with product and internal documentation.
Learn more about <a class="reference internal" href="index.html#document-choosing-a-site"><span class="doc">our two platforms</span></a>.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
